151364559.review:
A pesar de las numerosas críticas negativas de este último juego de la saga, he de decir que me ha gustado mucho.
[i]Es verdad que VLR me parece el mejor juego, con la mejor historia y personajes, pero ZTD también es bueno en estas cosas, aún con los problemas de animación de personajes y algunos agujeros de la trama inexplicados.[/i]

Puntos positivos:
[list]
[*] [b]Personajes.[/b] Son buenos, aunque me gustaría haber tenido más historia de Mira y alguna aparición/flashback de otros personajes pasados.
[*] [b]Trama.[/b] Está bien en mi opinión y cumple con las expectativas de lo que podía ocurrir en Dcom. Además de que cierra algunos agujeros que dejó sin responder VLR.
[*] [b]Giros de guión.[/b] Han estado bien, aunque no a la altura de los de VLR y 999. Y el de la identidad de Zero me sorprendió, pero me parece algo muy poco creíble para la trama.
[*] [b]Temática.[/b] Que el juego trate de líneas temporales es algo muy interesante y que es diferente de otros juegos, y vuelve a estos únicos. En este juego este aspecto lo han hecho muy bien, teniendo en cuenta la gran cantidad de saltos que ocurren.
[*] [b]Escape rooms.[/b] Las salas de este juego, al igual que en VLR, están bien diseñadas y te hacen pensar.
[*] [b]Decisiones finales.[/b] Hay gente que no les ha gustado, pero a mí me han parecido interesantes y acertadas. Son algo nuevo diferente a las preguntas AB de VLR y con curiosidades matemáticas.
[*] [b]OST.[/b] La música y el tema principal es de lo mejor de estos juegos.
[/list]

Puntos negativos:
[list]
[*] [b]Falta de indicaciones.[/b] El juego era un poco complicado de seguir el hilo. No digo que la idea no estuviera bien y era interesante no seguir una línea ordenada. Pero ha habido una ocasión que me he quedado bloqueado porque no sabía continuar, y fue porque es necesario ver todas las cinemáticas posteriores a las votaciones iniciales (la de todos vivos y las 3 de ejecuciones) para desbloquear los últimos fragmentos.
[*] [b]Final demasiado abierto.[/b] El final no estuvo del todo mal pero deja muchas dudas innecesarias y que se podrían haber resuelto con cinemáticas posteriores. Pero al menos metieron algunos archivos de información sobre el futuro de Carlos y María, Junpei y Akane, y Mira y Eric (Esto no todo el mundo lo ha visto y responde algunas dudas del final). [spoiler] Hay dudas problemáticas. Por ejemplo, ¿qué ocurre con Quark? ¿en esta línea temporal final feliz Junpei no lo conoce nunca? Y tampoco sabemos nada de Clover, que era un personaje que me gustaba mucho, ni de Santa. [/spoiler]
[*] [b]Giros de guión absurdos.[/b] Hay algún giro de trama algo absurdo y que no es muy creíble. Como ya he dicho antes, el de la identidad de Zero deja que desear.
[*] [b]Animación de personajes.[/b] La animación no ha brillado nunca en esta saga, pero me gustaba más la de VLR. En este juego eran un poco decepcionantes las expresiones de los personajes en las cinemáticas, habría preferido textos de diálogo como en VLR o 999. Pero el apartado gráfico del juego y las salas estaba bien, y ha mejorado desde VLR, aunque no mucho.
[*] [b]Gore?.[/b] Quizás en este juego se han pasado un poco con las muertes sangrientas, pero no es nada problemático, sólo un apunte.
[/list]

El juego, para mí, está bien y da un buen cierre a la saga, aunque podría haber sido mejor.
Es una buena experiencia de juego y una historia hermosa, quitando las líneas temporales malas claro.

[b]De forma global, contando 999 y VLR, esta saga es una joya de videojuegos que tenéis que experimentar vosotros mismos y disfrutar, como yo hice. Me gustaría poder jugarlos de nuevo sin recordar nada.[/b]

150305531.review:
As someone who liked 999 a lot and came around to liking VLR by its truly wild and fantastical ending, I'm really torn on ZTD. I see similar fun puzzle rooms with similar intrigue and similar attention to detail in the narrative, but the culmination of everything feels so...clumsy and shlocky.

'Shlock' is a good word for it - it feels so over the top in service of very little. The Zero Escape series is no stranger to violence of all kinds, but never has it felt so unnecessarily pronounced and shoehorned in there. Why is the solution to this "open a door" puzzle a grenade launcher? Why is the solution to this "open a panel" puzzle a shotgun? Well, so that unstable people can have a weapon handy for incidental murder!

It's just...dumb. And not in the fun way! Characters' morality is flipped on and off as is needed to advance the plot, something that especially hurts the final "Decision Game" which involves a moral dilemma the group has been actively ignoring for the entire game. And it's clear nobody could remember how to write for the 999 characters. I sincerely don't mind characters changing and growing over time (e.g. I had no problems with any of the VLR characters), but damn did they do Jumpy dirty in this game.

VLR set up the Dcom Experiment as a fascinating puzzle box, but unfortunately it really feels like the writers couldn't figure out what was supposed to be inside it.

Ironic for a puzzle game.

150188429.review:
What an absolute failure of a conclusion to this series. Let me get this out of the way first, the puzzle rooms are fine, so is the music.
Everything else is pretty shit. The animations look like shit, characters constantly have their hair clipping through their shoulders and emotional moments sometimes look like a complete joke because of the models. VLR did mostly fine with its models(only having one or two strange faces) so what happened here?! 

And then there is the writing. Oh my god the writing. Its so fucking bad. Most of the cast is extremely boring and the twists either come off as half baked or just straight up stupid. Sometimes if feels like bad fanfiction. I could go on and on about how bad it is but I really just don't feel like it. I can't believe this garbage is in the same series as 999 and VLR. 

And then there is the formatting. Unlike the other two games each segment is completely separated from each other because the characters are always injected with memory erasing drugs and each group stays the same throughout the game. Plus there are like 3 different main characters instead of just one. This makes it hard to get invested in anything that is going on since you're constantly bouncing around to fragments of different routes, each completely irreverent to the last one you played besides maybe giving you a password or something. 

And then the main gimmick of this game. The decision game! These are just basic yes or no choices most of the time that just are basically just result in death or not death. One of them is particularly pointless where the characters are worrying about whether the antidote to a poison is also poisoned and they make you decide whether or not to take the antidote or not, but the characters are dying anyway! It doesn't fucking matter if its poisoned! This game is a joke. 

This game is really only worth playing if you absolutely need a conclusion to the series and in my opinion its only good for laughing at.

150086241.review:
To appreciate this game you have to understand that you're experiencing it in a very confusing and unsatisfying way at first. It took me some time to accept it. It's hard to appreciate the characters with the format the game makes you experience it. 

But at the end I honestly think this is the best "zero escape" game. The story is wrapped up beautifully, in my opinion. 

I still had some open questions, but they were very minor and, in fact, even without the game explaining it I could think of numerous explanations. I ended up really liking most characters and was actually interested for once in all the "sci-fi" in the game. 

It was really fun and interesting to think about some of it. The game made me re-think some sci-fi positions I had once thought it was obvious how I felt about it. For that alone, I think it is worth playing, with a grain of salt. This is a bit hard to get into and the first two games are also hard to experience as well and I think this is best experienced playing all of them.

148895161.review:
999 is one of my favorite story driven games of all time. And I thought Virtues Last Reward was a decent sequel minus the lame ending and the retconing of Alice. 
Zero Time Dilemma was supposed to wrap it all up but failed.

Pros:
- Rooms/Puzzles are challenging, if you are below 100 IQ you have no chance of beating this game.
- New characters are intriguing and entertaining.
- Sigma is Top G.

Cons:
- Junpei and Akane are unrecognizable compared to their personalities in 999 and VLR, this isn't "character growth" they are just completely different characters from what they used to be.
- Depending on which branch you go down you can run into situations where you can tell the developers didn't account for your choices, and as a result you have to go back and forth through timelines and hear the same dialogue and it just gets boring. Obviously the point of the game is to jump between timelines but it was done better in the first two. Confusing the player for no reason other than you didn't pick the right timeline first isn't good story telling.
- I've always thought the Radical-6 virus was a lame plot device and I never felt like it was implemented well into the story.
- VLR had some uncanny valley vibes with the characters faces but ZTD takes the cake. Many cringe moments when a characters face just freezes after they stop talking.

Kotaro Uchikoshi has great talent when it comes to designing puzzles and escape rooms but you can tell he has trouble developing satisfying conclusions to his stories. 999 is a fantastic build up of suspense and mystery but the ending leaves a few big questions unanswered which we assumed would be answered in VLR. In VLR we got the most interesting character; Alice, retconned into an annoying bitch with the lamest backstory ever and so much potential squandered. VLR didn't really answer the questions from 999 it just gave us more and ZTD does the same. It places itself in the middle of 999 and VLR and basically at the end it comes down to, "OH we shifted back to the timeline where we won the dumb coin flip so Radical-6 won't spread but for some dumb reason mankind will still go extinct (???). And this was all done so we would take 'saving the world' seriously." What are these characters fucking retarded?! This is the same logic the Saw movies use; "Oh we have to subject you to insane torture cause you smoke cigarettes, now that you suffered so much you'll appreciate life." Its just lame and bad story telling. Fans wanted closure after VLR and all we got was filler. This game just felt like an excuse to display some cool puzzles.

4/10

TL;DR
Cool puzzles with a bad story which is made to be confusing to distract you from the bad writing, reminds me of Kingdom Farts.

147837474.review:
If you really liked the first two games, you'll probably at least sort of enjoy this one, which is basically where I'm at.

I was really enraptured by the first two games in the Zero Escape series. A majority of the characters were charming and I wanted to know more about them. I didn't really feel that way about Zero Time Dilemma. You already know lots of the characters, and really only one of them has changed between entries. The new characters for the most part, state their motivations and defining character traits straight off the bat. I honestly didn't really like any of the new characters, I guess Diana is okay but that's because she's paired with Sigma and Phi, who were some of my favorites from Virtue's Last Reward. 

Besides the characters, I felt like this entry had so little to say in terms of themes. I don't even know the point of this game, spoilers ahead but, we already know most of what happens in this experiment. We know Phi and Sigma were infiltrating and the only surprise is that Junpei and Akane are there too. It doesn't really fulfill any promises it was setting up. The Radical-6 plot line is basically relegated to one branch from Q-teams flowchart. I thought that solving the Radical-6 crisis was the whole point but I felt like they barely mentioned it, and when it did come up, you finished out that fragment pretty quickly and the characters forgot about it. 

BIG SPOILER

I guess the twist that Phi is Sigma's daughter is neat, but there was almost no pay off for when she learns that. There was one hug between Sigma, Phi and Diana, but otherwise it doesn't really matter. Same with the reveal that Mira is a serial killer. It was relevant I think twice and then she gets off scot free. What was the point? Dio was the villain of the characters in VLR and he was such a prick and made it fun to hate him. Mira is just, kind of rude sometimes, and only scary in like two scenes. 

As for the gameplay, I thought the puzzles were fine. The repetition of being put to sleep by Zero and the characters remarking on it got really annoying. I didn't feel any tension like I did from escape rooms in 999 and VLR. The teams idea is okay in principle but it thoroughly restricts character interaction. They should have had the characters meet up much sooner on in the story. Jumping from fragment to fragment is kinda cool but it was much more frustrating to understand what was needed to unlock new fragments. Especially when you need to see the executions of all the teams. I went back to make sure every team voted for every other team, but I didn't understand that I technically hadn't seen the executions, so I had to look up online what I was missing. 

Anyway idk it's prob like a 5/10, definitely prefer 999 and VLR, but if you like those, you can play this and have the same feelings I do I guess.

147619863.review:
El final de la saga Zero Escape. La vida es injusta, y eso es algo que este juego se esforzará por demostrarte.

La historia, como en todos los demás juegos de la serie, está increíblemente bien hecha. La gran mayoría de puntos están hilados de una forma en la que todo tiene sentido, y la forma en la que se enfrentan al controvertido tema de "Viajes en el tiempo" me parece una de las mejores maneras de llevarla a cabo. Como siempre, el plot twist de este juego, como en los demás de la serie, es algo que te deja boquiabierto, aunque quizá no en tanta medida como en Virtue's Last Reward, pero sigue siendo bastante efectivo.
Quizá alguno de los nuevos personajes no resuene tanto con la audiencia como lo hicieron los demás grupos de los juegos anteriores, pero le dan una perspectiva a los hechos que resulta muy interesante.

Sin embargo, aunque la historia es una maravilla, la forma de contarlo no lo es tanto. Debido a problemas de presupuesto, las animaciones de las escenas sufrieron un gran golpe de calidad. Es algo que se nota muy rápidamente, y aunque el estilo artístico de Virtue's Last Reward definitivamente era algo a lo que acostumbrarse, la rigidez de los movimientos en este juego son algo mucho más difícil de tragar.

El otro punto importante del juego son los puzles. Como en los otros dos títulos, son Escape Rooms bastante bien hechas, y en general tienen la dificultad justa para darle vueltas las veces necesarias sin que se haga un dolor de cabeza. 
Hay excepciones, por supuesto: en algunos casos, los comentarios de los demás personajes durante estas partes te pueden dar tantas pistas que acaban por trivializar el puzle (como en 999), y en otras ocasiones, la complejidad de algunas mecánicas puede ser bastante abrumadora.

La banda sonora es una absoluta genialidad. Sabe cuándo ponerse intensa, y cuándo jugar con tu corazón para emocionarte como debe. Un gran acompañamiento al punto final de esta emblemática serie de viajes en el tiempo, teorías físico-cuánticas y Escape Rooms.

It's not the opinion you want to hear, but it's the one you deserve:
This game is... Ffffine... With that elongated Ffff.
If you like 999 and VLR a lot, this game is probably still worth it. Its puzzles are pretty good still especially. 
But if you are expecting the game to be anywhere near the quality of either of those other games, you are sorely mistaken. And that's oookay. There's still good moments in here all in all. It's just pretty rough.

I think the worst part of this game is probably the fact that it just doesn't have a good sense of mystery or consequence. Since you only sometimes see the direct results of your choices in the game because of the sleeping agent device, a lot of the decisions are trite and don't feel like they have consequence and you're just gonna watch both versions anyway. Additionally the game barely gives you anything to formulate questions with.
999 is very upfront with information and still pulls off a twist with you, VLR is cagey about giving answers but it gives SO much info and so many mysteries and plot-lines, but this game feels like you are an observer to events and you need to wait and see where it's going at all more than anything. Not a bad send-off to the series.  Be sure to play both of The Nonary Games (999, VLR) before you play this or you will be lost - this is the end of an epic trilogy.

A lot of people trash this game in reviews, but it's pretty solid.  By FAR the bloodiest one in the series, so be warned.  

The game does a fantastic job of dripping information at a steady pace, similar to the other games.  One or two twists were foreshadowed poorly, but I still enjoyed the ride.  The cast of characters grew on me by the end and I came to appreciate most of them.

If you've gotten this far in the series, finish it out!  While not the best entry in the series (999 holds that distinction for me), it's still a wild ride.

145727378.review:
Look, this game is not great. But I can't *not* reccomend it, if you've played the previous two Zero Escape games. Zero Time Dilemma is an utterly baffling conclusion to the story set up by 999 and Virtue's Last Reward, true. But man, it might be one of the most entertaining farces I've experienced in video game storytelling. Things will just happen, you'll be tossed around the timeline, flopping and gasping for context like a fish. The visuals will do their best to convey scenes, but be just shy of par. And honestly? It was delightful for me.

But hey, it's not all ironic enjoyment here. There ARE story beats I genuinely enjoy (mostly in D-Team, which  [spoiler]features cast members from Virtue's Last Reward[/spoiler]), and the escape rooms, I'd argue are marginally better than most of Virtue's Last Reward's. And personally, I really enjoyed the ending beat. Not the twist preceding it, felt that was a little much.  [spoiler]The ending itself, however, has a nice resolution that meshes with the Decision mechanic of the game, and the epilogues provided for some characters were nice.[/spoiler]


As a whole, Zero Time Dilemma is a game I think all Zero Escape fans need to experience. It's especially enhanced by going in unspoiled. Now, if you love it? Hate it? Find a sick ironic enjoyment in it? That's your decision to make. Personally I'm somewhere in the middle of all three, but I wouldn't trade the experience I had here for the world. For better or worse, there will never be another visual novel game like Zero Time Dilemma.

142242481.review:
I highly recommend this game! But just like the other reviews for this game, make sure you play the other games in the series, they're absolutely amazing as well, but practically necessary to play this game. It would be incredibly confusing for someone playing this without the previous knowledge of the other games.

First of all the voice acting is amazing. There are some incredible voice actors casted in this game! From Matthew Mercer, Evan Smith and for the Japanese dub Daisuke Ono, the voice actor behind Jotaro from Jojo's among many other iconic video games and anime. They really went above and beyond for the voice acting!

Secondly the story is amazing! Minus some parts which admittedly weren't telegraphed too well, it's a really enjoyable plot which takes up right after the last couples of games! Which is both a positive and a negative, for players unfamiliar with the series they would be absolutely confused at what is happening, which could scare someone off of the series, unlike the previous games 999 and Virtue's Last Reward. 999 is the first game so it doesn't have this problem, and VLR manages to get away with a lot despite the context of the previous game, and you don't need to have the knowledge of 999, you can still enjoy it a lot, although you might not catch the references to the past game. As someone who played the other games I enjoyed it because it swiftly got into the story elements of the previous series without having the relearn them again, which was nice! But from a newcomer to the series it would be really confusing.

Third, the puzzles! The puzzles are just as fun in this game as the others, although some times I had to use a guide, the majority of puzzles are challenging, yet solvable!

Unfortunately it's come to the negatives.

The game looks bad, like really bad. For a game released in 2016 it looks awful, but this is because the game was basically made for the 3DS and was then ported to other platforms, this is why the game looks pretty awful. The character designs and models look amazing though, aswell as the character portraits, but the environments and the dog Gab just look mushy and rough, which is a huge shame.

Some of the story elements come out of left field, anyone who played the game knows about THAT twist I'm talking about. Although the story is really good sometimes it fails to telegraph specific things that lead to plot twists, which ultimately just confuses the player. Although it wasn't great I still enjoyed it.

Finally, the fragment selection screen. It's difficult to explain it without spoilers, but in other games you have a branching timeline that dictates the story, you start at the start, go through different choices and hit an ending. Most people are probably familiar with this. With ZTD though, it makes "fragments", you play out a small section of characters talking, escaping from a room or/and making a story changing decision. Although I like the change in some ways, it's ultimately really confusing initially, as things that happen in one seem to contradict in the others. Later on in the game when you finally start piecing bits together and the overall timeline starts to become more apparent it makes sense, but it was really confusing watching one major thing happen in a fragment just for it to not affect another one. But then again, it adds to the whole mystery of whats going on, and adds to that mechanic that I can't talk about because of spoilers.

Despite the negatives this game is absolutely fantastic, this game series is amazing and I would recommend it to anyone, despite it's flaws.

I wish I could forget everything about this series and play it again, although I'm not sure I could do that it 90 minutes! :D

Thank you Zero Escape team for the wonderful game series, this was an amazing send off for Zero Escape, and I'm really looking forward to what comes next! Onto AI: The Somnium Files next!!

141973284.review:
No other video game - potentially no other story regardless of medium - has ever had such a colossal gap between how clever it thinks it is and how clever it actually is. The other Zero Escape games had their frustrating moments or frustrating characters, but that's all ZTD is - trying to get over yet another bullshit plot contrivance or yet another awful character choice with really nothing of value to tie any of it together. Characters can be neatly divided into broadly tolerable (D team), predictably annoying (C team), or so genuinely insufferable that they make the game worse for every minute you're forced to interact with them (Q team). Oh, plus a healthy dose of gratuitous, unpleasant, over-the-top brutality and gore, with character deaths being far, *far* frequent than any other ZTD and usually portrayed on-screen complete with agonized screams. And as far as the ending goes, this is the most unsatisfying conclusion to a story I've ever seen. Calling it a twist is being WAY too charitable - a twist needs to actually make sense. This is just three Deus Ex Machinas stacked on top of each other wearing a trench coat and yelling about morphogenetic fields in the final act.

Oh, and I hope you didn't like any of the worldbuilding or narrative from 999 or VLR, because ZTD retcons or re-frames nearly every interesting element of this franchise into a worse version of itself. When I got to the credits and saw the bit about how "This game couldn't exist without the fans", my immediate reaction was "Don't blame them for this, this is squarely on you". If you *really* need to know what happens in this game, read the wiki or watch a let's play. Save your money. 999 and VLR were worth experiencing, ZTD is not.

141957483.review:
Zero Time Dilemma, the 3rd and final Zero Escape game, was just like the previous two games, a fun ride with some fun puzzles and some cool science fiction. While I personally still prefer 999 and vlr, this game is still definitely a mustplay for fans of the zero escape series.
The puzzles and decision making in this game are quite fun. The majority of puzzles are fun to solve, although there were a few that made me lose my mind. The decision making aspect of the game feels like an expanded version of the AB game from vlr, and it's honestly probably better than the AB game. I like that every Game Over and every ending feel unique and different. There were also some decisions that were pretty hard to make because of how terrible I felt making them.
The story is well-done, with one specific reveal that definitely shocked and surprised me (if you've played it you know what I'm talking about). The characters are good for the most part, although I don't really like what they did with Junpei as they made him a cringey "edgelord", and Eric and Mira were not very likable either. Q, Diana, and Carlos, the newcomers to this game, were probably my favorite, although Sigma and Phi were pretty good as well, even if Phi was pretty underutilized. The ending does feel a little underwhelming, but I still was engaged with the story overall
The graphical style in this game is, simply put, not the greatest. Character animations are super stiff, and it had me miss the more 2-D visual novel style that 999 had. Although, to be fair, the escape room sections do look great, although there aren't as many escape room sections as previous zero escape titles.
Overall, while this game might not be as great as 999 and vlr, I still had a lot of fun with it and found it very engaging. The puzzles are just as great as ever, and I found the story to be very captivating, occasionally on the edge of my seat waiting for what would happen next. I would definitely recommend this game to players of the first 2 zero escape games, and if you've never played a zero escape game before, I would highly recommend you do so.

139973699.review:
Well, I can't say it left a very positive first impression... you can REALLY feel the lack of budget in the animation, and the design of the decision game isn't nearly as clever and intriguing as either of the nonary games. Buuuut, it still managed to suck me in just like the first 2 eventually. It has some fine twists and turns, some of the reveals genuinely impressed me. The puzzle rooms are good, though I was quite disappointed in the lack of an "endgame"-type room(FFS, the QCD is RIGHT there). 

Characters are a mixed bag; D-team was great across the board, the boy is absolutely precious, and as obviously hateable as Eric is(and how hard his backstory is to take seriously), he somehow found a way to invoke sympathy in me at times. On the other hand, edgelord Junpei really didn't work for me(though he still had plenty of trademark Junpei moments lol), Mira is plain forgettable and nowhere close to the charisma machine that was Lotus, or even Alice, and Akane and Carlos were just plain serviceable. And as others have said, the Zero plot twist really is kinda stupid and unsatisfying, though admittedly the signs ARE there if you're perceptive enough.

I'm glad this game was able to be made, it's just a damn shame they had to do so with such hefty constraints. Credit where it's due, they did a fine job with what they had. But I can only really recommend you play this if you're truly ride-or-die with the Zero Escape series and have played both previous games already.

139811017.review:
I enjoyed my time with this game, although there are a lot of buts. Before I get into those, I want to say I like the tone a lot more than that of Virtue's Last Reward. It is a lot darker and doesn't have all those stupid jokes. The presentation is compelling; i.e. the cinematography, the sound, music and voice acting. All of which have quirks, that one can get used to. For example, the lack of inbetween animations is compensated with lots and lots of cutaways. Or that the lighting on the characters does not fit the atmosphere. Also, some voiced lines don't quite sound right. Especially from Akane. Nonethless, the cutscenes are entertaining. I did not expect it to become so dramatic and emotional because VLR had none of that.

When you get into this game, you better have played the two previous titles. Even if you did, be ready to get thoroughly confused right from the get go. You will then have to do one escape room after the other, because all other content is locked away. After that phase, you need to jump around in the flow chart to watch all iterations events could have occured. So the story becomes the puzzle at that point. Once you did that, there is a long stretch of watching story. I don't believe there is any other way to end this story other than getting 100%.

Now... I'm afraid the story is not very good. The whole plot is pointless and leaves a lot of stuff unanswered. For example what the deal with Mira is. Why was this entire exercise even necessary? The motives of the villain are muddy and are based on assumptions impossible to comprehend, because it's all based on a MacGuffin. Thinking of the Radical-6 angle here. And the themes are all over the place. It doesn't become cohesive; there are too many balls in play. Typical pretentious Japanese writing if I ever saw it. The writers read something in a book and just threw it in there because they found it interesting, whether it fits organically or not. Characters become strawmen for that and quote complex detailed text passages from memory. All of that is very contrived. By the way, the unsatisfying ending has to do with the way all of that story was conceived and planned. For a mystery story, you as the writer need to know the mystery in its entirety before writing anything. Then you sprinkle clues over the narrative. If you throw in some things that only appear mysterious to be figured out later, and if you need to withhold information that later comes out of the blue then you get a mess like this. That is the JJ Abrams mystery box approach, which is bad writing.

Having said that, I don't believe all of this game's narrative is bad per se. It just feels ill-conceived and rushed. There are some nicely done revelations and character depths. But a game should not make you feel empty in the end as if you were wasting your time.

[spoiler-free]
[b]GENERAL[/b]
Cool game. Stumbled on the first phase of gameplay but really pushed through halfway into the game. Story-wise, I liked its bridge and answers between its prequels but it's not amazing or anything of the sort. All I can say is, Zero was lame as hell and Junpei is an edgelord here

[b]GAMEPLAY [/b]
ZTD is a game that gets messy with their "fragmented memories" and the separated groups. If its purpose during the initial phase of the game is to thoroughly confuse you then they did an amazing job. The puzzles have the charm of 999 and are still challenging. I believe it's even better than VLR, especially with the way it makes you scour for the answers and keep you up on your toes. Quick-time events and choices keep your blood pumping, but not too much to be annoying and stressful. It's still a great casual game.

[b]STORY[/b]
This game is an interesting "middle ground" between 999 and VLR. There were times where you go "Oh shit, so that's why" but if [u]you have to commit to finishing the game as quickly as possible or you'll have a hard time following it[/u]. There will be moments where you didn't think much about this one plot point but it turned out to be incredibly relevant. There isn't a summarized version of events on a single timeline, you'll just have to check the flowchart or put a mental pin on it. Having played it, the twists are incredibly rewarding. Though, the twist about Zero is lame as hell. In fact, of all the Zeroes between the three games, this guy is the lamest Zero of all. He feels dorky as shit and not at all interesting as, say, the Zeroes of 999 and VLR. This one's just annoying and had the help of technology to do his busy work.

137860407.review:
...It's fine.

It has it's ups and downs, with some genuinely shocking and entertaining revelations... But honestly, it's not a patch on 999 or VLR. (from Zero Escape: The Nonary Games)

Zero Time Dilemma switches up the flowchart timeline mechanics and gives some interesting story implications to explain it, but overall it gets messy. There's also some hacky moments with the story progression and the plot devices introduced, and of course, there's that one infamously bad twist, which plays out like it's a gag... but nope, it's canon. I won't give too much away, but let's just say it's to do with how they play around with the franchise's cliche of: "the mastermind is one of us!". Poorly alluded to (very obscure, forgettable hints), and frustrating how it locks progression until you solve it.

Aside from that, the character writing was off in some places - Junpei comes off being pretty insufferable, Mira and Eric don't have any meaningful character arc by the end - just some backstory and a lot of erratic behaviour from Eric... The rest are fine for the most part, but sadly a lot of the heartfelt moments end up being spoilt by the hilariously bad animations. I understand this started as a 3DS game and was the first game from the series that went so heavy on animated cut-scenes... but there were so many parts that made me wish they'd stuck to text dialogue/ voice acting alongside character portraits.

At any rate, the game was still entertaining. There was plenty to enjoy about both in story and gameplay - but I honestly wouldn't recommend ZTD to first-timers. Definitely play if you enjoyed the Nonary Games (definitely recommend!), since it ties up the story with some solid closure... just maybe wait for it to go on offer.

135219515.review:
Zero Time Dilemma serves as the final game to the Zero Escape trilogy, and while I wholeheartedly enjoyed the game, it is definitely the weakest of the three. Filled with many plot holes as well as the most amount of absurd bullshit compared to the other two, ZTD definitely has many moments of cheesy scenes and convenient explanations for certain mysteries as a result of laziness or rushed storytelling. 

ZTD also has the most amount of cutscenes, because rather than the traditional visual novel style of gameplay like the previous two games, ZTD opted to go with more animated scenes over still panels. But when comparing to the actual gameplay of ZTD, which is the puzzle solving, it felt like there was a lower amount. The final stretch is essentially multiple long cutscenes to wrap the story up. This could be a positive or negative for people as I can only assume many really enjoyed the game for some of the interesting puzzle design, but for others, it probably stood in the way of seeing more of the plot unfold.

Yet, despite this new approach to how the game is presented, the animations were comically bad at many points, if not, the majority of the game. From the desync'd lip animations (I played the game with Japanese voice acting so it wasn't due to the language) to the hilarious walking scenes, the game suffers from terrible or funny presentation which can lower the serious tone the story intends to tell. 

So with all this criticism, why am I even bothering to recommend the game? Well, for one, I still enjoyed the game a lot regardless of any issues I had. ZTD had its awful moments for sure, quite a bit of them, especially if we keep comparing to its predecessors, but it also had its peak moments that were equal or surpassed those of the previous two as well. I thought the plot was becoming predictable in the halfway point of the game but once everything was revealed, I was genuinely shocked at many points.

But it wasn't only because of that, but also due to the fact that we even got this game in the first place. It still served as a conclusion to this ridiculous but also amazing trilogy, and I think it was still more than good enough to leave feeling satisfied rather than be a disgrace and better to not exist at all.

Especially knowing the context that ZTD was originally going to be cancelled, but was brought back to life from the fan support, you can't help but be grateful in the end that this game was allowed to exist, even if it ended up being a slight disappointment for fans of the other two games, as it's still a conclusion to the series that would've never existed in another timeline.

Life is unfair sometimes, and not every game with ambition will get the funding it deserved, and I think if ZTD had a higher budget, even one that matched the budget of its predecessors, this game could've had so much potential. But the result that exists today still left me overall satisfied, and is proof that a good story can still standout despite a poor presentation. 

I definitely recommend the game, but remember that this is the third instalment. Steam really needs to make it more clear for games that belong in a series...

132314938.review:
Third game in Zero Escape series, and a game that almost didn't happen. Does it live up to it's hype? No. I still find it amazing. It just never reaches the heights of Virtue's Last Reward, and the setup. This game does it's best to tie up the first two games, and finish the trilogy, and it wasn't an easy task. In my opinion it managed to do it.

One of the controversial things about this game was its move to full 3D with everything being shown as cutscenes, similar to Walking Dead or something like that. The quality of the assets used is rather low, anytime the camera zooms to something you can see pixels on the textures blown up to giant sizes. The animations aren't of the highest quality as well, and characters mostly stand stiff. There are many cuts to hide animations they didn't manage to create... But it's still leagues better than Pokemon games, which don't even try to animate anything. I got used to the presentation within 15 minutes, and it didn't bother me most of the time. The new presentation, and having everything voiced, means there's also less story to be had than in the other 2 games.

The game also takes interesting approach to the storytelling. Instead of branching story like usual the player is presented with fragments, which might happen anytime in any of the branches. You might first select something that happens near the end, and only later learn what happened before. Somehow the game manages to be perfectly comprehensible despite this solution. That said this also means to a bit of each fragment starting the same. The characters wake, then they wonder if they were waken up before or if it's their first time. Since they don't keep the memories between fragments they also don't get much of character development until the very end.

The game also divides characters into 3 teams from the very beginning, and they are kept that way. So you won't have interactions between Junpei from team C and Sigma from team D, which could have been really cool. Members of each team are quite closely connected, even if it's not obvious at the start. And all teams are more connected than expected. You learn of it slowly as you progress trough the game. 

Despite initial open order to progress trough fragments you might get locked out from some progress by lock icons, which you unlock by exploring other fragments. You might stumble into a lock quite fast, and then it might take hours before you're able to unlock it, by the time you might not even remember what happened in the branch. Two flowcharts are there to assist you, so it's manageable. At one point I had pretty much everything unlocked in my branches and couldn't progress, so I had to go trough random dead ends just to unlock a lock for no apparent reason.

The game also stops your progress few times with passwords you need to know. You learn them in other fragments. Even if you're like me and played this game twice before, and know the passwords, you can't really break out of the expected progress. Even if you answer the password properly you'll get a lock icon until you explore proper fragments.

Each fragment starts with just few minutes of talking, then it goes into escape room. All branches happen after you escape the room so you never have to repeat any room. This is quite good solution and improves the pace at which you can explore the game. The rooms themselves are much easier than VLR. There's only one difficulty, there's no alternate answer to any of the rooms. I only got stuck once, when I didn't see a box of matches on the ground.

Out of the three teams the D-team is the best written and characterised. The endings you get with this team are the best, and most epic and heart wrenching. Sigma and Phi come from VLR, and their story is well continued here. The C-team has Junpei and Akane. The newcomer Carlos seems quite out of place in their team, and only in one of the endings you'll learn what his purpose was. Q-team is the strangest bunch.

The game reuses a lot of VLR music, and that means the music is great. The sound effects are still pleasure to listen to.

Many fans were disappointed with the twist, and the ending, and felt the game did a middle finger to VLR. I think the game managed to tie up VLR quite properly. The final structure that is built makes perfect sense. The villain motives, which are many and complicated, also are satisfying once you start thinking about that. Near the end [spoiler]the game decides SHIFTing is akin to murder and tries to make it into some kind of moral dilemma. Even though trough whole VLR the player removes tons of Sigmas and Phis dead all over the complex, then trough half of VLR we shift a lot. Suddenly 5 minutes before the game ends it becomes "a murder" and we have to consider if we're ready to sacrifice other selves. This is what we were doing past 2 games, I felt completely no remorse or guilt, or any other special feelings related to the "last decision".[/spoiler]

This one is also the most brutal of all the games, with unsettling deaths happening everywhere. The characters don't kill each other so much, usually it's just the game killing them. The game explores some more real-and-fake physics, probability, mind parasites, the placement of soul, and many other things. It's built in into the script more naturally than in 999. The game also quickly reintroduces ideas from the previous two games as a reminder. In case 10 years passed since you played the other 2 games.

One thing the game fails at, is telling you there are additional epilogues available in your documents section after you beat the game. Without them the ending might feel incomplete, and the game doesn't inform you about them in any way. Once you finish the story you're thrown into flowchart, from which you can't even access the documents section. 

All in all, a very bold and strong entry in the franchise. In my opinion it's better than Steam version of 999 and worse than DS version of 999. I feel like it got a lot of unjustified fan hate on the internet, but as long as it's looked at as what it is, instead of "what might have been" it's really good. Initial opinions from others stopped me from playing this game for few years, so maybe I was also more lenient to the game since my hype went down. But now replaying the game for a 3rd time I still think it's very good.

One of the best (puzzle) games out there! Maybe not as polished as its predecessors, but it shines in its own way. Compelling characters, new mysteries, challenging puzzles, and, lots and lots of timelines - it has everything you want from a zero escape game!

They've tried to step away from the visual novel aspect of the previous games by using cut scenes, but the balance between story and gameplay feels roughly the same. The animation is a little rough in some scenes (like Akane's fringe clipping through her collarbone), but generally it adds to the unsettling vibes. I also really like Zero's design!

The game ties op most loose ends from the previous two games, while posing (and answering) a couple new mysteries as well. The world and timelines had become so complicated that it would have been impossible to explain and conclude everything, but it does feel like a proper end.

I also really like the 'fragments' and think they're a cool spin on previous game mechanics.

125898128.review:
TL;DR
Worst twist from any fictional story I've ever seen, and I'm not exaggerating. The game's also really ugly, has wonky animations, and is a bit of a mess early on.

Before I begin, if it isn't obvious, if you've not played 999 and VLR, do not touch this game with a ten foot pole as it is not for you.

The best way I can summarize this game in a single sentence is that it will make you miss the last two games dearly, and this is coming from someone that did not like VLR that much, mostly playing it because I wanted to laugh at crazy fake science. To begin with, as you can tell by the steam screenshots, ZTD is not exactly a pleasant looking game, which is admittedly, a huge problem in a game where when you're not solving puzzles, are just looking at cutscenes. I wish I could tell you the animations make up for this, but they're stiff as all hell. I absolutely understand that this game was on a tight budget, but if you're going to be on such a budget, at least use it more effectively or design your game so it can work around set budget. I wish I could say my audiovisual woes end there, but so much of this game's music is just reusing old tracks, which while fine, gets a little too tiring as this game sorta lacks in original tracks outside of a few gems and the escape room tracks.

Now that I'm done saying how this game's an audiovisual mess in 20 different ways, lets talk about the characters, which are, well, interesting. Junpei and Akane have some pretty stark shifts in character, particularly Junpei who goes from incredibly likable in 999 to an edgelord who thinks it'd be kinda funny if a bunch of people died. Akane, is more in line with her original self, including the crazy parts, but she's just... much less fun in this game; rather than going through all the small little ways she's done wrong, all I'll say is that she does not utter the nickname "Jumpy" a single time in this game. As for the other returning characters Sigma and Phi, they're handled well enough in this game, but I didn't particularly love them in VLR so that's more just a pleasant note than anything. As for the new characters, they're all generally... fine, some even having a few great moments here and there, though they can be annoying from time to time.

Now for the writing; this game's 1st third is a bit of a mess, since you spend it doing a bunch of puzzles and seeing a bunch of out of context scenes. For what was decidedly the worse, the game takes a very non linear approach to story telling, and it really drags things down as you're just doing puzzles, getting a little bit of generally inconsequential decision making here and there, and going back in again. The game's next third is actually kinda good and made me wonder if it was better than VLR, as it centered on the characters abusing the fake science mechanics of the universe, and had some of the better character moments too, now as for the last third... when the game reaches its big Uchikoshi twist, it torpedoes down, down, down, so hard that I went from having a positive opinion of this mess to just outright hating this game. It's a mystery that breaks the rules of mysteries and was presented in an incredibly unfair fashion, and ultimately came off as an "Ahaha, look at this twist, I'm smart!" then something actually clever. It also undermines the entire game because if this mystery was presented in a fashion that was remotely fair, you'd figure out who the big baddy is immediately, completely undermining whatever merits the rest of the game had for me.

If you're here because you're dying to know what happens after VLR, you're better off making it up or imagining it. Whatever it is will probably be cooler than whatever this game and its absolute joke of a twist are.

On the whole, it is pretty good. It took some time getting use to the new graphics though, and some of the characters are remarkably different when compared with their originals designs in previous Zero Escape games. Still, the puzzles are there; the mystery  is still there; the convoluted story that will hopefully make sense in the end is still there. And this is my biggest gripe with the game. The story is quite different when you compared to the previous games. It is a puzzle itself. Instead of following your typical beginning, middle and end, formula, the story is told from the point of view of three different groups. Moreover, you do not know what point of the story you are playing. For instance, at certain points, you get to know that a characters is dead, but you do not know why that happened. To make it simple, the story is told from three different perspectives, three teams, and at the same time, it is broken down since you play different points of those perspectives of each team. You do not play the perspective of each team from beginning to end. You play a part of the story. 


Surely, they did it on purpose, but so far nearly 8 hours and I kind of hate. It makes quite difficult to follow what the hell is going on. Why this character is dead? Why  did this happen? Why these two hate each other now?


Still, I would recommend it, but beware, this is not your typical storytelling. Expect to be very confused at some points.

125328385.review:
Zero Escape: ZTD is a disappointment in pretty much every possible way. Where to even start?

The plot and stories are bad. One of the biggest issues with the story is that scenes don't progress in a straight narrative like they did in the prior two games. In this one, you might be in timeline 1 scene 3, then do timeline 2 scene 2, then do timeline 3 scene 4. You never have any real clue what's going on for the current scene you're in or what led up to it.

I got stuck at multiple points trying to figure out what I needed to do to continue on (and so have many other people). The game very poorly illustrates what scenes you've truly completed and hides a few of them from the flowchart. Probably the two worst scenes to complete are the dice roll and gun. One scene has you rolling dice, needing to get three 1s (1 in 216 chance) or you die. It's pretty safe to assume the game isn't going to make you roll the dice 216 times or more, so you make the safe assumption that something will occur in a different timeline to let you succeed. Another scene states you have a 50/50 shot of shooting someone. I shot the person, replayed the scene 2 more times, shooting them again each time. So I figured you probably needed to do something else in the story to continue down that path. Turns out the dice one you need to play 3 total times and you'll always succeed on the third try. There is nothing to indicate this will happen. Turns out the gun is actually a 50/50 chance. I had to do that scene 10 times before I finally got the blank. So I was one of the 1/1024 who had to do that. I feel bad for the poor luck folk out there that had to replay that scene 15-20 times to get the other outcome.

The characters are all poorly written, especially Eric. The 9 characters get permanently split up into three teams of three people. Four of the characters are from the previous games: Junpei, Akane, Sigma, and Phi. Junpei and Akane are unrecognizable and act nothing like they previously did. When it comes down to you making decisions in scenes, characters in each group act pretty much the exact same way. You make the decision as character A, character B will always want you to kill/screw over everyone else, character C will always want you to not kill/screw over everyone else. Junpei and Sigma are homicidal maniacs in this game.

The escape segments are fine for the most part, though they greatly overuse the 'place the puzzle pieces into their proper spots' puzzles.

I'm one of those people who don't care about graphics in games. This is one of the few games I've played where I can actually say that the graphics/animations hurt the quality of the game. The 3D aspect of Virtue's Last Reward was a bit jarring at first, but you got used to it after a bit. You'll never get used to how awful the graphics and animations look in this. 

Characters faces and expressions look particularly bad. There was one scene where they kept showing a closeup of Eric's face, and his expression made me keep bursting into laughter. Other characters aren't quite as bad as Eric, but they're pretty bad. This kills the tone of scenes when you can't take what's happening seriously due to the stupid expressions.

Even the makers of this know how bad the animations are. Every cutscene involving a character being injured has the camera point up at nothing as it's happening, then cutting back to the aftermath. I assume this was because they originally had animations for these things, saw how ridiculously bad they looked, and decided to fix it by having the camera point at the ceiling/wall. One of my favorite animations that made me laugh is a scene which shows Junpei walking out of a room; He's doing big knees while he's walking out the door. It's absurd watching his knees going up to his waist as he's walking.

Zero Escape: ZTD is a giant leap back in pretty much every way from the previous two games. It's as though they simply didn't care about this and pushed it out the door rushed and unfinished. The plot, stories, and dialogue are bad. The characters, graphics, and animations are horrible. The only semi-decent part of this are the puzzles. You're going to play this just to finish the series. You really shouldn't. Stop NOW! DO NOT GET THIS! Do yourself a favor and pretend the series finished with VLR.

Although there is a lot less story in Zero Escape:  Zero Time Dilemma than 999, and VLR it is in fact a perfection conclusion to a perfect Trilogy.

In Zero Time Dilemma the standalone story itself is not as long, but the connection points to the other two wrap up perfectly.  Zero Time Dilemmas story basically is meant to put all the pieces of the puzzle to the entire story together to come up with a totally brilliant plot that connects all three games, and an amazing ending.

I have to say that this game series as far as story goes, is now for me, right up there with the stories in Xenogears, Final Fantasy X, The House in Fata Morgana, and HIgurashi When They Cry.  One of the ALL-TIME great stories.  

The story is beautiful, mindblowing, extremely intelligent, thought provoking, and brilliantly written.  Do yourself a favor and pick up the whole series, and be ready to get blown away by this trilogy.

This is going to sound negative, but trust me, this is a good game.

Definitively a downgrade compared to it's prequel. The "decision game" in this game is way less entertaining than the AB game in virtue's last reward. The stakes are higher but everything feels way too disconnected for you to care.

This game's main gimmick of being completely out of chronological order and kinda open-ended makes it way harder to get into the story initially. Not being able to see the immediate results of your choices and then having to deal with them takes the weight out of the stakes. It's only towards the latter half of the game that you really get into it, you know, when the initial plot where "we need to beat this game zero made" kinda starts to become irrelevant to give way to the real main plot.

The cast is overall very likable, except for everyone in Q team. Didn't like any of them from the get go and it didn't improve with time, even though they really tried with one of them. Didn't work this time around though. At least it made it easier to me to make my first choices, ehehe. 

Many returning characters and some new ones. Some returning characters feel like completely different persons though, so might as well consider them new ones. You know the one.

The "decision game" is less of a game than the AB game was. And characters seems awfully cooperative most of the time. Even the jerks hardly put up any resistance to cooperation. Their choices are all in-the-moment and feel like they have much weight.

Anyway, not the best in the series, still a good visual novel puzzle game. I still haven't finished it, but i should be in the final straight, less than 5 hours away from it

[b]Story[/b]

Game leans a lot more heavily into the horror aspects from the first two games instead of focusing on the brain melting plot points along with the fact that this game tries to clear up a lot of mysteries that were presented in the first two which I think does this game favours in the story department and in my opinion makes it head and shoulders above the rest in the franchise, sadly the same can not be said about the escape rooms and characters.

[b]Characters[/b]

The characters are not nearly as fleshed out or likeable as the first two games,Sigma and Phi are still lovable and make D team easily my favourite team to play Carlos and Diana are nice ,if not slightly boring, additions to the game but both grew on me very quickly and Q is alright if not a little annoying at times but the main issues I have with the characters in this game are the drastic change in akane and junpei's personalities which put me off of playing their section of the game (however it is excusable because there are in lore reasons for these changes) but by far the most infuriating characters ever put in this game series, Mira and Eric makes Q team horrible to play due to how unbearable they both are.

[b]Escape rooms / Gameplay[/b]
The escape rooms are easily the weakest part of this game and they lose a lot of the complexity and intrigue when compared to 999 and VLR becoming seemingly an afterthought that was put into the game in the last section of development.

[b]Overall [/b] 
Even though I have complained quite a bit in the review this game is still fantastic due to the story and worldbuilding that is included in it, as said before in my opinion the Story is great, probably the best in the franchise and although Q team and the escape rooms do pull the overall experience down a bit I would say if you are a fan of the zero escape series or visual novel games in general this game is an underrated gem and you would be doing yourself a favour buying the Nonary games collection (if you dont already have it) and this game!

Eric is basically Shaggy from Scooby Doo but somehow dumber.
Zero Escape: Zero Time Dilemma is the 3rd and final game of the Zero Escape series. If you are interested in playing the games you should first buy The Nonary games which includes the other games. 
As for the game itself, writing and the voice acting starts a little off and cringy but picks up and gets better over time. The animations are a bit ugly and the style needs some time getting used to. The flow chart is much more defined and easy to navigate. The escape room style puzzles are again the main gameplay element you have and i think they are super fun and more logical than the previous ones. 
As for the story, it is full of twists and turns you won't expect. It keeps you on the edge the whole time. You keep wanting to know more about what happens and it becomes impossible to stop playing, 
What makes a visual novel great or not is the story and thanks to that, Zero Time dilemma manages to be a great game even with its cons.
It is a must play if you want to know about the Zero Escape universe. I highly recommend it.

118843749.review:
Long story short, I think this game is weaker than the previous two in every single way. But let's not kid ourselves. You're not playing this game in a vacuum, for its merits alone. You're playing this game because it's the third game in the Zero Escape series and you want to know what happens. Maybe you want some more escape rooms. Well, at those things, ZTD does an okay job.

If VLR ended a little more conclusively, I'd consider ending there. But it doesn't. ZTD should probably have been part of VLR. Don't get me wrong, I didn't hate this game, but there were very few moments where I was not forced to confront the fact that ZTD is a pure step down from the previous two.

In classic Zero Escape fashion, the art style has changed, so the returning characters look totally different. And you know what? I really like the look of the character models... until they start moving. Then they look like awkward robots. Chunsoft decided to animate all the scenes like a Telltale game rather than using the classic visual novel look of displaying a reaction pose like the previous two games. I'm not a fan of this approach. The art style and direction works, and I have no problem with it, but the animation doesn't just look wonky: it takes so much longer to watch because you can't progress the text whenever you want.

The characters took a step down overall, which is a bummer because the previous two have such charming characters with great development. Some of the returning characters have different personalities for weak reasons, and some of the new characters are just plain unpleasant, lacking any kind of real character development. The way the game is structured, I often found myself avoiding certain options because I just didn't care about the participating characters. Voice work is good though, no complaints there.

Story-wise, I wasn't nearly as enthralled. There's a decent progression between the three games, and I generally like how the world changes and escalates, but the writing and presentation don't have quite the same charm this time. Some plotlines are kind of shoehorned in, and some of the mysteries just feel cheap. It's upsetting when a big mystery is uncovered and you go back to think about all the hints scattered around, but you still walk away thinking about how unconvincing and uncompelling it is. Where previous Zero Escape games were sometimes a little too convenient, ZTD inspires eye rolls. Often I found myself laughing [i]at[/i], not [i]with[/i], the dialogue, or saying "OKAY. SURE." out loud to my monitor. And that's not to even touch on the fundamental structure of the story, and how you experience it. I won't spoil it, but navigating the narrative is super clunky. They're clearly going for something, and I can respect that, but I can also hate it. The way they structured the narrative pieces doesn't feel good, and makes me care a lot less about what's happening in any individual moment. It takes way too long for the story to get to a place where I'm experiencing content I have reason to care about at a good rate. And at that point I was focused on how I wasn't super thrilled with how the mystery was being solved.

I can't believe I didn't think about the puzzle rooms earlier. They are way worse, and reflect an overall change in the game's design: ZTD is less about "solving" and more about "finding". Story-wise, there were times where I completed all available plotlines, and had no indication from the UI what I needed to do to progress. I'd just click around the flow chart guessing, hoping that re-watching something I've already seen unlocks something new (surprise, it does! Is it a bug? Who knows). There are some pretty good puzzle rooms, but ZTD also features the most unpleasant puzzle rooms of the whole series. I have no idea how they managed to have both of these problems, but for some rooms I had 0 clues for any puzzles, and had to move on to clicking on things that don't even look interactable so I could finally get started, and for others I kept finding clues for braindead "puzzles" I already solved a long time ago. Like I said, more about finding than solving. They just don't feel as well tested as the first two games. ZTD has also decided that it would be fun to make their puzzles more annoying. Here's a puzzle where the trick is you have to remember to press a button every few seconds. Here's a puzzle you need a pen and paper to solve, have fun using the in-game etch-a-sketch with limited ink. There are a lot of puzzles that take you out of the game, and even more that seem to intentionally make things annoying for you. In VLR you'd have a flashback and can really easily look up where the answer is, but in ZTD it's structured to be a total pain in the butt to look anything up, which is awful for a game featuring a disproportionate amount of "insert the exact right numbers/letters that you hopefully wrote down earlier" moments. Gross. More than once, a mystery was so in-your-face obvious that I was scared of solving it correctly because the characters had no good reason to know that information. It's just not great.

So yeah. You're playing this because the first two games established characters and a world you care about. This game is an inconvenient continuation of that story, but at least it technically continues it. It wasn't entirely satisfying, but it'll have to work. I recommend playing this game simply because it gives you something you can't get anywhere else. But boy do I wish it was a better game.

118470399.review:
Holy shit.

Holy shit.

I'm still astounded. Baffled. Discombobulated.

I'm writing this review not because it can be relevant at this point, but because I am so utterly shocked after playing it that I need to vent, somehow. Even if it is to a void, in the reviews page for a game released six freakin years ago. That is how appalled I am.

You need to understand, I was ready to let it go. I swear. Not the first shock turd I've experienced in my gaming life, and it won't be the last. And I usually move along and forget about it. But then, these unskippable, masturbatory credits  with this dramatic music started, like the game is taking the piss one last time and wasting just a little bit more of my time, and I couldn't just take it while it happens. I needed some feeling of retribution, some sense of recovering the cosmic order of things. So, where do we start...

First of all... This is, without a doubt, the biggest regression in quality in a direct sequel that I have ever seen. All accross the board, almost every element is worse than it was in Virtue's Last Reward. Visual quality? Yes, worse. Expressions and animations? Yup. Music? Of course. Structure and pacing? Absolutely. Story? Ooooh pal, you don't even KNOW.

[hr][/hr]

But let's not get ahead of ourselves here, because I can already hear you, hypothetical, non-existent reader, going "Wait, how can it be worse visually than Virtue's Last Reward? ZTD was released four years later! Surely it should look better, being four years more modern." 
Well I'm glad you (didn't) ask, because it is very easy to explain... You know the clunky 3D style that they used in VLR? Well, they [i] doubled down on it. [/i] Yes, they doubled down on the worst change they made from the first game of the series to the second. And they made it [i] much worse [/i].

You see, in VLR, they went almost-full 3D in what was an ill-advised decision, but they still somewhat salvaged the visuals and made them work, because they didn't go crazy trying to do a lot with them. They still had a talking head style, with only a few dedicated expressions and poses for each character, and not much more. So they could still make each of them look kinda decent.

But in ZTD? Well, it is very appropriate that this game deals with memory loss, because apparently, someone forgot they were working on a visual novel, and decided to go all cInEmAtIc, with full 3D real time cutscenes for everything! And they also forgot, they lacked the time, talent or budget to make it look decent! And you know what happens when you try to do a serious, narrative heavy game without  the time, talent and budget to have decent faces, facial animations, and animation in general? It ends up looking unintentionally creepy, awkward and hilarious. The conclusion to the epic narrative uber dramatic saga, and this fucker is walking around with a derpy semi-grimace that is a smile but isn't during a pivotal moment. Fantastic.

[hr][/hr]

But ok, ok. You say to yourself, dammit, the characters look like warped up dolls in a microwave. And I didn't recognize some of the characters of the previous games until they said their name. And it sure looked awkward when this character went to interact with another and they cut to a view of the ceiling because they couldn't make the animation in between. But... but, the writing will save it, the story will save it. Let's get on with it-

That's when you realize, you press the skip dialogue for the next line. And it doesn't skip.

The character goes on, slowly reciting their lines (in japanese, because of course you have switched from the extremely awkward english voiceover by this point). You already read the line in half a second, and have spent the next 5 looking for the skip button, slowly coming to the panicked realization that... no... none of them work... surely they didn't... surely they weren't [i] that [/i] stupid...

And, suddenly, it hits you, like a [i]  truck [/i]. Due to the new cinematic style, skipping unread lines halfway through is not a thing anymore.

It sounds like a super specific and super small issue, but, if you have played games of this type before, you know how devastating that can be to the pacing and flow of the game. Especially considering that in this game you have several different scenes that convey similar (or even identical) information to one another, and you are sitting there going "I already fucking know this pleeeaaaaaaase". 

Your only hope is enabling the option that you weren't supposed to use in the previous games, universal skip mode. But this comes with its own sets of issues: 
First, lines are tied to small animations. So a character will start slowwwly walking towards one another, you will be like, come on, let's move it along, skip to the end of the walk (because again, bad animation) and suddenly, bam, they are in the middle of a conversation. Because [i] the line was tied to the end stretch of the walk animation. You were supposed to wait for them to walk for two seconds for the line to appear. [/i] Because it's [i] cinematic. [/i]  So, to the log you go! The game has slayed the evil monsters of pacing and momentum once again!
Second, because the function is meant to be held to skip large amounts of lines, if you press it half a second too long, BAM, you have now skipped two lines. So, to the log you go!
And third, the implication that, if the hold skip can be a thing, [i] why can't there be a single press skip for individual lines.[/i] You know, like in the previous games of [i] the same series?[/i] The ones that were [i] actually good?[/i]

Fuck, you rarely see a game so damaged by a decision such as this game going for that cutscene style. Jesus.

[hr][/hr]

Anyway, you have endured the ordeal that is the delivery of the story, and what do you get? Two of the fucking most bullshit twist/reveals in the history of media. I couldn't! I couldn't! I thought I missed something! I had to go online to confirm that I didn't miss something and it was that utterly stupid! I started maniacally laughing, imagining the several meetings and discussions and several writing sessions during which everybody must've been "duuuude this reveal will be sooo good holy shiiiiit" and having lost all hope for the future of humanity as a rational species.

The game hinges on a Shyamalan-level asspull. No, not even that, a [i] Heavy Rain [/i] - tier asspull. It is an achievement! It should be in a museum! The asking price is too low for experiencing the level of dumbfoundedness that you will get from the end stretch. But please record yourself with a camera for posterity. Otherwise, nobody will ever believe that time that you yelled "Fuck you game you wasted my time fuck you that is cheating basic logic and everything I have seen with my own two eyes throughout the game that is fucking bullshit how did you dare to even pull this".

[hr][/hr]

Anyway the credits have ended, I had more to say but you know what fuck it, this doesn't get one more second of my time.

Decent game, would maybe recommend.

As a game, it was very confusing to start, but the more I progressed, the more I grew to love it. There are some characters I did not like at all, and their sections were increasingly painful to play. I think if you enjoyed the first two Nonary Games, this is definitely worth your time, though be wary of the final end. Please enjoy!

I wouldn't recommend you play this game unless you've already completed Nonary Games.

Pros:

Cons:

118041130.review:
This is an extremely conflicted, half hearted "not recommended". This game does not live up to the promise of VLR and has far too many loose ends and problems to be "good". But there's really nothing else quite like this series that aims so high and is definitely a unique experience in its own right.

Unfortunately, there are so many problems that aren't just the story. To get it out of the way, the story just doesn't form a cohesive narrative and just isn't as insane as VLR got to ignore those problems. It doesn't tie up most of the loose ends from VLR and adds new holes that are fairly egregious. While a lot of people say this devolves into nonsense, I'd say this doesn't go nearly as hard into the crazy as VLR did and that brings the game down a lot for me. It's far too serious in my opinion. In terms of pure gameplay, the UI is outright bad and the game just looks terrible. So many weird gameplay choices that I just cannot condone. The timeline is a massive pain to navigate and you have to resort to hunting for the next section, made more difficult by how unintuitively it is organised. The memo and file system is really irritating to navigate and a lot of the time you need to have both open and the game just doesn't let you. The memo system has added a new "ink" system that keeps going down the more you write on screen which was already useless and limiting but for SOME REASON, ERASING MAKES THE METER GO DOWN TOO. There's also some abject garbage with certain choice paths where you need to type in something instead of being given a MCQ, but sometimes the text to unlock some paths is not communicated at all which completely halts your progress because you don't know what you're supposed to be doing. The puzzle rooms are all of middling quality and maybe 3/13 rooms were actually interesting enough. It just devolves into either a "click everything" fest or a linear "follow the instructions" snooze.

The game also just looks terrible. They went for a fully 3D modelled aesthetic but the textures are really horrible and ugly. The PS4 version has a much better lighting system that adds dynamic shadows that fixed a lot of glaring problems with the art style but that's completely missing from this version. The music, while great, is largely simply tracks from VLR and I didn't recognise any new tracks.

All the good in the story and the sheer ambition does not outweight the facts that the game looks bad, plays bad and ends bad. If you're a VLR fan, you're probably invested enough that you'll play it anyway. For anyone new to the series, don't start with this game and also don't play it.

I had low hopes for ZTD after the contrived setup in VLR and reading negative comments.  ZTD starts off as an aimless mess with life-or-death decisions about characters you don't know yet and what feels like missing introductions.  You play "as" three team leaders, but nothing seems to be from their point of view except a few decisions, which made me feel more distant from the characters than the other games.  It doesn't help that you play fragments of the story without knowing when - or what history! - they take place in.

However, the story eventually comes together, and the escape rooms are the most fun I've had in the series.  I heard there were budget issues, but it doesn't show in the gameplay sections or story, though the funding did seem to run out as they were modeling Mira's face. This is definitely worth playing, whether you just want more escape rooms or you want to see the story more or less tied up.

I'd love to see more games with these sorts of puzzles and this level of writing, maybe even without being attached to an edgy death game for once.  This is likely my last Spike Chunsoft game, as they've been growing fonder of degenerate content.  End of an era...

115756209.review:
Have you ever wondered what a Zero Escape game entirely written and animated by a janitor who has never written or animated anything would look like? Wonder no longer, because that's what ZTD is.

The story is a garbage, and somehow gradually gets worse and worse as the game progresses. The pacing is atrocious, and even though there's kinda a story excuse for it, it doesn't make it any more tolerable. The ending is the cherry on top and really emphasizes just how bad the overall writing is.

The models and animations are so bad the game is almost painful to look at, and I legitimately don't understand what they were thinking. What was wrong with the visual novel style dialogues? Why did they have to have really poorly "animated" cutscenes? We will never know, for their motives are complex.

The only redeeming factor of this game are the puzzles, which much like the ones in 999 and VLR are pretty fun and diverse. There's 13 puzzle rooms in total, and they're all pretty decent so I guess they get some points for that.

The only reason you'd want to play this game is if you want to witness a trainwreck, but it's a trainwreck that will leave you wishing you were in a different timeline.
