115572086.review:
Se podría decir que sigue la premisa de 999, hasta se podría decir que se respetan ciertas cosas de los 2 juegos anteriores (de los cuales estan en steam dentro de un paquete). El gameplay tambien se puede decir que sigue la misma tematica de los 2 juegos anteriores, pero, esta vez no tenemos un solo protagonista del cual debe de hacer la ruta y tomar las decisiones hasta llegar al final de la ruta, si no que hay 3 protagonistas o mas bien... Equipos, de los cuales tendran que resolver los acertijos y escapar de cada cuarto, esto por supuesto se aprende más de la historia.

La historia... esperaba una historia un poco más realista o algo no tan descabellado, pero no es un aspecto negativo tampoco, es una historia de ciencia ficción pura y dura de lo cual me encanta pero puede que no sea para cualquiera, y eso contiene todos los elementos de la historia y como se desarrolla de principio a fin. Esto puede provocar que lo dejes de jugar, cosa que lo veo totalmente normal si no estas acostumbrado a este tipo de historias.
 ¡Tambien algo muy importante a tener en cuenta! este juego requiere que prestes atención a todos los detalles, por que cada palabra, contraseña, acción, etc. Puede significar una respuesta/una ayuda para los otros personajes para que puedas progresar.

La verdad es que el juego es largo y más todavia si estas para sacar todos los finales posibles, sin contar que se puede "alargar artificialmente" si te atascas en un puzzle en concreto.
 El juego esta bueno, quizá la historia no es para cualquiera, va de la mano junto a la ciencia ficción y trata temas complejos lo cual puede resultar pesado, pero es un juego para dedicarle unas semanas largas y estar dispuesto a terminarlo (si ese es tu objetivo) o dedicarle día por medio para no perderte en la historia.

Le doy un 8/10 cumple como novela visual (que a veces no parece novela visual)

I read some negative reviews and felt like it might be worth skipping this game due to a few of them claiming that it "ruins the whole series" etc, but I'd say it's necessary to play Zero Time Dilemma to understand the series as a whole.

I played Zero Escape: The Nonary Games which includes the first 2 games "Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors" and "Virtues Last Reward" over the last month and finished the series with this one.
This series is amazing and I'd consider it a must play for fans of this genre.

At the start of this game I felt like the pacing was better than the other entries due to the fully voiced and animated cut scenes and how quickly It went into actively solving puzzles, but that slowed down significantly after the first 12 hours.
My game save says it took me 25 hours to beat the game 100%, and the last 7 hours of that were cut scenes with no active puzzle solving apart from entering codes given in other cut scenes.
I'd consider that this games biggest issue, I understand that the series is originally a Visual Novel series but that was probably the longest period of cut scenes in a video game I've ever heard of.

Mild spoilers throughout, nothing major.

Hoo boy, the first half of this game is a slog, bad enough that I only got so far before I quit for half a year. The non-linear storytelling makes the first parts an exercise in frustration - you make a lot of decisions that don't seem to matter and don't connect to anything else that happens. And it is really, really gory, which combined with the frustrating decision making, means it feels like a lot of the time you're making the correct decisions and watching the characters die horribly anyway.
It's fun to see characters from the first two games appear, but I don't love some of the characterization. It kind of works to see that Junpei was genuinely messed up by the events of the first game (because oh my god), but it doesn't make him fun company. And Akane's uwu moe act wears very thin very fast when you know how ruthless she can be ([spoiler] Ma'am, you revenge exploded a man to death, you don't get to play moral high ground [/spoiler]).
So why am I recommending it? The escape rooms are still really fun and I ended up quite liking all three protagonists. Plus, one you see start to see how all the elements come together, the story does get more engaging. And then they started introducing some buck wild twists in the final act and I ended the game having a fantastic time.

Everything is designed to be a loop in terms of the story of Sigma and Phi and even Akane and Junpei. They even foreshadowed the events of the true ending in the ending of VLR with how a character told Sigma inside of Kyle's body that the events of VLR do work it just happens in a different timeline and that they cannot tell Sigma how and why because it would break the cycle and then that reality would cease to exist.[/spoiler]
          On top of that this game explores and reveals the connection between Sigma and Phi and we finally learn the truth between them [spoiler] Which is that Sigma and Diana (yes the Diana that Sigma lived with for 3 years in the original timeline and would eventually model Luna after) in another reality during the events of ZTD would be trapped after Akane wins and for basically almost a year were together alone and would develop feelings for each other and lead to the birth of a pair of twins. One of the twins being Phi the other being Delta ( Zero in ZTD and also Q). They would end up getting sent to the past as unfortunately they have ran out of food and basically starved to death. Delta would grow up and then proceed to ensure him and his sister would be born with their specific powers by becoming zero and causing the events of ZTD to not only have that happen but to produce a reality where everyone lives with the knowledge of ZTD so that they have the fuel to prevent the messed up future we see in VLR[/spoiler]

Recomendaría este juego para darle un mejor "final" a la saga, no porque el juego me haya gustado especialmente (sí, el entrecomillado tiene un sentido, luego lo explico).

Como aspectos positivos, destacaría que los puzzles vuelven a ser bastante buenos (no mejor que los de la segunda entrega, pero superan a los de la primera), las voces de doblaje están bastante bien, y vuelven a introducir personajes ya conocidos para continuar con sus historias.

Pero para mí, el juego destaca más por lo negativo. Tiene demasiadas escenas en comparación con los puzzles. A veces parece que estás viendo una película de bajo presupuesto. ¿Y por qué de bajo presupuesto? Porque las animaciones y los modelos 3D no son nada de mi agrado, se ven algo feos y rígidos. No son capaces de transmitir lo que pretenden, hasta rozar en ocasiones lo ridículo. Y volviendo al tema de las escenas, no te dan la opción de pasar más rápido los diálogos, así que se vuelve a veces muy tediosos, sobre todo si eres de leer rápido.
Por otro lado, las reacciones de los personajes a veces escapan de mi entendimiento. Se vuelven muy exageradas en determinadas situaciones, rompiendo totalmente con sus personalidades. Creo que quisieron meter drama y morbo, pero pienso que se pasaron, y abordan este asunto de forma algo burda. 
El sistema narrativo de escenas sueltas sin conexión se me hace especialmente lioso y hace que pierda el sentido de un todo. Tienes que repasar activamente las escenas cuando las tienes prácticamente todas desbloqueadas para entender qué ocurría antes y qué después, y para mí eso hace que la historia pierda frente a las anteriores entregas. 
Y ya para terminar, decir que el final queda muy abierto, y tiene pinta que no van a hacer más juegos. Después de tantos líos argumentales, saltos temporales, lineas alternativas... Me parece una forma muy triste de terminar una saga en la que se han currado tanto la historia.

114183050.review:
Definitely a lot more enjoyable than Virtue's Last Reward due to its achronological approach. Instead of slogging through 20~ hours of branching scenarios to reach all of the locks, you're immediately thrust into the action with short playable Fragments. The player also has a sense of whiplash and complete bewilderment that compliments the story well (and the characters' position within it).

Where this game really falls down is the production value. There was a clear step down in budget between Virtue's Last Reward, resulting in stilted character animations and not a lot of new music, but I don't think that this gets in the way of the story and engaging with the characters nearly as much as people make out.

In terms of the story and characters, it's a mixed bag. Some of the new additions are great (Carlos, Q, Diana) and those returning from past titles are just as good as you remember them (Phi, Sigma, Junpei, Akane). That being said, Mira and Eric are both some of the worst characters I've ever seen in a visual novel/adventure game.

Zero's plan in this final installment is also a little... underwhelming. I won't go into spoilers here, but I can see why so many people came away from ZTD disappointed. I'm honestly not sure that Uchikoshi could've done a better job considering all of the expectations, however.

7/10 places it just above VLR (6/10) and below 999 (8/10) for me.

111730226.review:
I had heard a lot of praise and scorn over the direction Uchikoshi took in Zero Time Dilemma, and I was super excited to get into it. I 100% agree that it's a mix of incredible highs and dismal lows. Zero Time Dilemma does a lot of things right, but it also does a lot of things wrong. 

The Good:
-- Coherently concludes the previous two games
-- Develops several reoccurring characters in very interesting ways (Junpei is now super nihilistic and this drastically affects his relationship with Akane in a way that I greatly enjoyed)
-- Almost every new character is well written
-- D-Team segments are phenomenal
-- The main antagonist is well written and their complex motives add to the story
--[spoiler]Fitting extension of the narrative of the previous games (999 had sending information to the past, VLR had sending personalities to the past, ZTD sends entire people to the past)[/spoiler]

--Zero II's reveal is really well done.
-- Diana is cool and awesome
-- The escape rooms are very well designed and a lot of fun
-- Decision games are very fun and there's lots of gore
-- Good voice acting on some of the characters
-- Has room for a sequel but feels relatively complete as a trilogy

The Bad:
-- Some of the characters are unlikable. Eric sucks ass and there was only one scene where he was even remotely likable. Mira is a character that is really interesting and has a lot of room to explore her character but ends up being really stale and generic. 
-- Dio is not in this game
-- There aren't many decision games that are that fun. I went in expecting SAW-esque death traps but a lot of the games were very basic and were just based around getting the right answer. A good portion were entirely scripted and felt like they didn't matter. You'd make a decision, and some unforeseen consequence emerges and gives you a game over. There's no real choice there.
-- Much shorter than either of the Nonary Games. I think this boils down to the fact that this game is not a visual novel but instead uses cutscenes. This affects the game length as writers can put a lot more information and dialogue in text per minute of gameplay compared to voice dialogue. I don't hate the cutscenes, but I feel like it holds the narrative back. VLR had some very good descriptive writing (Sigma's description of death, for example) and the cutscene format makes it harder to pull of good descriptive writing without telling the audience out loud.

111263103.review:
Strange as it may seem, I think I'm the first person to review this game who has never played any of the games in its series prior to this one.  Therefore, it is best you only read if you too have not played other Zero Escape games.

I bought this game because the premise sounded much like the Saw films, of which I am a fan of.  I also like many films that are similar to those such as Cube, The Employer, Breathing Room and many more.  I played the first Saw game more than a decade ago and really enjoyed it.  The presence of a sinister-looking villain named Zero further enhanced my expectations that Zero Time Dilemma would be similar.  The way Zero introduces the games instantly reminds one of Jigsaw, and indeed it is strange that no one else seems to have made this comparison.

The beginning is very much along the lines of the Saw-like films I have mentioned.  But straight away, after a relatively short cut scene, the player has to make a choice.  To me, this felt like a twist on a formula I'm familiar with.  No problems so far.

Once past the intro segment, the format of this game is non-linear, however.  And the way that is implemented in the game is to divide the nine characters into three teams and then divide the individual "games" into segments.  Some of the "segments" at least can be played by each team.  This allows the player to manipulate the outcomes to see the differing branches of the story.  This has obviously been done because the game would need to be replayed lots of times in order to see all the paths and endings.

Unfortunately, the game's design makes the experience of playing very convoluted and involving repetition.  Added to this, there are long, boring dialogue exchanges that seem to go on for about 15 minutes at a time, before we get to the actual "game" in that segment.  Imagine going through that three times for a single segment, once for each time, and you will soon get annoyed.  And all this dialogue all seems to hinge on the player understanding what the previous games in the series are about.  If, like me, ZTD is your first excursion into the series, the dialogue will seem like a load of incoherent nonsense.  The voice acting is monotone, making matters worse.

The "escape room" puzzles had the potential to be great, but are harmed by the lack of a hotspot reveal system of the kind you generally find in modern point-and-click adventure games.  It's easy to miss something if you are not clicking on everything in the room.  And that means it feels like a pixel hunt, which is tedious, and only serving to slow the pace of the game down further.

Beyond the basic premise of people being trapped in an underground facility of some kind, and having to play a series of Saw-like games, I really cannot tell you anything else about the story.  I could not follow it.  And it bored me trying to do so.

I'm sure that one day someone will make a game that is similar to the films I have mentioned and is implemented in a manner more akin to Saw: The Video Game, which is excellent.  That game, unlike this one, doesn't bore the player to death with endless dialogue.  Its plot is easy to follow.  The "games" are each very tense to play and keep the player on their toes.  I'm struggling to think of anything I disliked in that game, except the annoying circuit puzzle.

Unfortunately, ZTD is not the game I thought it was.  Boredom, coupled with the convoluted gameplay, ruined what little enjoyment I got out of it.  I had Zero Escape: The Nonary Games on my wishlist for well over a year.  Not any longer.

A great end to a fantastic series. I enjoy how there aren't as many sexual harassment type comments towards the female cast as other games in the series (VLT is particularly bad for this). I love how ZTD links back with the other titles in the series. I find the content of this game to be a bit more dark and gory than the previous two, but I don't imagine many squeamish people got this far. I honestly think it'd be a shame not to play this title if you've played 999 and Virtue's Last Reward. It'd be shame to play this game first too. There are many components that would confuse new players to the series.

Gameplay wise, it is a little strange to have animated cut scenes instead of having the game be more visual novel style. I also found that the rooms were less challenging than VLT, but that also meant that I was stuck less. There was a lot less puzzles that relied on chance too, so that's definitely a plus.

The soundtrack is very similar to VLT, but I found it drew on my fond memories for the other game.

In terms of content, I found it to be a bit stigmatizing towards mental health, but a lot media doesn't shine the greatest of lights on that topic matter. I understand why those choices were made for the story, but I can't help but wish it went a different way. 

All in all, I highly recommend it. If you enjoyed VLT, you're in for a treat.

109762218.review:
This is the third (and currently last) game in the Zero Escape series, so I would not recommend starting here if you have not played the first two. This game is meant as a continuation and conclusion to both games, so either play 9 Persons, 9 Hours, 9 Doors and Virtue's Last Reward, or the Nonary Games bundle on your own first before thinking of trying this one out.


For those already invested in Zero Escape, ZTD follows up on VLR's ending with a group of time travelers infiltrating a Mars simulation sight to stop the spread of an apocalyptic virus, and meeting faces old and new. That's what happened last week, anyway. Instead, we open in media res as the participants of the DCOM simulation wake up imprisoned by yet another Zero, who forces them to play the Decision Game in teams as they face escape rooms and Saw-esque choices to make it out of the bunker alive.

Zero Time Dilemma is heavily story-based, if you are only interested in the puzzles, ZTD is not for you. The game isn't a true visual novel either, instead it is presented like a movie or tv show, and over half of the game is cut-scenes. Several of the rooms are also more difficult than past games. The game's other gimmick is you can play scenes out of order, as the characters forget what's happened every ninety minutes, letting you jump all over the timeline piecing things together slowly.

This game was originally cancelled, and petitioned back into existence by the fanbase. As a result, its animations are pretty limited but this can be forgiven. If you enjoyed the first two, you'll probably enjoy this one as well. It has the same mindbending twists and turns, especially in the second half of the game.

108258383.review:
I was highly uncomfortable with a lot of the plot points, subject matter, and characters in this one. If you have any of the following triggers you probably shouldn't play this game (being as vague as I can without spoiling it for people): [spoiler] suicide depictions/mentions (not surprising to anyone who played VLR), r*pe (there were a couple scenes where it was mentioned, and another where it was only "attempted" and not completed and intent was not there, but it was messed up that this was a plot point tbh and many other kinds of scenes could have replaced this one), child harm, animal harm (there were "reasons" for this but none mentioned in-game, which made it worse tbh), depictions/mentions of abuse of all kinds, among other things but I think I've covered most of the big ones here. [/spoiler]

This IS a horror/escape room game so expect death, kidnapping, and other things of the sort, obviously, but it is worth mentioning the above triggers and concerns for those of us with triggers who wish to avoid them. I felt that some of it was lazy writing, and could have been done differently; there is no reason to include some of these things, and with a bit of creativity they could have been avoided and it still could have been a fully fleshed out horror game. If you played VLR some of it comes as no surprise, though.

Also, I have a bit of an issue with the flirting with Phi in VLR now because that is pretty gross, all things considered; if you decide to play ZTD you'll understand why I say this. All of Sigma's pervy behavior towards characters in VLR is super icky anyway and I almost didn't play this game because of it. Just because it's a common trope doesn't mean it should be perpetuated. 

With the social issues out of the way, now come the technical and gameplay critiques. I also noticed ZTD had almost but not quite as many graphics issues as VLR. VLR looked like an absolute rush job re: mouth movement and the like. This one is slightly better, but not by a whole lot. Still, there are quite a lot of glitches with Akane's hair where it moves around and twitches on its own at random during cutscenes even when they are paused when you go to the menu. My favorite game is 999 in the series because it manages to avoid most of the social issues while still being a great horror game. Would it be better if all of it was fully animated? Yes, but it also doesn't necessarily need it. The sequels being animated is cool, but they would be better if they were fully finished. These games don't look quite finished, which is a bummer when you're paying money for them.

Gameplay-wise, it's mostly fine. But, my ADHD brain struggled with the Team Select menu and trying to sort out what scenes to play in which order. If you intend on playing this game, definitely take advantage of the flowchart and use that as your guide for where to begin and where to go next. I think VLR and 999 did a better job in some ways with this and with the various endings being a bit more detailed and not just a quick "game over"/"bad end" sequence. I would have added a few more incentives than already offered for completing all the dead ends; maybe you find more info in them, and use it in the next jump. Makes it a lot more worth it for completionists, as this game took me several days to complete (real-life stuff included, because I like most people couldn't speed through this in a day or two). In addition, the memo screen having limited ink and erasing counting towards that ink used bar were a major and unnecessary annoyance.

I was disappointed we didn't see Kyle in this one. I know his extra ending in VLR isn't canon, but it would have been nice to see him return.

If more games in this series are ever made I don't know that I'll be playing them. The social issues were enough to put me off of it, and I almost didn't finish this game because of them. I just wanted to know how the story ended. If you look past those, it is suspenseful and interesting. But the gameplay isn't as good as previous games imo aside from the extra camera angles when you rotate around in an escape room.

106954084.review:
As you see, yes I do recommend this game. However, I must add this entry has more fault than good which is unfortunate, as it is the finale of the Zero Escape trilogy, an amazing series. 
 
I would like to keep this review brief and spoiler free. Bare with me and let's begin. 

Mentioned before, Zero Time Dilemma is the finale to a trilogy, the last game in it's series.  Honestly this is one of the very few reasons why I recommend it. It's the end and a good story needs an ending. 
SO, IF THIS IS YOUR FIRST ZERO ESCAPE GAME, STOP NOW! I BEG YOU!! Go and purchase it's previous duel package "Zero Escape: The Nonary Games". Trust me those games are fantastic, worth every penny and you'd hate to spoil yourself. 

Okay? Good. As for a real justification I'd check this entry out, is for it's flowchart. This may be debatable among players, but I personally found myself quite engaged in the scrambled and fractured timelines. By not knowing exactly where or when you are, the game is setting up mystery to both the player and characters. Also with the way ZTD's story is executed, having everything jumbled, going back place to place to place, this is very fitting. Ha ... and ... these are puzzle games, therefore I think it works rather well. . . . oh yeah . . . This was a puzzle game. Hmm

Into some cons I guess. The puzzles within ZTD were a little too easy especially compared to its  predecessor, Virtues Last Reward, where admittedly I had to cheat at some point. Nothing stood remotely unique or challenging in any of the escape sequences. If you want to get through it quick, sure its great. I mean, the rooms were pretty cool but to me what came with them felt shallow just like some of new characters. I Don't want to get too into it for spoilers sake, but to be frank, I hated some of these new characters. They felt cliche, the writing was lazy and I wish there were more to them in the end. As for the re-occurring characters, they were fine and it was fun seeing them all again, they were definitely a pro.  

The game itself is boring to partake in but hey it plays more like a movie this time around  right? *Exhales* it looks hilarious. To be fair they were being ambitious for a small budget project, but I don't think they should have stepped away from the visual novel aspect. Events that occurred were cool and all, filled to the brim with violence and shock value, but gosh, it could have been better and...maybe even cheaper to have a wall of text thoroughly present us with detailed imagery and emotion. You can see what the creators wanted yet its a shame it almost fails.

And last the story. My, my, did the game have its up and downs. Things felt so rushed and instant you'll find yourself just accepting things as they happen. "Oh okay, they are dead now. Moving on." like that. However if you played VLR you know your end goal for ZTD and this game will tell you your answer. It was satisfying in it's later sections. When our characters finally start piecing together the best thing from this game, the puzzle of the flowchart, its kinda hype yet you need some patience. The first half's writing is mediocre at best, not as well woven as past games. Just let the ball get rolling to get to the good bits.

ZTD overall felt like a 6.5/10, an okaaay game. I really want to say more but not ruin it, there's not enough meat for me to expand upon without spoiling it or its prequels. I wish someone could SHIFT and make it better but still, this closure was all worth it in the end. Here we conclude Zero Escape, a mind bending cosmic series people should never forget.

106357580.review:
This is the only game in the series I have played, most likely a mistake on my part considering this game's story, but I wasn't to know that unfortunately, so my review will come from the perspective the above.

I don't recommend it. The voice acting is alright as I've seen worse, the music ranges from good down to either repetitive or uninspired. The in-game animations are poor.

As for the game itself, progression often takes a while as you look at a flow chart trying to work out what you didn't do, despite the flow chart showing that you have done all you could. It's not very intuitive in showing what you haven't yet done. Some of the outcomes are based on RNG, so even doing it "correctly" isn't possible for multiple attempts, which does not help when factoring in how un-intuitive it is to know if something was done correctly or not. Headbutting the same thing for a different outcome is straight up stupid. There was also a point in time where an answer was two words separated by a space, however to input the answer you needed to omit the space. Further in, there is an answer that does require a space. I can only assume this was a localisation issue, but it's shoddy non-the-less. There are also heavy inconsistencies in the game, most made notable by how a grenade launcher worked at one point, and then in a subsequent story-line past its initial use. It was incredible nonsensical, and downright shoddy.

As for the plot, as spoiler free as I can make this, it's inconsequential due to the subject matter at hand. There is no threat. At some points character motivations and their subsequent actions just don't line up at all.

That being said, there were some genuine moments of greatness in the story too, though they were few. Those were enjoyed, and heartwarming, which I believe was part of the intent of the plot. It just seems poorly constructed, unfortunately.

I doubt I'll play the other games after having played this, as it has not made me want to try their stories/experience out for myself.

105499760.review: Zero Time Dilemma marks the conclusion to Spike Chunsoft’s Zero Escape trilogy of visual novels, and in the nicest way I can put it, this game is a bloody mess. Unlike the first two games, this game takes place from the perspective of multiple characters, specifically, it is divided into three teams of three: C Team, Q Team. and D Team. You go through portions of the story called “Time Fragments” to play each scene out and experience that portion of the story, and more fragments unlock as you clear more escape rooms and Decision Games. To be frank, though, for a game that prides itself on the choices the player makes throughout the journey, I honestly don't feel like the player's choices matter in this game all that much compared to the previous two, even if there is more variety in the Decision Games than "Pick a door to go through" or "Select whether to Ally or Betray another player". For what it’s worth, the game still has a number of endearing scenes that will tug the player’s emotions in all sorts of directions, particularly the endings, though that does not negate the issue of the plot feeling scattered at times. Since the game's story is ultimately split up into time fragments that are scarcely connected to each other, the decisions end up not mattering as much as before when the player 9 times out of 10 is just going to either replay each decision to get all of the outcomes (admittedly, also an issue in the previous installment, though it wasn’t as bad there as it is here) or move on to the next time fragment and complete its puzzle. Because of this, I also don't feel like there is much of a sense of progression to the game until the player completes all of the escape rooms and gets to the game's endings. On top of that, the presentation is god awful. While the game admittedly looks fine on a handheld like the Nintendo 3DS or the PlayStation Vita, on more advanced software like a PC or the PlayStation 4, it really becomes apparent how poor the animations and graphics are. The backgrounds look fine regardless of the system you’re playing on, but character models were clearly designed with the handheld releases in mind, and weren’t properly upscaled as well as they could for the PC and console releases. Frankly, even compared to other 3DS titles released the same year (Pokémon Sun and Moon, Ace Attorney: Spirit of Justice), I still feel this game’s animation quality is inexcusably horrendous. The music, on the other hand, is definitely better. A decent chunk of the music comprises remixes of songs from VLR, with a handful from 999, and though I prefer the original versions compared to ZTD’s rearrangements, I still feel the returning songs are done well in this game. The new songs are also composed rather well, too, with the ending theme being one of my favorites. The escape rooms are also still as good as before, even if there are fewer than the last two times, some of the puzzles feel like the kind you find at a children’s toy shop, and they have a tendency to end abruptly. Despite this, I still had plenty of fun solving the many puzzles the game throws at the player, and I never felt any of them had any especially cheap moments, nor did I need to use a walkthrough to solve any. Ultimately, while I do consider this game as arguably the weakest of the trilogy, I do still recommend playing it, both to enjoy it on its own merits and to wrap up the trilogy. Time will tell if we end up getting Zero Escape 4 or not, but until then, I'm still glad I got to play these three games. Pleasant dreams.

105029941.review:
This is, without any doubt whatsoever, the dumbest story I have ever experienced in my entire life. 

And I'm not even disappointed. I'm actually impressed by the amount of effort that was spent on writing every single detail of this ginormous pile of garbadge. Congratulations to everyone involved. 

The disjointed narrative structure makes it impossible to care about anything. Characters will constantly reference things you haven't seen yet or specifically chose not to do. Imagine if someone told you to direct a movie. But you've never read the script before until they hand it to you one page at a time and completely out of order. There's basically no coherent story up until maybe the last 25% of the game.  At which point it all comes together on the premise that nothing mattered anyways, that there was never supposed to be any story in the first place. The arbitrary decision points and branches just boil down to a check list. Sometimes it even feels like you're playing a 90s Sierra game: "Do you want to go left or right?". "Left". "An anvil drops on your head! Game over".
Even more ridiculous concepts like alien time machines are constantly introduced for the sole reason of clumsily tying the plots of the previous two games into this mess. And that's considering the fact that the entire series is already built on the shakiest foundation with its selective amnesia nonsense.
The big plot twist is so unbelievably bad, mismanaged and on top of that pointless, it eclipses the one from Virtue's Last Reward. That one was just as cheap but at least served a purpose. At the end there's still no tangible explanation why any these stupidly complex setups (particularly the escape room puzzles) and plans spanning hundreds of years were necassary or possible or why any of these specific people were even involved.
But the most vexing thing is that, realistically, nothing should even happen in this game. Because at least two characters have already figured out how all of this works and should never even run into any these weird situations. Yet for some reason they have to relearn everything over the course of the 20+ hour story.

And all that's nothing to say about the rest of the game. The graphics, specifically the animations, are extremely rough. More often than not the camera pans away to convey all the action by sound alone. Lip syncing is also nowhere to be found. Although that wouldn't really save the horrible dialogue scenes either. The script is considerably trashier than a B-movie. Every single time someone dies it turns into an unintentional comedy, both because the scenes are usually completely ridiculous and out of left field and because the characters overact so hard.

Even the puzzles are worse than the previous games'. In fact, to me personally Zero Time Dilemma feels more like a glorified hidden object game in many cases. More often than not the goal in any of the escape rooms is to spend 10 minutes spinning the camera around in a 3D environment trying to figure out which exact pixel the developers wanted you to click on to advance. 

The soundtrack is still fine but mostly reused from previous entries.

All in all I don't recommend Zero Time Dilemma it to anyone, but especially not to those who liked the first or the first two games. The conclusion to this story is idiotic and full of gaping plot holes that are just impossible to ignore.

102852128.review:
[h3]Pros: [/h3]

- Amazing music (like the other two games)
- Quite nice animations compared to the other two games, camera panning makes cinematics look a lot more alive
- The story explores many interesting concepts like the prior games, I enjoyed finding out about new thought experiments
- The story is not perfect, but I think it is close to a really good one
- The decisions are mostly interesting and some even quite challenging
- Very interesting character design and great voice acting

[h2]Cons:[/h2]

- The way to progress in the game is sometimes very difficult, as the game expects you to do all choices two times before unlocking some new content. This does not make a  lot of sense to me, as some "wrong" choices literally feel pointless to do

- Similarly, like in the previous game, although way worse, sometimes you just unlock some random "!" somewhere after doing something, and there is no where to find that out apart from checking every single available scene. They also are often not visible in the main decision tree view, which is strange

- The fact that the player is not any character this time really confuses the experience from the beginning, as you have no idea what team is going to get unlock next and where, until later when you start seeing the connections eventually

- [b]The puzzle rooms this time were really disappointing because:[/b]

 -  They often contained all kinds of uninteractable scenery objects which were not marked in any way, so as a player you'd think why can't I click this or do more with it

 -  As per previous games, there is no way to highlight what spots in a room are interactable, and this makes the experience really frustrating, as some larger objects are invisibly divided into smaller clickable parts. Sometimes this goes so far that I had to look some puzzles up, because I just was not clicking the correct pixel apparently.

-   There were illogicalities with many of the puzzles, for example the puzzle where half of the room is dark and other half is lit. You cannot interact with things in the dark, EXCEPT one thing, for no reason.

-    Overall movement in the puzzle rooms was feeling really slow and tedious, and the camera angles shifted really bothersomely: Sometimes I clicked just past the target and the camera zoomed so I can no longer see the target and have to zoom out first, Also, if clicking on one item and then it zooms in and there is another item visible in the zoomed view  which is not part of the same "item block" in the code, you cannot click it, despite it being visible!

 - Other kinds of issues with some items only being clickable at a certain perceived distance

- Apart from puzzles, we had a way of writing notes, similar to before. This was good and necessary, but it contains a bug. There is a "highly unnecessary" count of how much one can draw on one notepad (does not relate to how full it is, only counts when a pen is being used). The main problem with this is that it also counts when you ERASE text, so writing two sentences worth of stuff, and then erasing them counts as writing 4 sentences worth of stuff. Also just moving the eraser back and forth without erasing anything counts as text limit increase. If the limit is full you cannot add more notes, and have to be careful to not click "yes" in the confirmation for "erase this page of notes?" which follows.


[h1]Overall:[/h1]

- Apart from usability issues and sometimes awful puzzle design (mechanically, not thematically) you are looking at a great game at its core, which does bring a conclusion to the Zero Escape series. I do think that if you enjoyed the first two games, you should play this, just too see what they came up with if nothing else. 


[i]Morse certa, acta est fabula. [/i]

100829048.review:
NOTE & TL;DR: this is a (slightly) Positive review, and I would only recommend this to people who have already played both 999 and VLR. In summary, while this game has a ton of problems, it will at least let you leave the series with a better taste in your mouth than VLR ever would if you decided to just stop there; I personally hated VLR, and while this doesn't change that, at least it closes the series out in a more acceptable manner. 

Personally, I'm gonna keep this one simple. D-Team hard-carries this game, but there's a lot of great stuff there, so overall, it's worth it if you are already so deep into the series. And that's it. For every other positive point, I can say a negative one that detracts from the experience just as much as the positive adds.
- The voice acting is absolutely great (A+, really!) / The animations are outright terrible (the models are better than VLR when in a still picture, but when moving, BOY it is actually a lot worse, not just in how it looks, but it's full of "bugs" where people will have their animations reset last second, dead people will blink, etc.)
- C-Team has its good moments (Carlos is great!) / Q-Team is awful (Just... everything about them...)
- The puzzles are fun / The story has an enormous amount of problems and holes
- The OST is pretty good / There's a lot of scenes that go for pure shock value and felt ridiculously exaggerated and unnecessary quite often
Etc.
It really is D-Team that, as I mentioned, makes this worth to play through, at least in my opinion. I truly loved and cared about them, and their parts of the story are pretty damn good. 

So, overall, I personally would recommend playing 999 only. But if you play VLR as well (considering it's already bundled with 999 on Steam), then you should definitely play this one (ZTD) too and finish the series. Doing so is much better than just stopping at VLR, even (or maybe especially) if you hated VLR like I did.

Nothing about this game is particularly well done, the ending is atrocious and the characterization falls well beyond just being flat. This game should not have been the note to end on as it taints the legacy of 999 and Virtue's Last Reward. If you want to play a Zero Escape game make it one of them and not this travesty.

98448719.review:
This game, honestly, is not good. It fails to be a truly compelling conclusion to the Zero Escape trilogy, and it also fails to stand out in most other aspects. 

I believe there are a lot of fans of the Nonary Games who will hate this game simply for not being as good as those earlier entries, and I will give them exactly that. If you're someone who can't tolerate a game that is rough around the edges, or you're hoping for answers to questions you may have actually posed after finishing VLR, turn around now. Do not play this game. It isn't going to be worth your time, and I can't put that any more nicely. Maybe play it if you're interested in seeing what a clusterfuck it can be, as it can be an exceedingly hilarious experience with friends, but know that I warned you.

If you're someone who's willing to 'hear Uchikoshi out', so to speak, this game might be for you. I personally think this game has some ideas in it that are good in concept, and probably would have made for a pretty good addition if the "original" vision of this game actually released. Despite the utter ridiculousness of the game's general plot and premise, it manages to stay pretty consistent with itself. No matter how stupid the plot twists are, they are undeniably foreshadowed, and even the plot contrivances that are present to make them happen aren't much worse than some of Uchikoshi's other games.

The fragment system is truly a "love it or hate it" scenario. While I will say that it almost objectively robs the game's deaths of any possible emotional impact, it is nonetheless fundamental to what Zero Time Dilemma is. I think the concept leads to a pretty interesting dynamic within the game's plot. Some fragments manage to retain their emotional impact despite being potentially rendered null and void in the next fragment you play, which coupled with the game's pretty okay overall plot shows the true potential of the idea, and it's something I ended up enjoying in the end.

I will say that my opinion is informed very deeply by an appreciation of ideas and potential, and the passion put into this stupid little game. If this all seems like useless mumbo-jumbo, and you'd rather just be playing an actually well constructed game, you can go ahead and skip this one. I don't blame you! I just have my own reasons to respond 'Yes' to the question of whether I recommend this game. If you're someone like me, someone who wants to see all of Uchikoshi's ideas, including the ridiculously bad and the painfully mediocre, I do wholeheartedly recommend this game.

Also, this game is really, really funny. There's at least 20 all-time funniest moments and quotable lines in this piece of crap. Almost worth playing just for that.

97908545.review:
[b] This is the 3rd game in the Zero Escape series. In order to fully understand its plot, you need to play the first two. My review of them can be found [/b] [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/nowimex/recommended/477740/]here.[/url]
[list]
[*] The decision to make cutscenes with animated 3D models is a good choice over 3D sprouts in VLR. The execution of those cutscenes is where the problems lie. It is bad: facial animations are pretty much non-existent and general animations are clunky. After a while you get used to it, but it's still a big problem.
[*] The puzzles makes a good balance between 999's school-level and VLR's mastermind level. The game makes you feel smart when you solve it without making you feel dumb when you can't solve it.
[*] The voice acting is very good, which makes clunky cutscenes at least listenable. Some lines sound off, but there are very few of them. Sound design is kinda bad, a lot of things either sound off ([spoiler]gunshot is not loud enough[/spoiler]) or don't make a sound at all (tapping a metal box).
[*] The story is not very climactic to feel like an ending to a series, but it's very good. The strengths of this series still stay: foreshadowing the hell out of reveals, confusing moments being perfectly explained, characters asking questions the player is interested in, etc. Characters are cool, but some of them feel one-sided. Some twists don't add anything to the story other than shock-value (they are still fun and interesting, just not really meaningful).
[/list]

[i] (Sadly, just) a good finale to a great series. [/i]

7/10 if you accept cutscenes, 6/10 overall

95790991.review:
My recommendation: play the first two games ("Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors" AKA 999 and "Virtue's Last Reward" AKA VLR), and then pretend this game (Zero Time Dilemma AKA ZTD) does not exist.

There are many problems with ZTD, but the biggest is that the plot is garbage. The writing across the whole series was never great, often suffering from "anime syndrome". However, the plot itself was strong enough, and the twists interesting enough, to be worth the payoff at the end.

Not so with ZTD. The writing is as weak as ever, but now the plot is nowhere near good enough to save it. By the 2nd act of the game, the protagonists acquire a power (or realize that they had that power all along?) that essentially gives them a get-out-of-jail-free card for any situation they face, completely deflating any dramatic tension.

I pushed on through the game, in hopes that "the big plot twist" payoff would be worth it. It was not to be. It's hard to explain how egregious the Deus Ex Machina was without giving spoilers. Closest analogy I can think of without giving too much away is: imagine the movie The Sixth Sense, but they had included a scene where the mother and Bruce Willis played patty cake prior to the big reveal.

Plot problems aside, the game also has some gameplay and user interface problems.

In VLR (and possibly 999, though I can't quite recall), you acquire "files" that contain info that is necessary to solve the puzzles. The info from the file alone is not sufficient: you often need to combine the info from the file with info from the scene you're in. A typical example would be some graffiti on the wall that's encoded, and the file contains the key to decypher the code. VLR includes a "note" feature where you can scribble arbitrary notes to yourself using the mouse. This feature isn't strictly necessary, because you could always play the game with a physical pen and pad of paper by your side, but I definitely appreciated it as a Twitch streamer, because it allowed my viewers to see exactly what notes I was taking and they could follow my thought process as I worked through the puzzles.

ZTD downgrades this feature in two specific and inexplicable ways. First of all, they made it so that you cannot open the notes while viewing your files. That means if you were trying to take notes from the file so that you could later combine that info with what you saw in the scene, you'd have to click on "menu", then "file", then click on the file you wanted to look at, memorize some of the info, click on "exit" to return to the scene, then click on "menu" again and then click on "note", and then reselect the color you wanted (since it always resets to green when you re-open the notes), write down the info you wanted, click on "exit" to return to the scene, click on "menu" again, click on "file" again, click on the file you wanted to see again, memorize a bit more info, click on "exit" again, click on "menu" again, click on "notes" again, re-select your color, and then draw a bit more, and repeat until you've copied over all the info you intend to extract from the note.

Second of all, they added an "ink" mechanic such that you can run out of ink when taking notes, and then you have to completely discard all your notes to get a fresh cartridge of ink.

These downgrades are inexplicable in that again, you could just play with a physical pad and paper to take notes. They don't make the "non-streamer" experience any more difficult, but they just make things more annoying for people who want to Twitch stream the game.

I also disliked in ZTD the "3 robots/bomb disarming" puzzle. It's difficult to go into details of the problem with the puzzle without spoiling the solution to them. So instead, I'll say that in both 999 and VLR, every puzzle made sense to me, and I managed to solve them eventually without ever looking up the solutions online or resorting to trial and error. But this was not the case for this puzzle. And even after seeing the solution, it was still unclear to me how you were supposed to arrive at this solution with the info available to you.

There is also a "narrative puzzle" in ZTD which I found extremely unsatisfying. Again, I'll be a bit vague to avoid spoilers, but it's structurally similar to the following analogy: Zero gives you two potions to drink, and they say neither of them are poisoned. So which one do you drink? The characters start off by reasoning that if neither of them are poisoned, it doesn't make a difference which one you drink. But then one character asks "What if Zero was lying about whether or not the red potion is poisoned? In which case, we should definitely drink the blue potion!" Hopefully it's obvious why this reasoning beggars belief: If Zero was willing to lie about whether or not the red potion was poisoned, why wouldn't they be willing to lie about whether or not the blue potion was poisoned as well? For people who have already played the game or who don't mind spoilers, what I'm getting at is if we're willing to entertain the idea that Zero lied about [spoiler]being able to predict people's decisions[/spoiler], why wouldn't Zero also lie about [spoiler]whether Radical 6 is a cure for Fanatic Bio R[/spoiler], or [spoiler]whether Fanatic Bio R even exists[/spoiler], or [spoiler]whether the vials contain Radical 6 as opposed to just straight poison[/spoiler], or any number of other possibilities. There's a reason logic puzzles axiomatically assume that the rules of the puzzle are not lied about: if you allow for the possibility that the person telling you the rules of the puzzle might have lied about what the rules are, then all reasoning goes out the window.

All that said, ZTD does bring some interesting innovations to the series. I think the idea where ZTD asks you to directly type in an answer is pretty clever, and it was [i]mostly[/i] well executed. However, there was one puzzle where I found they stumbled. Again, to avoid spoilers, I'll give analogy. Imagine the game asks you "What do you call your mother's mother?" Naturally, you would type in "grandmother", but the game tells you you are incorrect. So you scratch your head, and try other answers like "nana" or "granny" or "grandparent", all of which gets rejected. In desperation, you try all sorts of variations until you finally find out the game wanted "grand mother" instead of "grandmother". I feel like the possible answers were distinct enough that the game should have accepted your answer if you were within 1 or 2 Levenshtein distance of the "true" answer.

The other thing I liked about the game was that it was a nice introduction to several topics that people might not otherwise encounter, like the Sleeping Beauty problem, the Newcomb problem, and alternatives to causal decision theory. Their handling of time travel was pretty sloppy -- they almost manage to touch upon the Novikov self-consistency principle, but fall short -- but most works of fiction handle time travel sloppily, so I can't fault them too much for this. That said, don't expect a very rigorous treatment of these topics either. They fall prey to the laymen mistake of overvaluing the concept of of "identity" (specifically, the idea that in alternate timelines, there is a well define set of atoms that corresponds to the "you" of this timeline), and underestimating just how infinite the number of "infinite alternative timelines" is in the multiworld interpretation of quantum dynamics (in the game's narrative, they say there's an infinite number of alternative timelines, but then act like there's only about 12 alternative timelines).

So yes, the game has its positives, but let's be honest here: The only reason anyone would play ZTD is because they played 999 and VLR, and they want to see how it all ends. I honestly do not think ZTD will give those players that satisfaction. If anything, it is more likely to disappoint and enrage those players. And so I do not recommend anyone play this game.

Let's just say that you'll notice that this game was basically funded by it's fans and not a studio. Certain content/story had to be cut due to these new and major restrictions to the developers time and funds.
Just don't expect too much I guess. 
And don't expect every single plot point left unsolved from VLR to be resolved in this one.
If you enjoyed the other games of this series I don't see a reason why you shouldn't play it.
For anyone else it might be a miss rather than a hit.
(Then again, it might also be a miss for fans as well.)

94707869.review:
i’ll briefly sketch outlines of three views of free will in this steam review. the first is that of “libertarian agency”. while many off-the-cuff definitions of free will seem to quickly descend into tautology, by far the most cogent definition of free will that i’ve come across was offered by apologist j.p. moreland. the second position that i’ll discuss (the dissenting view) is the deterministic position. in brief: we "do not have" free will. finally, i’ll take a moment to introduce the compatibility position, which states that determinism can be reconciled with free will. this is the position taken by many modern naturalist philosophers. in the essay “naturalism and libertarian agency”, moreland describes his “libertarian” view of free will. he insisted that our actions do not have prior causes: you are the ultimate cause of your own actions. you can initiate and stop yourself from initiating any action. we are all “little gods”, or “unmoved movers”. now, you may ask why i'm citing an apologist to define free will. well, theologians tend to spend a lot of time thinking about free will, as it is central to theodicy and many other works of apologetics. i'll be dealing primarily with libertarianism for the purposes of this talk, but i’ll briefly discuss a different, compatibilist view of free will later on. libertarian agency is also called contra-causal free will, because it holds that our decisions are not bound to our brains (which are made of matter), it is difficult to imagine how our thoughts could be completely free, or causally unbound. for this reason, free will is often linked with dualism. within this framework, the “soul” or “spirit” (which is not composed of matter, and is therefore freed from causation) is the “free agent” in decision making. determinism holds that we live in a causal universe, and that we are not somehow exempt from that web of causality. our thoughts and deeds are fully caused. our decisions are the effects of prior causes, and the causes of future effects. put simply, determinism is the position that your choices, like all other aspects of the macroscopic universe, have causal antecedents; that is to say, given the same options and the same set of preconditions, you will always make the same choice. but we still make choices. if you’re at the café for lunch, and you decide to get a regular cum soda instead of your usual diet cum soda, there was a reason for that: probably many reasons, that all came together in that one decision. in fact, the question, “why did you do that?” really only makes sense within a deterministic framework. remember: determinism doesn’t say that you’re some sort of mindless automaton with no mental life. you still deliberate over choices, your past experiences still play a role, you’ll still sometimes make a snap judgement based on your emotions instead of thinking things through- but all of these factors are fully caused, and causally affect your decision-making process in turn. determinism does constrain you, but it only constrains you to act within your own character- which, upon reflection, doesn’t seem so bad. within a deterministic framework, your decision may be influenced by a multitude of factors. some of these factors may be consciously recognized, while you may be completely unaware of others. regardless, from the determinist perspective, your decisions are the result of a calculus. a whole bunch of variables go in, and a decision comes out. let’s contrast this with contra-causal free will: you are waiting to cross the street, and the light says “don’t walk”. perhaps you’re running late for a meeting, perhaps you’ve been standing in line all day and you’re feeling impatient, and perhaps you were recently issued a citation by a police officer for jaywalking. does any of this factor in to your decision to cross against the light? if you’re a “libertarian agent”, the answer must be “no”. if you are an unmoved mover, you simply choose. in many ways, a free choice is a meaningless choice. when you’re weighing your options, this is a deterministic process. in fact, “weighing” one’s options is an excellent analogy for the way decision-making works within a deterministic framework. even though it might seem like a close call, thirty grams of lead and fifteen grams of gold will always weigh more than five grams of silver and thirty five grams of copper. if you weighed them a second time, could things come out differently? i’ll expand a little on the example that i used earlier (which i stole from the guys at reasonable doubts, by the way). let’s say you’re ordering lunch, and you’re trying to choose whether you’re going to have a cum soda or a diet cum soda. your decision may be influenced by how you’re feeling about yourself, by whether your spouse has recently made a comment about your waistline, by whether you have a strong dislike for the aftertaste common to diet cum, by whether you suffer from diabetes or chronic hypoglycaemia, by whether you have a sweet tooth, by whether your father used to drink a diet cum soda while he worked on the car, by whether you just saw a magazine with a really slim model on the cover, by whether you are a huge gay queer, or by whether you’ve decided that aspartame is part of a secret government mind-control project (which it is). do we have options in a deterministic universe? does it make sense to say that you chose the diet cum soda over the cum soda? doesn’t that imply that things could have worked out differently? well, in a sense, things could have worked out differently- had a different set of contingencies been in play. when choices or options are presented to us, we don’t necessarily know which we will choose, but that doesn’t make our choice free from causal influence. there are some definitions of free will that are compatible with determinism. rather than asserting that a decision could have come out differently even had all of the contingencies been the same (the libertarian position), compatibilists may define “free will” simply as an agent’s capacity to act in a manner that is not coerced or restrained. daniel dennett articulates his two-stage model of decision making in his essay, “on giving libertarians what they say they want”- "when we are faced with an important decision, a consideration-generator whose output is to some degree undetermined produces a series of considerations, some of which may of course be immediately rejected as irrelevant by the agent... ultimately serve as predictors and explicators of the agent’s final decision." 

that’s not only compatible with determinism, that is determinism.

This was the game is what made me no longer have hope for any upcoming game ever. I love the Zero Escape series. I have played all the games. This game is so bad it makes the previous entries retroactively worse by association. It's a real shame. The plot is out of control, with contrivances that put Virtue's Last Reward to shame. This game involves ancient Alien Spacetime teleporter pods that need 10 months to recharge in between uses to set up a nonsensical plot twist that doesn't add as much as it takes away. The only value to be gained from this game is purely by laughing at it, and viewing it as lame fanfiction. The cutscenes are terribly acted, poorly animated, and makes me miss the beeping text scrolling of the original game. Uchikoshi tries to recapture some of the magic from 999 and VLR, but it comes off as trying way too hard, creating a narrative severely lacking in nearly every regard. The puzzle rooms are not very memorable either. They are mostly forgettable, outside of one that involves changing the room's shape and layout.
This game isn't too long, around 20 hours if you know what you're doing. But it's a very long 20 hours. The ending is rather worth it given the absolute insanity that occurs in the third act. But absolutely not the ending you expected, wanted, or what the series deserved. 
To summarize, I suppose you could say,
"Life is simply unfair"

93937409.review:
Zero Time Dilemma is the third game in the Zero Escape trilogy, concluding the story started in 999 and Virtue's Last Reward. I would recommend this game, but with some caveats. First, don't even consider playing this game without playing the other games first. Zero Time Dilemma is heavily reliant on prior knowledge of 999 and VLR, especially the latter. Second, keep in mind that ZTD is the weakest game in the trilogy by a considerable margin. Temper your expectations accordingly. The game is still worth playing for some of its interesting ideas and some really cool moments, but if you loved Virtue's Last Reward and want everything set up there to be resolved satisfactorily, you may come away disappointed. If you keep these things in mind, you can still have a good experience. It has its moments, as long as you go in completely blind. 

Like the other games in the series, Zero Time Dilemma is half visual novel, half escape the room puzzle game. This may come down to personal taste, but visually, I think this game is the worst in the series. The 3D models somehow look even worse than in Virtue's Last Reward, with stiff, amateurish animations and facial expressions on top of that. The English voice acting is pretty hit or miss, but it's tolerable and some characters give decent performances. Music is about on par with the other games in the series. 

When it comes to the story, ZTD may have the most experimental structure in the series. Sometimes, this works out well and there are some great moments where everything seems to click and come together. However, without spoiling how it works, I question whether it was entirely worth it. In Virtue's Last Reward, the game's unique narrative structure really enhanced the game, but in ZTD, it often came off as more confusing than interesting. Zero Time Dilemma also has the huge narrative problem of having to resolve everything established in VLR, which I don't think it does very well by the end. VLR set up too much, and this game wasn't up to the task, unfortunately, particularly with one twist that I strongly disliked. The game is still worth it because some of the game's highs do live up to 999 and VLR, but it doesn't maintain that quality for the entire runtime. 

ZTD's puzzles are generally inoffensive. They're more difficult than in 999, but easier than in VLR on hard, which might be for the best. VLR's moon logic puzzles could sometimes be frustrating without any hints, while 999 was so easy that the puzzles solved themselves. ZTD gives you hints the longer you take, but won't be as quick to outright give you the answer as 999. I found this to be a nice balance.

Overall, I would give a lukewarm recommendation for Zero Time Dilemma. If you loved the first two games, you should play this game, but without setting your expectations too high. If you meet this game on its own terms, there's still a lot to like, despite its problems.

I'm guilty of playing this game first as it is the third game of a trilogy, however, I enjoyed it so much although I was confused at first, later I understood what is it all about. The story about nine individuals who were kidnapped and trapped in an underground facility, they were divided into three teams:

[list][*] Team C: Carlos (Leader) Akane, Junpei.
[*] Team D: Diana (Leader) Sigma, Phi.
[*] Team Q. Q (Leader), Eric, Mira.
[/list]
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2494811511

You choose which team to play and witness an event from their point of view, once this section ended, you can go to the second team and play through the same event or a different one, you'll also get to see the outcome of what other teams did which will effect on their colleagues. The story is very interesting and the more you play, the more you'll be hooked. I liked the puzzles so much, some of them are quite difficult and you could easily die. I didn't like the gore, sadly you have no option to disable it as it is a necessity of the story. 

The voice-overs are good, some of the voice actors are very well known. I liked the graphics style, however, I'm not very keen on some of the characters' designs. The soundtracks are nice, I liked the one that plays whenever there is an emotional part. The characters personalities are different from each other, I understand that the games, in general, make all types of characters to please all audiences, but one of them got on my nerves to the point that I was willing to skip his part. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2494807577

The best thing about this VN is that you can go back and forth between the events, choosing the cutscene or the part where you need to decide something. You can keep on replying to get different outcomes. There is a chart for each team or a global one, you can keep a track of the story and what else you must unlock.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2507056232

There is a backlog of the conversation, and a section where you can take notes on any screen you choose as evidence or something that'd help you to solve a puzzle. You can also view all files and everything you've collected so far. 


Pros:
+Interesting story.
+Excellent writing.
+Interesting characters 
+Good soundtracks.
+Chellenging puzzles.
+Multiple endings and routes. 
+Manual save.
+Good game length.
+Steam achievements.

Cons:
-Quite repetitive at the beginning, but it becomes very interesting after the first part. 

Highly recommended to gamers who enjoyed Visual Novels, puzzles, mystery, and psychological horror. Keep in mind that there is a good amount of gore in this game that you can't disable.

92432842.review:
Let me start with this: there is a lot to unpack with this game

a *lot*

For those of you who don't know, or neglected to look into this game for more than 10 seconds, this is the third entry in the zero escape franchise. If you have not played the first two, go play them first (Zero escape: the nonary games). If you don't, this game will not make much sense and you will miss out on many of the "Oh sh** moments". If you have played the first two games, and don't know whether or not to buy this one, I hope that I can supply enough information to help your decision. 

Starting from the top,

------Eating the frog first------
If this is not the first review your reading longer than a paragraph, or you haven’t seen the monstrosity that is about 2 minutes and 9 seconds into the trailer, then you already know one thing. The graphics in this game, are, well, bad. Look, I liked the game, it was fine, but there's no denying that the graphics suck. Graphics never really bothered me, I could play some really questionable-looking games with no problem, but these graphics did break the experience for me from time to time. During most parts (escape rooms, menus, UI, hand-drawn art) the game looks sleek and beautiful, it is only the 3d modeling that is the problem. During most cutscenes like the “oh here is some information about some random 1995 philosophical theory” bits, it’s fine, but during the scenes with a lot of action, emotion, or violence, it really showed. I don’t want to spend to long on this topic, as it has already been done to death, but there is one thing I would like to say that I do not see people talk a lot about when they review this topic. The zero escape team was not originally funded enough money to make a third entry, but fans really pushed them to nonetheless. The team was put in a tight spot, and they really had to cut down on the price for modeling to release the game. Honestly, when it comes down to story, length, or animation, I would want the animation to be the first thing to have a price cut, which is what they did. Plus, zero escape was never really known for its super-realistic art style (Far from it, albeit), and way more known for its stories and characters, so I can understand why they cut this first.

------Murica’ moment------
Gotta love America. Many people may not know this, but the first two games did not sell well at all in Japan, so the devs decided to make this one much more American. This can be good or bad, for those of you peeps who rode the Danganronpa wave over here and want to see your favorite waifus get rolled over by a bulldozer, then this is going to be a little different. The game has a much darker and gritty theme to it and playing it reminded me more of “saw” than anything else. The two main obvious changes to please us westerners are the new cinema mode, and the characters. Let’s start with the cinema mode. This game is like a movie now, they moved away from the “click to progress” style and made all the cutscenes cinematic. They apparently did this because Americans can’t read, but it most definitely feels a lot less like your typical visual novel this way. There are still subtitles, but for those of you who like to read through text really fast (such as myself) are going to struggle a tad here. It’s not that bad, most of the cutscenes are fast and to the point but for longer parts, it can get veeeerrryyy long. As long as your ok with sitting back with some popcorn from time to time, it’s nothing experience-breaking. Second, the characters. Let’s start with the elephant in the room, Carlos. Don’t get me wrong, Carlos is a great character, but I just wanted to talk about him for a bit. First, this dude is pure ye haw redneck Truckin American. Well, he’s not that American, but it is obvious that he was meant to connect to the western audience. I ended up really liking him, but I know many people felt he did not bounce off other characters that well. They also changed many of the other existing characters to be more American as well, which I know many people did not like either. I know all of this may seem trivial, but the reason I bring it up is that this is not your average visual novel, if you came here for the stuff like danganronpa or even the previous zero escapes, you may like it less. If the more western style doesn’t bother you, then it will probably not make a difference to the experience. 

------Decisions decisions, all of them wrong------
Oooohhh yay! A new gimmick! You can’t just pump out the same game 3 times in a row, everyone knows this (Except for EA, apparently) so you gotta toss some new spice into the mix for each entry. This game’s gimmick is the decision game. Everyone once and a while the game will put you in a situation where you have to make a, you guessed it, decision. I won’t say much due to spoiler reasons, but I think this was a really good addition to the game. It made the timeline splits feel much more meaningful than “Oh I went through door A instead of door B”. I know that there were decisions like that in the last game, but most of them were like “oh haha pick the right one or die”. While some of those are like that, many of the decisions lead to a different timeline. The game also does a good job of making your decisions feel impactful, even though you can just go back and change it. I’m not really sure how they do this, but a lot of the time I would really think through my decisions, and the impacts they would cause, even if I could just go back and change them. This may be because (Spoilers unless you played the first two games) they really liked to do the whole time jump thing, so I never really knew what to expect.

------Because 60 minutes wasn’t enough------
Oh, wait, another gimmick? It cannot be! Well, this time it’s the fragments, a less well-received gimmick than the previous ones. Basically, the characters in the game have their memory erased every 90 minutes, so you play the game in “fragments”. This means that every 90 minutes is isolated from the rest of the game, each time the characters wake up dazed and confused, and can only remember the first little bit of the game (no matter how far through they actually are). This means that it’s up to you to think through where you think these things would fall on the timeline as your playing them. *usually* it’s pretty obvious where it is on the timeline because you can just compare the shape of the fragment flow chart with the global flow chart and you can find it. This also means you play the story mostly out of order. There is not exactly a clear path, and you can start (almost) wherever you want to on the timeline. I never really had a problem with it, and made it much easier to find stopping points, but I know a lot of people hated it. I can’t really do much else besides explaining it, because it never really stuck out to me as a big thing, but I do know many people do not like it, so keep that in mind.



------Better than nothing------
If you’ve made it this far, then I’m sure this looks like a lot of negative things, but that’s because I can’t really go over the positive things without major spoilers. The game’s strengths is all in the story. The story is just as good as the previous games and never failed to surprise me with plot twists or funny moments. And I’ll say this, the game is better than nothing. I’m glad that we got an official conclusion to the game, rather than having it hang off at VLR. Yeah, it’s not the best, but endings are hard, and this is one of the better ones I’ve seen. The team didn’t *have* to make this, but they still did, and I feel like they don’t get enough respect for that. The community knew they didn’t have funding, and should have expected lower quality than before, but the writing is still beautiful, and it provides a reasonable and satisfying conclusion to the series.

92119766.review:
This game is trash. Hot trash. The dirtiest, greasiest burger of the VN world. So dirty and greasy that it's... kind of good.

I'll try to cover the four parts of the game that I think are worth discussing. 

1. The format. Unlike the previous instalments where you followed fairly clear, fairly linear timelines, ZTD is presented to the player as a series of chunks or "story fragments" that you have to follow in order to unlock more fragments and, ultimately, endings. It's a fresh-ish approach to the series, matching the experience of the characters, all of whom are forced to wake for 90 minute periods, retaining no memories of previous periods. You also play as three separate teams with no direct contact to one another, which could have been an interesting dynamic were it not for the sheer difficulty of juggling nine sort-of protagonists. And unfortunately, even when you can see the fragments forming into their linear timelines, there is little sense of progress. More often than not, the game feels quite senseless. One thing ZTD does have over 999 and VLR is (some) better dilemmas. Because the format and the timeline branches are freer than in previous games, there are more meaningful and problematic decisions to be made than just "Ally/Betray", "Take/Give this one item" or "Pick a door."

2. To continue that thought, then: the story. ZTD is an incredibly cruel game. Not in the sense of 999 or VLR which required difficult choices and set out clear motives of characters working for the "greater good"; ZTD is, in parts, just torture porn. It's clear that the popularity of DanganRonpa has been an utterly catastrophic influence on the development of this game. Much of the story has no more artistic or narrative merit than the latter Saw films. So if you actually like DR, congratulations, you got a fourth one at ZE's expense. That's not to say it's all bad; you can tell the [spoiler]Diana/Sigma/Phi[/spoiler] branches were written first because they are actually exceptional by the game's standards. They hit the same sweet spot that VLR consistently hit in terms of crazy, stupid, yet fun twists. It is almost solely on this basis that I recommend the game: as an add-on to VLR. (It does also inherit VLR's unfortunate side effect of shitting on 999. [spoiler]Junpei and Akane[/spoiler] are warped almost beyond recognition for much of the game, and ZTD does a sloppy job of trying to explain itself.) Similarly, when the game tries to stand on its own feet, it fails quite drastically. At one point I seriously considered the possibility that the dog might be Zero, because that's how bloody stupid the game was getting. But if you needed closure on VLR, then it's probably worth going through the rest of it anyway. Phi said in VLR, "Not even Jupiter can find a lost opportunity," but if you squint hard enough you can just about find the one in this game.

3. The graphics. Holy shit are they bad. That's not graphics-whorism; they really are awful. The character models look worse than VLR's, and the cutscenes are just clunky, uncanny messes. I guess they thought the VN-format was too anime-ish to be popular (weird given how it tries to emulate DR in so many other places) but I guess nobody told them bad graphics are unpopular too. I don't know too much about the technicalities of 3D modelling, but I have DS games that look better than this. That said, you do kind of get used to it somehow.

4. The escape rooms. They're a mixed bag. I think there are thirteen in all; there were probably two or three that I thought were incredible and some of the best in the series, and then one that was so dull I just followed a walkthrough. The rest I remember as being fairly serviceable puzzles, if a little samey as the series has used up most themes for rooms you could think of (Maybe if there's a fourth game we can get an aquarium escape room? HMU for more details Spike Chunsoft). 999 only had eight rooms in total, and the UI is pretty dated, so ZTD probably has it beat, but in this respect (as in most others) VLR is still king.
