[b] tl;dr: a better use of your time is to just (re)play 999 and VLR as well as AI: The Somnium Files, pretending this game doesn't exist--ignorance is bliss in this case. harsh words, i know (and i don't mean ill-will towards the people themselves who have worked on this game--i hope the best for them); but at the same time, it was how i felt at time of completion and currently--maybe my opinion would change 10 years from now, but i don't expect it to. [/b]

(spoiler joke tl;dr: [spoiler] i wish i could mind hack into a different timeline where this game did not exist. [/spoiler])
---

loved 999 and liked VLR...but i wished this game did not exist. this is a harsh comment, yes. at the same time, it was how i felt about the game at time of completion and it is still how i feel now.

sure, you can find enjoyment in playing this game for ironic reasons, i guess, as some others have done: the voice acting is a little campy and some of the situations the characters are put in can be kind of silly. however, i personally felt completely let down by the game story-wise (especially the twist) and character-wise. Going into detail about it would mean a wall of black text for this review and is better saved for a discussion among fans, so I will just say that it felt weaker in execution relative to 999 and VLR.

in interest of fairness, i remember the puzzles being generally fun: it's been a while since i've played, so the only one i particularly remember fondly at the top of my head is the one that implemented a probability paradox concept, which played into the story as well (skip this text if you don't want to be spoiled: [spoiler] specifically, the one with the monty hall problem [/spoiler]).

overall, though, i feel that (re)playing 999 and VLR would be a better use of your time, pretending this game didn't exist. please don't read this to mean i hate the developer: I don't mean ill-will towards the people who have worked on this game and i hope the best for them (i enjoyed their later game AI: The Somnium Files!).

fun(?) fact: this came out on my birthday. what...a gift?

91431052.review:
The weakest entry in the Zero Escape series, easily. Partly because 999 and VLR are so amazing, so it's hard to live up to that. But also because this game takes such steps backwards. The 3D models are fine enough but the animation is terrible and takes you out of it. Some of the new characters (particularly Eric and Mira) are some of the worst written characters I've encountered in a game and I hated them so much. Some of the returning characters behave uncharacteristically. The story (which is really why you're here) has some good twists and reveals, but pales in comparison to the previous two games. The general flow of the game is really chaotic. It is explained later, but there's not much narrative flow and momentum when scenes are played completely out of order randomly. Just didn't get me invested. 

I do think the puzzles are still pretty good, though -- on par with VLR -- so there's that.

I would probably give this a "neutral" rating if Steam allowed that. There still is good stuff here and the story -- even if not as strong as 999 or VLR -- still is leaps better than most games. It's just unfortunate that after the total complete mind explosions that were 999 and VLR, we get this very anticlimactic ending to the trilogy. Perhaps if those two other games never existed I'd think differently of ZTD, as there still are some good reveals and it has it's moments. But they do, so that's that.

A story-based, exploration/puzzle game w/ TONS of dialog and.... dramatic..... ...... ....... PAUSES!

Pros:
* Well-written plotlines.
* Varied levels and characters.
* Fun puzzles, mostly.

Cons:
* Dialog is... really... SLOW, and then goes... to... dramatic.... ... .... ... ... PAUSES.
* "Skip dialog" functionality can be enabled, but seems to skip all of a char's dialog if it has 2+ sentences and you skip the 1st one.
* Can't resume in the middle of a level, AFAIK. (could be wrong)
* Some puzzles are really annoying (eg: solve an anagram'd phrase into another phrase)
* Some of the characters are... really, really stupid. (eg: Eric still wants [spoiler]Mira, even after she's revealed as a serial killer who's already killed him a cpl times[/spoiler])

Meh:
* Plot is [u]very[/u] confusing until the last 1/3rd of the game.
* Game can seem like it's ignoring your choices - overall, it isn't, and it has a reason that will be revealed... eventually.
* LOOOOONG, due in large part to dialog speed.

TL;DR: If you like a good story, and don't mind a slow game, 7/10 (8/10 on sale); else, skip.

If you loved the first two Zero Escape games this is a good follow up.
Is it kind of cringey, over the top, and absurd? Yes. Does it look awkward with stilted animation? Yes.
But, that's just how this series is. It's a bit of a mess but it's a beautiful mess.
For one, the voice acting is a blast, I love the work the actors put in, they're all pushing themselves to the max for this performance.
They focus on the characters and they are absolutely wonderful (except two). The interactions and relationships are some of the best in the series and it makes everything else come together in an explosion of awkwardness that you need a massive suspension of disbelief in order to accept.
But let's be honest, you already like the first two if you're looking at the third, it's just more of the absurdity that makes Zero Escape great.

NOTICE: This is a spoiler free review for both this game and the entire Zero Escape trilogy. It is still highly recommended, however, that anybody looking to play this game to first play 999: 9 Hours, 9 Persons, 9 Doors and then its sequel, Virtue's Last Reward.

TL;DR: Zero Time Dilemma is a psychological horror visual novel and the third and final game in the Zero Escape Trilogy. It is a gruesome, mind-bending story that does an excellent job in wrapping up all of the loose ends.

Recommended For:
• Zero Escape fans obviously.
• Visual novel/puzzle fanatics.
• Patient deep thinkers.

Not Recommended For:
• Anybody who did not play the first two Zero Escape games.
• Fans looking for something fast-paced.
• People that have a personal vendetta against the anime art style.

Against the odds, Zero Time Dilemma manages to meet the high bar set by its sequels.

This game was supposed to be more brutal than Virtue's Last Reward, but I didn't think that the one getting brutally tortured would be me, the player. 88744976.review:
When I first started playing, this game felt pretty scuffed. Having played the other two Zero Escape games, the fully voiced/animated mostly-unskippable cutscenes were a little jarring, but grew on me very quickly. 

It's very important to note that while the first two games provide some depth to the background of a few characters, this game does a good job of giving you important background details on its own!

If you want a masterfully crafted fragmented story-line and puzzles that make you think outside the bounds of the game itself, please do yourself a favor and give this game a try. You have to scratch deeper than surface level to find the gem beneath, but once there you'll find yourself continuing to chip away to uncover deeper Truth.

My only real advice to anyone giving this a try would be to spread out across the three groups instead of focusing on one group at the start. Eric (Q-Team) is maybe one of the most frustrating characters in gaming but all elements of this game - except the completely unnecessary and barely used jiggle physics - are necessary for its magic to happen!

88640528.review:
[b]Zero Time Dilemma[/b] is the third entry in the Zero Escape trilogy with [b]999[/b] being the first and [b]Virtue's Last Reward[/b] being the second entry respectively.

If you are thinking about playing this game and you haven't played the other two before: please don't. It will confuse you a lot if you haven't played them.

Many people consider [b]Zero Time Dilemma[/b] to be the weakest in the trilogy and I can definitely see why they would say that. However, if you played [b]999[/b] and [b]Virtue's Last Reward[/b] before, you definitely owe it to yourself to play ZTD as well due to it giving you closure on many fronts. It has been a while since I played the other two games but it felt to me as if ZTD had less puzzling than the other two games and more [i]"make a choice and see what happens"[/i] segments. I personally didn't mind that, but I wouldn't be surprised if that were an issue for some people. The chosen art-style or however you want to call it looks very dated and feels somewhat cheap, but to me personally it wasn't that big an issue.

It all boils down to one thing: If you like games with cool stories full of twists, definitely play the entire trilogy. But if you haven't played [b]Zero Escape: The Nonary Games[/b] (the collection of the first two games), stay away from [b]Zero Time Dilemma[/b]. If my review made you curious, get the collection first and start with [b]999[/b].

88558355.review:
Spoilers ahead, somewhat:
It was nice to play. But compared to 999 and VLR it gave me some mixed feelings. 

The Good:
- The plot in itself is intriguing, everyone has their own goals and back story. 
- The system with achronological episodes was refreshing and didn't interrupt the gaming experience.
- The 3d-modells are rather pretty. As long as they don't move.
- The rest of the art style is consistent with the other games of the series.
- You can choose between Japanese and English voice acting. 
- The pairing we've all been waiting for finally gets their shit together. 
- The music is lit as always. The game is just as atmospheric as 999 and VLR.
- It clears up things from VLR. 


The Bad:
- Mental illness ex machina. Why does the murderer murder people? Because murdering is fun! *vomits*
- You like blood? Then this game is for you. 
- The ending? Will certainly be a surprise. This an be a good or a bad thing, depending on how ridiculous you expect the reveal to be. 
- Compared to 999, pseudo-science in here sometimes annoyed me because it felt so ... far-fetched? In 999, young me believed every "scientific" idea explained there. It felt somewhat real, somewhat understandable.
But here, realism is thrown out the window, which is kind of sad. I guess nothing can top 999 after all. ^^'
- Sometimes the riddles were really hard. I mean, yes, they are supposed to be challenging, but sometimes I got stuck in an escape room hysterically clicking everything to then realize that I missed that one exact pixel. Watch out to adapt your cursor speed, pals!
- Akane isn't as smart as she used to be. 
- No Aoi in here. Me very sad. 
- The rough animation and funky standing around and staring into space. But that's just a matter of preference, I guess.

The Ugly:
- The ending was not my piece of cake. at all. When I say that my motives are very complex, I don't need explain them at all.

88378402.review:
I can't understand how people say this is a great series, it's a headache that get's worse with each game, and I only played it through because of Sunken Cost Fallacy. I'm just going to do a general review of the series because I don't want to spend any more time on this damn game than I have to. TL:DR at the bottom. 

Holy shit where do I begin, this game has some promising elements but they all gets drowned out my everything else. It's a fine game at times and frustratingly bad at other times. One of the only consistently  good things I can say about it was the art-style in the first game, and I say first game because they get rid of it in the 2nd and 3rd games for some pretty crappy 3d models, so even that's not consistent, The voice acting is sometimes good, and at other times half-assed. The puzzles are sometimes fun, and at other times tedious, repetitive, and bullshit. The plot is decent at it's best moments, and underwhelming, predictable, full of holes, and boring a lot of the time. The game is filled with so many annoying control-elements and feels like shit to play. 
I can sense that there are some talented individuals that worked on this, and I don't mean to be rude, but these games really took a turn for the worse. I'm only being harsh on this game because I can see some of the good in it and want to hold it to a high-standard, but it just isn't fun in the end. I really hope that AI: The Somnium Files is better than this and I can see their talent shine on it. Go play games like Phoenix Wright or Danganronpa if you are interested in this type of game and haven't played them yet. They have their problems, but are much more enjoyable in the end.


TL:DR: I really want to like this game, and while there are some things I like, I just can't like this series. The controls, graphics, story, voice acting, characters, and puzzles, all are decent at the best times, and horrible at worst. If you want recommendations for other games to play, I recommend Danganronpa and Phoenix Wright. It's not worth getting into this series.

88184102.review:
This is a difficult review, because it has many shortcomings, but I feel like despite that there's still something to be gained from it that is worth it.

Some of the dialogue and interactions are cheesy, or not really interesting. Certain characters have problems and don't really get developed. On the other hand, we have some cool scenes and a very complex plot with major twists.

The biggest shortcoming I say would be the fact the VN format was fully traded for cinematics only, losing agency over the pacing and flow. Adding to that the stiff animations, it isn't really pleasant to watch and I'm thankful that the game doesn't pause when tabbing out. 

The puzzles felt slightly less polished than VLR, but it wasn't too bad.

Setting aside all of it, I think that if you liked 999 and VLR, then you should play it, because it brings closure and some great moments.

87693705.review:
As expected from Spike Chunsoft there are a lot of twists and turns. Sadly, in this occasion, this results in a very complex story that keeps getting more and more convoluted while delivering a somewhat disappointing ending. There is at least one or two endings that still don't make sense to me.
The escape the room parts were great, the puzzles on par with the first game of the series. And don't get me wrong, the story and its branches do have a lot of things going for them, but the resolution doesn't live up to the huge backstory. 
There are big parts of the game, [spoiler] specially the ending, [/spoiler] where it practically abandons the puzzle aspect and is mostly a lot of cut scenes. If you're like me, you've most likely played it in a short span of time, which makes the explanations very repetitive. You can fast forward through them, so it's not an impediment, but it's still cumbersome and takes you a bit out of the narrative if you're constantly having recaps. Long recaps.

All in all, I was left disappointed. Too many hours spent on a hard story to follow, not enough payoff. If you're into escape-the-room games, I'd just go for those sections and stop after the "complete all quests" achievement. If you don't mind being left with some questions un-answered, the story can still be very interesting.

Also mad that Delta says that killing Gab is good news without saying why. 86795182.review:
IMO, the move from 2D to 3D is a major failure. The partial transition to 3d in VLR is bad enough, but clearly they didn't get the memo. 
The use of a 3D engine made this game look and feel MUCH more outdated than its 2D counterparts, despite being fairly more recent. Animations are choppy, expressions are unrealistic, and models are not as well rendered. There's a lot of moon logic moments in escape rooms as well, [spoiler]such as where the TP room requires you to click BELOW the hologram text to enter the secret code with no clear signs whatsoever, [/spoiler] not to mention the clunky controls and no option to rebind keys (as well as lack of basic features such as swapping items without going into the menu screen). 
The structure is, while innovative, full of flaws. Due to the segmented nature, a lot of lengthy expositions are retold over and over again. I don't have to be told that they'll be forced asleep in 90 minutes for every. last. escape room I do. Certain announcements are also heard repeatedly with equally long explanations from Zero each time you play a different team that encounters it, and of course there's no way to skip them. I'd have let it slip if each team actually exhibited any different behaviors/attitudes, but no, they tend to just listen to Zero with barely any notable remarks. This obviously also lends itself to the story's terrible pacing. Often leads don't add up and you have to jump to disparate parts of the story and search aimlessly while extra leads just pile on with no real answers in sight. 
Overall, the story is not absolutely terrible, and you might enjoy it if you are willing to overlook the mechanical and narrative downfalls, but I think your time will be much better spent with just the two previous games (in Zero Escape: The Nonary Games package on Steam).

86588260.review:
So... This game is on absolute crack. A seemingly never-ending flowchart, all-over the place story, questionable concepts...

...And yet I'm recommending it. Why?

Uchikoshi, as a writer/director, has always had my utmost respect, and he still does here for the reason that as out-of-nowhere a lot of things seemed, it made sense because of how he wrote it.

I've seen a lot of complaints about certain 'unrealistic' aspects, but c'mon- if you played the first two games, how "realistic" are you expecting it to be? I think putting some more sci-fi touches to the game made it a bit more investing since it wasn't as interactive as the first two games.

Speaking of interactivity, it's significantly less than 999 and VLR. However, the puzzles that WERE in there were good, and the movie-like aspect actually made me more interested in the plot since i couldn't just click past/skim through dialogue like an idiot.

If you've played the first two games, this one is worth a shot. It clears up a few things from past games and does connect to the other games in a good manner. I've gotten through a decent chunk of the game at the time of writing this and thoroughly believe that, while not the best in the series, it was still a good final hurrah.

86563533.review: This game understands how to build a slowly developing and complex narrative like few things do. It makes good use of the fact that it is a game to tell its story. The sense of humour and well-rounded characters help to invest you in wanting to see how every eventuality plays out. It reminds me of Umineko in terms of style, but is much more interactive and gameplay / puzzle focused.

86398698.review:
A movie disguised as a game, not that I mind it that much. People seem to dislike the art but I genuinely found it good, besides a few of the expressions.

The issue I have with this title is that it lost the essence of the previous titles, and that is: interactivity. All you can do in this one is watch cutscenes, make a few choices you are forced to and play the escape room puzzles. A story told in a non-linear manner, yet not in the best way. Also, since 999 the voice acting has gotten worse and worse. Even Junpei whom I was so impressed with in the first game let me down.

The premise of the story is interesting, the music is great, the escape rooms are just as good as they always are, so if you care about all of these things and like the Zero Escape franchise it wouldn't hurt to finish it. While I feel like they went downhill after the first title some might disagree.

All-in-all, not a bad title, yet I feel like you should play it only if you really care to find out about the ending. I will still recommend it for the work Spike Chunsoft put into this really vast and complex storyline. If you got time to kill, maybe this one's not that bad of an idea.

86054535.review:
[h1]Zero Time Dilemma is both the last game in the Zero Escape franchise, and the worst one[/h1]

I really wanted to like this game. Even though I didn't care for the second one, I [i]loved[/i] the first one, so I was hoping this game would redeem the series in my eyes. It did not. It did just the opposite, in fact.

I'll start by saying the switch from visual novel to animated cutscenes was a poor decision. With VNs, I can go as fast as I want, but with cutscenes I have to [i]sit through[/i] all of them, which was rather annoying. This is made worse by the fact that the 3D models are so, [i]so,[/i] ugly, embarrassingly so. They somehow look even worse than the already ugly models of the last game. I think the cherry on top of what makes me hate the cutscenes though is the lack of escape rooms.

This is a series of games about escape rooms, it's in the title, Zero [i]Escape[/i], but this game does not have enough of them. It has less than both of the last games. This game is about 40% escape rooms, and 60% godoforsaken slow, ugly, cutscenes.

The flowchart is also very hard to follow. With the last two games, you start at the begining of a branch, and you play it until pretty much the end, maybe returning with a password. In this game the branches are split up into a ton of different parts, all of which are played out of order. You might play something at the beginning of one branch, then the end of another, and then the middle of yet another. It makes the story ridiculously hard to follow.

It's also needlessly bloody. The last two games had hardly any blood, just as much as was needed, but this game can be kind of a gorefest at times. Trying to copy Danganronpa yet again it seems.

Speaking of Danganronpa, that speech they give the mastermind at the end? [i]So[/i] corny. It's like every Danganronpa ending combined. They basically said "we're gonna find the truth and make our own future with the power of hope and friendship!"

I also didn't care for the fact they switched from a nonary game to a decision game. The number nine was a key feature to these games, and it feels wrong for it to basically be absent from this one.

If there's one good thing about the game, it's the voice acting. The voice actors are all very talented, and they deserved a better script than this one, because this game's story also leaves little to be desired. Spoiler territory below.

I think the first bad decision is the reveal that [spoiler]Phi is Sigma's daughter. There are two main reasons this is bad, first being that it created a paradox, but the first game had one as well, so I'll let it slide. The main issue is, well, incest. One of my least favorite things about the second game was that Sigma spent a lot of time harassing women because the writers just thought it would be funny (it wasn't). One of those women he would make perverted comments towards was Phi, most notably when he said he wanted to see her in a swimsuit or that joke about making a baby together. Granted, neither Sigma nor the audience knew, but still...eugh. The perving was already unnecessary and gross, but now it's just even moreso. If you're going to reveal two characters are related, maybe [i]don't[/i] do it after having one character be perverted towards the other.[/spoiler]

Another story decision that bothered me was revealing that [spoiler] Delta, the old man and mastermind, was just...there, the whole time. He was just sitting there next to them the whole time and none of them ever mentioned it, nor did they seem uncomfortable with him sitting there while they tear each other to shreds. Also, in the various endings where some of them got out, you're telling me [i]no one[/i] thought to bring him? They wanted to bring the dog but not this other human? This is almost as bad as Sigma somehow not realizing that he's an old man throughout the entirety of the last game.[/spoiler]

Also, we need to talk about [spoiler] the C team force quit box scene. If you don't remember or just don't care about spoilers, it seems like, out of [i]nowhere[/i] Carlos suddenly tries to r//pe Akane. Junpei justifiably beats the snot out of him. It's revealed not long after he did that because he had to get close to both of them so he could whisper in their ears how to avoid the injection, he was never going to hurt Akane, and it was all an act to save them. I [i]hate[/i] this. There were so many ways you could have accomplished this without a r//pe scare. I bet they made it look like Carlos was going to commit one of the most disgusting acts a human can do for the same reason there's all the blood or Diana's abusive husband or Eric's PTSD: shock value, which is gross.[/spoiler]

Speaking of [spoiler] Diana's ex husband and Eric's PTSD, they're very unnecessary, and like I said, just for shock value. You should never throw in something disturbing just to shock the audience, it lacks integrity, treats serious topics with disrespect, and it leaves the story with little value once the shock wears off. Diana has an abusive ex husband that really has no impact on the plot except strengthening her and Sigma's relationship for about five minutes, which is in really poor taste, and Eric has PTSD from that time his abusive father killed his brother when they were kids and forced him to help hide the body. Eric's tragic backstory adds literally nothing to the story. Diana's tragic backstory at least adds a little bit, but Eric's adds [i]nothing.[/i] It could be completely removed and the story would be exactly the same. Other than just making the audience shocked, the only other reason I would assume it's there is to make audiences sympathize with Eric, because he's whiny, petulant, and resorts to violence way too quickly. His constant violence and threats towards Q, a [i]child,[/i] really put me off of his character. He also has a habit of shifting blame when hes clearly at fault, but it seems that that one is a [i]result[/i] of his tragic backstory, because his dad blamed him for his brother's death, so in this case his tragic backstory made him [i]less[/i] sympathetic.[/spoiler]

Overall, only get this game if you're just [i]dying[/i] to know what really happened to cause the events of the second game, or if you just...really liked the second game maybe. But really, you shouldn't waste your money on this.

85645793.review:
I had bought all Zero escape games, and played them in order. The first one was super good, the second one was a huge disappointment, which caused me to want to refund this game (I read quite some negative stuff about this, and the gore/violence was something I didn't want). Couldn't refund, so well, I've let it rest for half a year, and then decided to play it. Needles to say, my expectations were quite low. The game ended up being much better than I anticipated. Especially compared to Virtue's last reward (VLR).

Disadvantages:
- The game is really short. I am a kinda slow player, taking my time examining everything, even then, it took me merely 23 hours to complete the game. Several issues rise up related to this. There are fewer escape rooms, and no "boss battle"/final escape room. Characters develop a bit hastily, expressing secrets quickly, and there isn't much character development to begin with. 
- The game is incredibly fantastical, which makes the story incredible and thus less interesting to me. 999 was so good because it did a good job at making the story credible.
- Escape rooms were generally too dark.
- No animated portraits during escape room interactions made all the conversations there very unemotional and boring because of that.
- For some reason, some characters become nonsensically aggressive/bloodthirsty. The gore/violence (which is lore-wise probably not even needed) was bearable, except for one sequence (you'll know which when playing, so you can prepare yourself a bit).
- I got stuck because I didn't know I had to replay the execution sequence multiple times.

Mixed:
+- The escape room had a very healthy mix of puzzles and click/combine the right things. VLR was too puzzle-heavy for my taste. The general difficulty was moderate to even low. I don't remember resorting to walkthroughs (unlike VLR). This made the experience very smooth. However, the escape rooms did have their issues: the puzzle variety was really low (puzzles got reused multiple times within the same game!). One escape room accidentally made me skip a big portion. Time spend in escape rooms is too low for this game series.
+- The animated scenes are a large improvement compared to VLR. It was easy to get used to, and I actually somewhat liked the style, even if not really detailed. I liked 999's style more though, and I have a small feeling the labor needed to produce these hindered making longer conversations, resulting in the short game it is.

The good things:
+ The game handles the flowcharts much better than VLR with its fragments. The general flow chart is also much better than in VLR.
+ The game is well-constructed, making it not completely random like VLR, where pairings/colors/unlocked rooms/... all felt random. This well-constructed aspect is something it shares with 999.
+ It kept my attention well. Unlike VLR.

As final note: I recommend playing 999 before this, and recommend knowing the story of VLR (through reading or playing) before playing this. One, this spoils a lot from the previous games, two, those games were longer than this one because things were explained better. The explanations are kinda rushed here.

I hope more games like this will be developed!

85428432.review:
Before I start talking about the pros and cons of this game, I think I need to make something clear: I enjoy bad media and making fun of said media with my friends. A perfect example of this is any "game" made by David Cage. When I bought this game on sale, I thought it was going to be like a David Cage experience, completely inept in its execution with the added bonus of what is effectively anime Saw. I was, however, entirely wrong. This game actually had me engaged all the way through.

Pros
The riddles are challenging but most of them one can solve without a guide (when my friend and I played it we only needed a guide once).
Most of the characters are engaging and likable.
The story is very engaging but it is not for everyone (it's my first game in the series).

Cons
Eric is one of the worst characters in all of fiction.
The story is not for everyone; if you do not like stories about time travel and the type of pacing that comes with, you will not like this game. It ain't back to the future.
If you do not like anime, do not buy this game as it has a lot of the cliches common to the medium.
The ending is very open-ended and can be seen as pretty unsatisfying.

All in all, it's a good game and I was pleasantly surprised by this game in an industry that is plagued with a lack of originality and open world games but those are the same thing.

9 out of 10

85267210.review:
The final instalment of the Zero Escape Trilogy. I rated the previous games as 6/10 and 5/10 affairs, decent games but with flaws that drag it down somewhere. For the first, it was the ending that let it down, and for the second the messy complexity of the routes, which made it exhausting to go through, alongside a non-canon finale and again, a poor ending. Still, they are by no means a bad game, I do enjoy them and I have enough interest to shoot on to the finale.

Where the first two (The Nonary games duo) were visual novels with puzzle/escape room elements, this one has fully jumped into the adventure genre. It dispenses with a lot of the visual novel trends, UI, text boxes and so on, enough that even VNDB has denied it classification as a visual novel.

That doesn’t detract from the game though. This is still mind-bending stuff, with a lot of core concepts based in pseudoscience and wild theories that exist in real life. The creators of the game take all the previous themes and run with it. There are a lot of nods and call backs for players of the previous games, in fact, you really shouldn’t be coming anywhere near this without completing the previous two.

This time around, we’re investigating the DCOM’s Mars Simulation – a plot device in the previous game, and here we get to see the full events of the cliff-hanger ending of the second game. Of the cast, there are many familiar faces, people who were involved in the first and second games are here starring as central protagonists for the finale. As is tradition, several people (9) get captured and put in a complex where they are forced to solve puzzles to survive and/or kill each other.

Gameplay is now broken up into cinematic sequences, choices and puzzle rooms. Cinematic sequences are full videos of the characters being put in a situation, with lots of talking, it’s essentially watching a movie, and you need to pay attention to the plot hooks and reveals if you want to piece together the story and the truth. You’ll often get a choice at the end of the cinematic, usually resulting in the death of one or many other people and often setting you down different realities – there’s alternate universes and time stuff going on here, it’s all out there and messes with your head.

Puzzle rooms are the same as IRL escape rooms, similar to the previous two games, they’re not too difficult.

What has changed now though is there are no longer straight-forward ‘routes’ to unlock and progress things on. Now, everything is smashed into ‘fragments’, and you have to pick a fragment and investigate the choices etc within and then work out where the fragment fits in the timeline, i.e. the more traditional ‘routes’. The in-universe explanation for this is that everyone is on memory wiping drugs, so no one knows in what order things are happening. (You could, if you’re so inclined use one of the many chronological order guides out there, although you lose the fun of figuring some things out, you gain in having a more coherent storyline to follow, either approach works. I note that the fragmentation of the routes came under criticism from some fans, I don’t blame them.)

The brilliant thing about this game is you can roll the credits in 10 minutes flat. It’s pretty damn clever, I won't spoil it. The story elements have gone back to being darker and more gruesome, a lot of the deaths pan away from the immediate incident but then proceeds to show the aftermath and they’re not very pleasant. A lot of the puzzles now contain a fairly lethal element to them, similar to the Saw movies.

The story is also fairly serious, and all throughout I found it fairly interesting to go through. The pacing is good, the ending is reasonable and I think it left the series in a good place; a wild journey with lots of mindbending pseudoscience to take to my grave, an enjoyable if flawed trilogy. If they trimmed the second game and upped the ending of the first, I'd say this would swim into my 'best series ever' catalogue, but I think for me, personally it just misses the mark.

If you were lukewarm on the first two, I think the third is definitely worth trying. However, again I might be going against the grain here as I understand that this was a bit of a marmite affair for the initial fans. Still, I'm very glad I tried the series and I definitely will keep an eye out for future works.

84393607.review:
[h1][u]TLDR:[/u][/h1]
Zero Time Dilemma (ZTD) is the third and final game in the Zero Escape series and therefore, to enjoy the game to the fullest, you absolutely need to play the previous two games found in [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/477740/Zero_Escape_The_Nonary_Games/]9 Hours, 9 Persons, 9 Doors and Virtue's Last Reward[/url] to get an understanding of the bigger plot. 

As for the game itself, it is okay but lacks finality and feels like a somewhat rushed project. The puzzles aren't as tough as in VLR but they're pretty decent. The storytelling method is a bit odd in that you have to constantly jump between memory fragments rather than following a single chain of events up to an end or story block like in previous games. The character animations are stiff and janky, there are a lot of blood and gore scenes that appear to be just for shock factor, the game is overall very short to 100%, and[spoiler]the ending is ambiguous and not set in stone[/spoiler]. It's worth playing if you haven't experienced the finale in the series, but you should probably buy it on sale. 

[h1]GENRE:[/h1]
Visual novel, puzzle, sci-fi story follows the events of previous two games in the series

[h1]GAMEPLAY:[/h1]
The game plays out as a visual novel where you, the "observer" of the story, pick fragments of story to play through that are often not connected chronologically. Within these fragments, you play as the protagonist of one of three groups in a specific part of the map where you are trapped in. You get a bunch of exposition before you are faced with some kind of puzzle room that you need to complete in order to escape. Puzzle rooms usually have a gimmick where something needs to be unlocked via a series of actions in the room related to objects contained within the space and specific interactions between them.

At the end of these puzzle rooms, you have to make a choice between two or more different outcomes and whatever choice you pick unlocks new story fragments that follow those choices chronologically in the same time line. In order to "finish" the game, you have to reach the "True ending" by viewing and playing through all the critical story fragments and unlocking certain character actions. 

[h1]GRAPHICS:[/h1]
The visual novel and user interface elements are presented pretty well. The text in dialogue and in menus is legible and navigating between different interfaces like your inventory, the timeline map, and additional resources is intuitive. The visual display leaves something to be desired, though. The game takes place deep underground in a bomb shelter so most of the environments aren't exactly gorgeous sceneries. The character models aren't great mostly because the way everyone is animated is so stiff compared to the presentation using 3D models seen in the previous game, VLR. Also, you can expect lots of bloody scenes in the game and oftentimes bodies are being dismembered so just be aware if you have a weak stomach. 

[h1]STORY:[/h1]
ZTD's story follows the events that occur in VLR, Virtue's Last Reward, and that game establishes so much of the story that there is not enough room to fit that in this review. Basically, finish 999 & VLR and understand that story before diving into ZTD. 

The events of ZTD take place chronologically a few years after 999. A group of 9 people have signed up for to take part in an experiment to simulate an environment where they are all stuck together in a base on Mars. Unbeknownst to them, the experiment becomes something completely different when wake up in prison cells and meet a masked man who introduces himself as Zero. After failing an encounter by luck, he forces all 9 people to play a game called "The Decision Game", where the only way to win is if 6 of those people die. The fates of the 9 people, and basically the fate of humanity, rests with whatever happens in Zero's game.

[h1]STRENGTHS:[/h1]
•Zero Escape games are popular for their puzzles. 999 had some pretty straightforward but decent puzzles, while VLR cranked it up to 100 in the difficulty of some of their locked rooms. ZTD takes it down back to less difficult, but not clearly obvious puzzles. It is always fun to try to figure out the correlation between the various objects lying around the locked rooms and how using them on each other interact to guide you toward the solutions. 

•To its credit, most of the events that occur in ZTD do explain various story gaps that were left at the conclusion of VLR. If you have played the previous games, you will probably be satisfied that most of the burning questions you have are probably answered here.

•Most of the characters are great. Some are reccuring from the previous games, like Junpei, Akane, Phi, and Sigma. The recurring characters are pretty consistent personality-wise with how they were in 999/VLR. 

[h1]WEAKNESSES:[/h1]
•I already mentioned it but, ZTD's graphical presentation of the characters could've been improved. VLR's animations were vastly superior in that character expressions and animations were conveyed much, much better than in ZTD.

•Eric is an insufferable character. Sure, it makes sense why he acts the way he does because of what happened in his past, but he is still a d*ckhead like 80% of the time.

•The story feels way too short to complete and to get 100% in. VLR, the previous game, took a good upwards of 60 hours to complete blind and to reach the "True ending". I 100%ed ZTD in under 20 hours and overall wish the story was longer and a bit more more fleshed out.

•(Regarding the ending)[spoiler]This is one of those games where at the peak moment of a story's conclusion, the camera pans away and doesn't reveal what occurs. Personally, I am not a fan of these endings because for a game's story to be built up so dominantly over two whole games prior to this one, I wanted a more concrete and decisive conclusion of events. The ambiguous nature of this ending just adds to the mind-boggling time-jumping antics of the game where either Carlos did shoot Delta and prevented 6 billion people from dying from Radical-6, or he didn't shoot him and... who knows?[/spoiler]

[h1]NUMERIC SCORE (if you care):[/h1]
6/10

ZTD is an okay conclusion the Zero Escape series. The puzzles are cool, but not as difficult as the ones in VLR. Story gaps are explained for the series but I wanted more from the conclusion.

My 2nd visual novel style game. Imagine Saw as a cartoon, but with parallel worlds and a sci-fi branching story.

It's not perfect as it "cheats" at the end, but it has a decent chunk of twists with foreshadowing and it uses its random access style approach to a nice effect. The flowchart is nice as well, though there are some usability issues with it that made me think my game was bugged (look for ! marks on the flowchart if you can't see any options to progress).

You'll also want a notepad handy. Overall, a good sci-fi thriller mystery that made me care about all but a small group of its characters (and those I wanted to die in a fire).

83758521.review: This game sends off the Zero Escape series in one of the most unsatisfying ways possible. This game is shorter than both it's predecessors, having the least amount of actual escape rooms as well. You'll often find yourself sitting there waiting for characters to discuss things you already know because dialogue advancement is out of your control. The dialogue itself and poor voice acting at times can make it hard to take certain scenes seriously. The game tries to be a Saw movie rather than it's own thing, or even another Zero Escape game. Putting an emphasis on crudely animated violence while taking away many of the puzzles as well as dumbing down many of the characters takes away a lot of the enjoyable aspects the series has. Characters are frustrating both in their writing and overall character designs. The designs are a significant downgrade from past entries, favoring more of a generic ever day look rather than the colorful displays of personality that have been used in the franchise in the past. The animations are laughably bad, especially considering the game was released on the same systems that VLR was, showing that it isn't just hardware restrictions. The game fell into many tropes and annoying twists that made it frustrating to play. It might be better to just make up your own ending for the events after VLR and pretend this entry does not exist. If you want a zero escape game, go replay 999 on mobile, and if you want a saw experience, just go watch this movies instead.

82906900.review:
Zero Time Dilemma is a very hit and miss ending to an overall excellent trilogy. It's definitely the weakest of the three games, but the parts of it that are good are very good. I've played through this one twice now (once on PS Vita and once through steam) and I will say that it is better on the second time through. 

There are a few questionable writing choices made in ZTD, which I'll go through and give my takes on. There will be spoilers ahead, but I won't be spoiling anything major (in this game, the previous games are going to be spoiled heavily here).

Writing Choice 1: Split the group into permanent teams instead of allowing the characters to form their own teams based on restraints (as in 999 and VLR).
Take: This was a worse way to get to know the characters of ZTD. In 999 and VLR you needed to form your own teams for every escape room based on criteria (finding the digital root of the door through math and the bracelets in 999, or matching the colors with the bracelets in VLR), which was how you branched off into the various paths of the game. This worked really well because it forced characters into working together with people they might not have liked, and allowed for the player to avoid characters they were suspicious of. We don't ever really get to see how a lot of the characters might have interacted together directly. We get some inter-team interaction through the messages send via the dog, but I think it would have been really interesting to see how Eric and Mira (new characters to ZTD) would have interacted with Sigma, Phi, Akane and Junpei. 

Writing Choice 2: Changes to Junpei's Character
Take: I think this might be a hot take, but I actually liked Junpei becoming a much darker, jaded person in this one. While 999's Junpei is a much more likeable character, I think him becoming a jaded asshole is more realistic at this point in the story. Akane using him for her own survival and then running away without a word can do that to a person, and I see the Jaded Junpei as a logical middlepoint in his progression into becoming someone like Tenmyouji. It at least makes sense, I've known people who've become jaded over less than what Junpei has gone through. 

Writing Choice 3: Q Team sucks
Take: There isn't a single person who is likeable on Q Team. I'm kind of torn on whether this is bad writing, or very good writing, at least on Eric's part. I get Eric. Not as in I'm a hopeless Simp with nothing to live for outside of chasing someone who is bad for me, but he is and it makes sense. I've seen people like him before, and while he is a total shithead, his backstory works well and he feels like a real person. I think he is supposed to reflect what Junpei might have been like had he accepted Akane's willingness to use him as an instrument instead of becoming a difficult asshole, but that might be me reading too much into this. Mira and Q on the other hand do not feel like real people. Mira feels as if she exists to just do all of the evil things that Zero is unable to do himself. Her motivations are pretty boring (feels like something I might have read about on myspace 15 years ago). She basically serves 2 roles, to do bad things and to act as a foil for Eric and indirectly for Akane. Q is boring, but I can't explain why he's boring without spoiling the true ending.

Writing Choice 4: Sigma didn't change much
Take: The Sigma in ZTD isn't the Sigma we played as in VLR. He is a decades older version of himself from an alternate future, yet he feels very similar to his 22 yearold self from the previous game, although maybe a little less jokey. I was really hoping for a Sigma who felt like an entirely different person, because he is literally 40 years older now than he was before. Interestingly enough, we have 2 former Zeros acting as participants in this Nonary Game, yet they hardly bring any information related to their experience creating Nonary Games. That's super weird. I really wish we got to see a bit more change in how Sigma acts for this one. Akane too, but a lot less time has passed for her so its less disappointing. 

Writing Choice 5: Using new characters as player characters
Take: We play through ZTD as three new characters, Carlos (Arguably the real protagonist), Diana, and Q. This works really well with Carlos and Diana, who work in teams with Akane/Junpei and Sigma/Phi respectively. As I mentioned earlier, it doesn't really work that well with Q, but working 2/3's of the time is still more than half the time so it isn't the end of the world. This was probably a necessity as playing as previously known characters would have taken some of the mystery out of the plot, but in doing so we have lost the mystery of most of the characters. One of the best things about 999 and VLR was slowly learning new things about the characters you were playing the Nonary Game with. In this cast, we have already met 4/9 of the cast. 3/5 of the remaining cast are POV characters who we learn about directly from themselves, meaning the only characters we get to explore outside of POV are Mira and Eric, of whom Eric is the only well well written character. I think the best way to go about a story with this cast would have been to only have 1 POV character (either Carlos or Diana) and have the teams a bit less set in stone, allowing for whoever the POV character would have been to explore the others (plus Mira and Eric) with the player. 

Overall ZTD did a lot of questionable things with the story, but the true ending is a good one that is satisfying but leaves enough for another game. If this is the last it functions fine as the finale, but doesn't guarantee no further sequels. The new characters are very hit or miss, but when they work they work well. The puzzles are a little unreasonable from time to time, but they have always been in Zero Escape, so that isn't anything new. I'd recomend this game if you've played the previous ones, but don't expect something on the game level as 999 or Virtues Last Reward.

Very weird game. The choice is not mine, as the game forces you to backtrack and make ALL the choices. 
Without this, you cannot progress.

Some non-spoiler tips that I wished I knew when I started:
1. Do all options, it's critical.
2. quest room are always solvable, you will never need information from other places
3. Passwords are not always solvable. You might need information from another place. Do keep in mind password as they are given to you, but you can always rewatch old scenes again if needed.
4. Not making a choice (pressing back or letting a timer run out) is also a choice, and in one ocasion I was blocked because I forgot to let a timer run out!
5. When you need to enter a password, and you already saw earilier the clue to it, a hint will pop to let you know where it was. But you will need to find this and write it down, so it might be frustrating. It's best to just write it before hand.
6. There was at least one ocasion that I didn't know what to do, and apparently I had to go to the fragment tree and pick a question mark which became an exclamation mark. Not very intuitive.

This game requires more than a bit of patience, but the plot is intriguing and very much not what it seems at the beginning.

NOTE: I pressed yes on will I recommend the game because I had to make a choice, but I'm on fence regarding recommendation.

81790231.review:
[h1] One Step Forward, Two Steps Back [/h1]

There's no getting around it: the Zero Escape games are a bit messy. The puzzle-based gameplay has always been clunky, character dialogue has always been awkward, and the world is built entirely on a bizarre pseudoscientific foundation. Despite that, the series has managed to tell a truly engaging story that uses the format and structure of a visual novel to subvert the player's expectations at every turn. Zero Time Dilemma makes a half-hearted attempt at resolving some of the series' issues, but it can't quite stick the landing.

First, let's talk about the biggest departure Zero Time Dilemma makes from VLR and 999: the visuals. Rather than a traditional VN perspective, ZTD makes use of fully animated and voiced cutscenes. The character models look great, but the animation is awkward and the lip sync is downright abysmal. I can't deny that actually SEEING the characters move around in more intense situations adds a lot to the experience, but the unskippable nature of the cutscenes also slows the pace of gameplay down to a crawl - there's no way to skip dialogue, and chances are good that the player will finish reading the subtitles long before the characters finish speaking. All in all, I'm okay with this change, but it made for some pretty frustrating moments especially during exposition-heavy scenes.

The second major departure ZTD makes is in its structure. Without going too deep into the overarching narrative, this game breaks away from the standard set by 999 and VLR by splitting the characters up into three smaller groups. These groups never change and rarely interact, and as a result there are far fewer interesting character dynamics to explore. This ends up working in favor of the story, but if you don't like a particular person or group, you'll be forced to engage with them for quite a long time whether you like it or not.

On a positive note, puzzles have received a major facelift and (to my surprise) ended up being the best part of the game. Gone are the horrendous inventory management of 999 and the endless reams of numerical charts and coded files of VLR. ZTD's puzzle rooms are lean, challenging, and thematically appropriate. I have no complaints here.

Finally, a few words about the story: to put it bluntly, it sucks. I loved the world and characters established by the previous games in the series and I was anxious to see how ZTD would wrap things up. Unfortunately, it drops the ball at nearly every turn. The plot feels rushed and unpolished relative to the previous games, and the player is hammered with "twists" that feel more cheap than clever. I don't want to say too much for spoilers' sake, but this is the first time I've ever seen a series finale retroactively create plot holes in previous entries.

I'm going to mark ZTD as recommended because there are a few genuinely exciting aspects of the game. I loved the puzzles, the music is excellent as always, and it's nice to have at least a small amount of closure on the series' larger narrative. Unfortunately, it has a ton of problems, and it'll only MAYBE please fans of the previous games. Give it a try if you're invested in the series, but temper your expectations before diving in.

79619718.review:
I've played the entire Zero Escape series, and let me say, it's good the whole way through. I enjoyed Zero Time Dilemma quite a bit. Was it Virtue's Last Reward or 999? No, not at all. But was it an enjoyable experience? Absolutely. The plot is good, and the characters? Just as interesting as they were in the past games. It really manages to tie in the backstories of so many of the characters together, into a nicely woven tapestry of murder and emotional distress. The writing was good, and there were so many points where the game sent me into a panic over the events that were occurring. C-Team is insanely lovable and has a wonderful dynamic, Q-Team... exists, I suppose, but they're still nice, and D-Team has one of the most emotionally investable backstories in the Zero Escape Franchise. The voice acting was really well done, the puzzle rooms were fun, and, for the most part, the animation was nice. Sure, it was a bit choppy, but as I once saw someone refer to it, 'its hard to keep your eyes open' during some of the more brutal cutscenes. If you're not a fan of watching people get hurt? Might wanna close your eyes and mute your volume, cause there's a lot of murder. Unlike in Virtue's Last Reward, you *Need* to get bad endings to continue. In fact, that's the best advice I could give a new player- get every single bad ending, no matter how much it hurts to get one, and no matter how useless you think it might be. 
My (and most people's) major gripe with the game would be the massive info dump of exposition at the last moment, and how the main antagonist's motives aren't explored too much, but even then, they're still an interesting character. Another one? Nitpicky, sure, but frequently, the lip-syncing of the dialogue doesn't match up, which isn't a huge deal but it's still a little bit irritating.
I'd give Zero Time Dilemma an 7.8/10, personally. A good game overall. Maybe not the best ending for the Zero Escape franchise, but definitely a good addition to it. If you like Phi, Sigma, Junpei, or Akane? You'd be best exploring this game and getting to see how those relationships develop. Have fun!

79579697.review:
This game is a total mess. Absolute insanity from start to finish in terms of story.

BUT, if you just become a passenger to the ridiculousness, it's really enjoyable. There are moments that leave you going "huh?" at a pretty astounding rate, however the game is still packed with fun details, is clearly very thought out, and has characters that you still love to engage with and learn more about.

The complexity of the story is odd. There are some elements- the ones that really pack a punch, which are foreshadowed appropriately from the beginning, have good support and satisfying payoffs, but then there's also a fair share of random ones which seem a bit poorly shunted into the plot last minute. If the game was paced in a more "standard" way, this would probably not be the case. It'd be interesting to see a sort of "director's cut" or re-done edition of this game that follows a consistent storyline, and I definitely think the game could have been executed on a lot better.

That being said, just strap yourself in and enjoy it. The game's fun, play it with some friends so you can holler about whether you're gonna push that big red button, or you can all go ape mode when some crazy shit happens.

79499858.review:
EDIT: Restructured my thoughts on the ending: the game's now "good", not "meh".

In short, I'd say that this is a good game, but a little bit of a middling showing from Uchikoshi (although if "good" is the lowest he dips, that says something): the actual puzzles and individual character moments are enjoyable enough to make the lackluster visual style and strange true ending worth it in my eyes, as long as you brace yourself for (technically) the worst game in the Zero Escape series. However, this is just my gut reaction and my personal opinion, so this is all subject to change.

Also, quick disclaimer: this game, while technically playable on its own, is LEAGUES better and more coherent after playing Zero Escape: The Nonary Games (which you can also get on Steam!). Unlike this game, I can undoubtedly recommend it to just about anyone who likes fantastic storytelling. So go play that first because, regardless of what I say here, you shouldn't play this game until you play The Nonary Games. Cool? Cool.

First, the good. I think the cinematic style actually provides a lot of benefits to the story as a whole over the traditional VN format. It lets the game communicate its more outlandish situations clearly, it lets the expressions of characters (somewhat) give insight into what they're thinking, and it significantly aids the pacing of the game, since it never has to stop to give narration and can substitute it with camera angles and sound effects.

The puzzles are still quite good. The free-camera makes exploration way less janky than in VLR (part of me would've preferred 999's approach still, but this works solidly). I did still have the same problem that I did with the other two games, namely that I often spend ages trying to solve a puzzle because I forgot to check some drawer with the solution inside it (although that's likely just a "me" problem), but they have some clever moments and serve their purpose by stopping the game from becoming stale. Without them, it'd just be a 16-hour movie, and I think that would be hard to sit through. Although there are some dumb moments: I had to smash every item in my inventory with every item in the room to find that iodine solution goes on the potatoes (like, yeah it does in real life, but there was basically no clue pointing me to that without me just knowing that that's a thing. Also, yes that's where it goes, you'll thank me if you get there).

The decisions and scenarios in this game are really enjoyable. They have so, SO much more variety than VLR's or even 999's: the fact that it makes "do you inject yourself with a dangerous serum" a genuinely difficult choice to make speaks to its ability to weave these together. Much like in the other games, the characters will actually analyse the choices they're presented with, which makes them feel more real and fleshed out. One thing I love is how they're presented: some are a simple "pick A or B", but others get you to type stuff out or put you under a timer, with these all adding to the moments and providing more insight into the situation at hand (except the final ending keyboard, because the ending ruins everything, I guess: the fact that I had to guess the twist really isn't like these games, which normally make their twists engaging by proving just how little I knew about them).

I actually didn't find the story and fragment system especially confusing here, at least not until the end (and I'll get to that). As a matter of fact, it was less confusing for me than VLR, because it's designed around said system. The start of a fragment will normally give you the current time and casualties, meaning you can piece together where in the timeline it fits before it gets put on the global time chart and confirms your suspicions (or not, meaning you'll be able to figure out why it goes there, or be excited when you stumble upon the fragment that precedes another you found earlier, where you learn WHY those events happened). Plus, the variety of scenarios in the game meant that, if I got told the casualties, then I could normally pin it to a certain scenario and its relevant info if I'd already seen it, whereas VLR just told me to remember what happens down a certain path with close to zero prompting when it'd been days since I'd touched it. Finally, it doesn't give you any major ending fragments, meaning that you can't spoil yourself on anything early, so all it really does it get you into the mindset of the characters, who are trying to figure out where they are just like you.

Alright, now for the bad. The elephant in the room must be addressed: this game looks pretty rough. The models and environments are alright, but the animation is just atrocious. I get it's a quantity/quality thing, but they should have realised going in that animating such a large game with a non-AAA team would not have been the best idea. As it stands, while it does sufficiently communicate the characters' emotions, it isn't fun to look at. It's something I got used to dealing with, though.

The "true" ending is a bumpy ride. It isn't completely unlike anything from the rest of the games in the series, since some twists are well set up. However, it doesn't really go anywhere and doesn't really relate to any of the hours of content and decisions you just went through: I even had to look up one of the answers to one of the final questions, and even when I had the answer it still didn't make much sense in the moment (for anyone whose already played the game, I'm referring to [spoiler]the true identity of Zero[/spoiler], and I did later see how it made sense, it's just annoying to try to go back and figure out). The game then throws in a bunch of plot elements which, while foreshadowed, don't go anywhere, robs you of the last meaningful choice it could give you (again, SPOILERS but it was [spoiler]whether to shoot Zero or not, which considering the game's emphasis of choice, was weird to just leave hanging[/spoiler]) and then just ends unceremoniously. I was just sitting there, waiting for an end-credits scene because there HAD to be one, and there... sort of was? Some "post-payoff" cinema files get added after the credits, but I didn't find them until ages after the ending because it doesn't tell you they're there. These actually do quite a good job of closing the ending out, and significantly improve my opinion of it, but it's baffling that they're not signalled to you.

If you're curious why I didn't like the big end twist, here's why (and massive spoilers, obviously): [spoiler]it feels so utterly contrived. With most of the other twists, they're built on some assumption that both the player and some of the characters share, which is then shattered: the reveal that the wards were all the same is one such twist, and I like that one. However, the thing that annoys me about this ending is not that "Delta is Zero", that's fine. It's that "Delta was here the whole time, he was just offcamera." It's something everyone except the player knew for no reason. It is technically foreshadowed, but when it happens it's just confusing, because it's foreshadowing you're not supposed to pick up on because it ruins the twist. And if Eric used slightly different wording or called "Q" Sean, the jig would be up.[/spoiler]

Having mused on it, I like this game now. It's got probably the best scenarios in the entire series, some great puzzles and some fun character moments: even the characters who became worse people had realistic and sympathetic reasons for doing so, and I like every character in the game (some I find entertaining even if they aren't good people, which is pretty impressive honestly). But it also has the worst ending in the series: it isn't a slam dunk like 999 or VLR, but still irons out eventually, and the visual style has taken an even further dip from VLR. I still think it's worth a shot though for its better moments. AUD$30 might be too much, though: wait for it to go on sale like I did.

77952342.review:
If you haven't played 999 AND VLR, do *NOT* play this game. This is the third game in a trilogy, and the story is the most important thing about it. Spoilers will ruin it for you. Do not read anything about the game, get the heck out of here, and don't look back until you've gotten the true endings on the aforementioned games. On Steam, 999 and VLR are bundled together as one purchase under "The Nonary Games."

Alright, so continuing now, ZTD has a very interesting storyline and is more in line with VLR than 999 in terms of how it handles the branching paths through the story. However, it can take a little while to get used to the new user interface, and it can be a bit confusing at times. In fact, much of the game, I had no idea where I was starting in the timeline for each path for the team I was playing as. That said, the story was still pretty awesome. Finding out who Zero was wasn't as fun as it was for me in the first two games, but it was fun having four returning 999 and VLR characters! Although they are hard to recognize in the weird new art style, two characters from 999 and two characters from VLR make an enjoyable return. I won't say who they are, though, as it's more fun to gasp as you hear their names in-game and realize who is back.

On the topic of characters, I actually felt like most of the women really could have used more story moments. The lead character you play as on D-Team was only likable for me in like...3 or 4 scenes out of a 20+ hour game filled with scenes. We needed to learn more about her before her best scenes, but didn't. Most of the game, she felt like one of the lesser Telltale's The Walking Dead characters making dumb worried faces and bad decisions, but lacking any real character depth. The character depth is there, but you won't find it until you should have already cared about her, in my opinion.

The female character on C-Team had a secret that the leader - Carlos - REALLY should have heard for the sake of some interesting dialog. I won't say what for sake of spoilers. When you hear the woman's name as she's introduced, you'll probably almost immediately think to yourself "Wow, what if Carlos finds out what she did a year ago?! That could be a really interesting and intense scene." Instead, it never comes up. Sure, it was smart not of the people "in the know" to keep it a secret, but it should have been revealed for sake of drama and tension/mistrust.

I won't say what, but there was one storyline in this game that had me absolutely crying bittersweet tears as it was simply brilliant and wrecked me emotionally. There were a few other fun moments, but wow, the ONE plot thread just destroyed me for a while today.

The gal on Q-Team, named "Mira," is very interesting...but only for maybe an hour and a half or so. After that, the game has kinda given away all her secrets and nothing else ever really comes up about that, nor is any of it ever really resolved. After you complete the game, there are some "epilogue files" in-game that you can read that give you a little bit more information to leave you with (hopefully) less questions than you started with and some level of satisfaction/closure on Mira. She was really getting interesting, but then everything just sort of tapers off and she isn't important anymore.

If you're skimming reviews, you will see the name "Eric" pop up. Eric sucks. Eric is just the worst. He has a couple of good background bits, but oh my word he is pretty despicable in almost everything he says and almost everything he does. He's written alright, and I thought that people were exaggerating about hating Eric and that he wouldn't be that bad, but he's just awful. He didn't ruin the game for me or anything, but that guy was difficult to put up with sometimes.

The voice acting in this game was good, the overall plot was pretty cool, and the puzzles were my favorite in the series. I didn't have to go through the same puzzle room multiple times (*stares daggers at 999*), and the puzzles usually weren't too convoluted (*stares flaming daggers at VLR's pantry*). I used a walkthrough a handful of times, but if I did, it was generally no more than once in any given puzzle room.

Overall, I had a nice time with ZTD. It was a decent conclusion to the Zero Escape series and the 3D animations helped to convey the scenes well. I think they could have done better with the expressions at times, and I certainly had nothing against the 2D stylings of 999 and would have enjoyed 2D with crisp animations just as well. The game concludes without everything feeling resolved and there are supposedly no plans for sequels, so that's a bit of a bummer. I really wish they had brought everything to complete closure with this game, though, because at this point, even if they did make a fourth entry into the Zero Escape series, the science fiction elements have gotten so convoluted and so much stuff is going on that it would be - in my opinion - excessive to go on further. So this was a case where I feel like they should have "quit while they were ahead" and just written the story to have an ending that has more resolution than we get here.

To be fair, though, after how much I loved VLR (except for the puzzles that stomped me), it was going to be difficult to leave me as satisfied with a sequel after it, but I think that the satisfaction of more closure for the characters and the setting might have gone a long way to leave me feeling great about the game. As it stands, it left me feeling a little empty inside. I must say, though, that after having played this series, the Danganronpa trilogy, and the Phoenix Wright trilogy on Steam, I'm really liking stuff in this sort of genre and will be keeping my eyes out for more of its ilk.

Seriously, though, screw Eric.

77648545.review:
As the third and final installment of the Nonary Games, this game does not stay behind regarding the other two. It completes the circle on this over-the-top engaging and amazing storytelling. While the two previous installments had different art style in each but were more on a basis of a visual novel, the third game provides us a dynamic and full view of the space and characters just like any other role-playing game would.
If you aren't aware of the game style, here's a basic rundown: with each decision that they ask you to make the story is different and new information is told (sometimes it's even for the better to have a pen and paper on your side to take notes of some extremely important things). This information will help you further along on the story development and give you some guidance amidst the confusion that sets in everytime a new storyline is shown. Brace yourselves for a lot of exposition and people talking in great length. But it's all worth it in the end because that makes the story engaging and might even get your mind blown! Some puzzles can be a little frustrating at times, in the sense that they turn out all to be rather simple in essence but overthinking can get in the way and complicate it. So try and keep it simple!
