76726631.review:
I completed this game not because it was good, not because the game intrinsically motivated me to do so, but out of obligation. I had purchased this game alongside the Zero Escape collection containing the first two games. I absolutely adored its predecessor VLR and while that game wasn't perfect, the way they executed its concepts and story were phenomenal. I installed this game and played for less than an hour before being so turned off I had to stop playing. I came back two years later, and here we are.

If you enjoyed VLR and are willing to go through a bad game just to find a proper conclusion to the end of VLR's plot (the reason I stuck through this game), do not bother. The answer is in no way satisfying and has some contradictions that are so glaring it destroys the whole point of this entire game existing. If you have other motivations to play, don't believe me, or love seeing models clip and clop more than a race horse then by all means try this game out.

There is some good. The escape rooms were fairly easy but had some good puzzles, overall these were good and sit somewhere between 999's and VLR's. There were some legitimately good story moments, and there was a section leading up to the end that piqued my interest and then kept it and got better as it went on. I cannot believe that achieving such a thing in one segment that lasted no more than 20 minutes is noteworthy but, I may as well mention it.

Presentation is so bad, the models clip, specifically the hair most often. The characters with long hair have it so bad the hair often gyrates rapidly from being so confused. Keep in mind that in gameplay you do not manipulate the models, this is all in cutscenes. The devs knew exactly how these would look, and it is frankly unacceptable. I'm not someone who cares a ton about graphics, but this crosses the line and looks ridiculous and happens far far too often. 

The characters have almost no expression and they keep static expressions as they talk through moments that have actual emotion intended that just doesn't come through. The characters never change expression on camera, they barely move on camera most of the time, if there needs to be any change in pose or facial expression there must be a new camera angle or, worst of all, a jarring cut to the ceiling while sound effects play to INDICATE what action is occurring. Passing out? Cut to the ceiling. Entering or exiting a room? Cut to the ceiling. I hope you  like looking at the ceiling. In one scene, a character is punched and when they hit against the all, they crumple to the ground and this blew my mind. This animation was nothing special, but when I saw that my first reaction was "wait so you DO know how to animate a character falling to the ground". Without spoiling too much, the base premise of the game centers around all the characters waking up and falling back asleep through injections in their watches, so they pass out constantly, yet this wasn't important enough to be given animation?

And i won't get into the story for spoiler purposes just know that, while some moments are good, the game's biggest twists are just... bad. So much of this game is bad, the writing sometimes is just off, the story beats are never GREAT. Sometimes good but rarely great and often bad or terrible. One ending in particular upset me so much because of how important and STUPIDLY it was handled.

Strongly do not recommend. There's some good in this but there's too much wrong and the good isn't so good that it outshines the rest. What's good in this game about its story and situations is never better than the good of the first two games, which also got the rest of the stuff mostly right.

76682254.review:
Spoilers ahead, reader beware!

I suppose after finishing it twice, I have a bit of a better idea about how I want to 'rate' this game. As a fan of the first 2 games (999 and VLR) and after re-playing those 2 as well, I thought this would be nice to give a re-play as well.

But this game is... Ehm... Not as good as it's predecessors. 

The premise is the same; people are stuck inside a facility where they have to do escaperoom-esque kinds of puzzles. Most of the music is the same, some of the sounds are the same and even improved. The voice cast is (as far as I could tell) the same and even some of the puzzles are similar.
But Unlike the previous game(s), the 3 teams are pre-set and those people are stuck with eachother from the get go and through mostly (about 80%) of the game afterwards... And it's rather heavy, depressing and dare I say... Unrewarding.

The start of the game throws you into what you could expect for the rest of the game. You make a choice with all 3 teams and the result is that 1 of the teams dies as a result. Why? Because 6 people need to die in order for the X door to open and if you chose the 'good way out' you can't progress the game.
From there, the game 'begins'. The surviving team(s) find themselves in a puzzle room and need to find their way out... If they can. This is where it gets a little confusing, as you can choose between the 3 teams' perspective whenever you can and not 'every' choice you made earlier is logically carried over.  Most of these stories overlap, but that's only clear near the end, so before that, there's a lot of confusion going on.

So the first puzzle room is completed with only 2 people currently present. During the puzzle, you find limbs from someone's corpse and while the player starts putting 1 and 1 together, the characters act like it's a little creepy. At the end of the puzzle, the corpse belongs to one of their members and the girlfriend does a fake-out. Then after the fake-out, she goes nutzo and attacks the other member of the team. Now the player has 2 options, to defend themselves or to give in to the questioning madness. The end result: another one dies. Later, ofcourse, you find out _why_ that all happened.

The second puzzle, with another team, has you search a room full of antiques, only to result in a standoff between the 3 characters. They have a crossbow, pistol and grenade launcher. I'm not sure that the devs know what a grenade launcher can do, but if you may believe this game, it's a pretty safe weapon. I digress. The end result is: 1 of the 3 dies. There's an 'epilogue' where 1 of the characters goes nutzo and the other one can go bonkers.

The third and the last team, they need to make a choice, either pull the trigger or don't. The end result? You guessed it, another death. But why stop there? Why not make it so that 2, ahhhh 3, get randomly killed out of nowhere? 
Are we starting to see a pattern now?

Almost(!) every one of these rooms has some sort of ultimatum. Yes, it's explained at the end for what reason this was 'needed' but as a player, I became numb to it. There was so much 'shock value' and 'needless deaths' that I stopped caring about the characters. And the characters are actually what made this game 'good' in my first playthrough and 'quite obnoxious' in the second one. 

The characters are a bunch of returning characters from the 999 and VLR games as well as a couple of completely new ones. However... Do some of them act and behave like total monkeys or aliens sometimes. The returning characters are... Doofusses, especially Akane (I already warned about spoilers beforehand). She takes actions that she would never do in both the prequels and I'm not just talking about her randomly going berserk. In one of the endings, she even 'knew' that this would happen, so why is she this dislocated?
The same goes with Phi, normally calm and calculated... Near the end, she takes such a huge risk that she nearly blew everything they had worked on. Why? Then there's Eriku, good god, why people think he's 'relatable' is beyond me. There are arguments to be had that he's already had his mind broken, which only excuses his stupidity for about 5 minutes. In the whole timeline where he meets Diana, Sigma and Carlos, he's not human at all.

So what's happening is, more or less, what the previous 2 games have hinted about. The morphogenic field or SHIFT and whatnot. Transfer consciousness between time and space, but then on a grand scale. All of the puzzles are connected in some variety of way the eventually lead up to several endings. One of the endings leads to the start of VLR, which, I'll admit, was really damn well done. The rest was... Hmmm, I'd compare it to Chaos;Child.
The 'villain' is probably the most annoying  thing about this whole game. First of all, he talks too much, whereas in the previous games, things could be found out by the player instead. Then he talks some more and when you finally meet him... He has superpowers. Namely, the ones where he knows what the contestants are thinking AND can mindcontrol them. His background story is supposed to be tragic, but it felt closer to being... Over the top and unnecessary. 

And that's what this game sort of sums up to in the end. It was needlessly over the top with its deaths, endless talking, barely likable characters and an ending to a plot that felt really underwhelming. 

It's an unsatisfying ending to a trilogy that was otherwise pretty good. I dare even say that this game made the prequels 'void' because of this plot. One could also argue that's to 'conclude' all those games, but... Eh, it doesn't feel like it deserved that deep of a thought. 
It's a garbled mess with a lot of good ideas here and there, then very sloppy execution. I know that a 3rd game wasn't really planned and that there were some issues creating it and it can definitely be found back in the game.

I haven't even talked about the graphics and the animation, because those 2, I feel, can be overlooked. They're definitely not great by any stretch, but as a visual novel'esque style of game? Fine enough.

So why am I recommending it anyway? Hm, because the previous 2 games are great / super good. Sure, there were a lot of things missing / breaking / bugging me about those as well, but at least the story was engaging, interesting and energising. They didn't kill off every character that they could find after someone acted like a neanderthal... And because this game offers some pretty good disclosure on at least 1 of those storylines. Or, should I say, serves as a prequel to those. 
Some of the stories were really intriguing.
The puzzle rooms were hit and miss, mostly average as there's nothing interesting there. Some were too short, some were nonsensical and others were just fun enough. 
The last reason I can think of is because there isn't a 'meh' option. 

I suppose it has more to do with that I _wanted_ to like it, rather than really like it. It's 'okay' entertainment for a while and I like that there is a nod to the previous games... I just really don't like that this is the way the series ended.

76403901.review:
999: Junpei wakes up, player has to escape
VLR: Sigma wakes up,  player has to escape
ZTD: Cast wakes up....coin toss

I'm sorry to say that I did not enjoy this game in the least. So much of what I loved about 999 gets thrown out of the window. The best part about zero escape was without a doubt the escape rooms. There is simply nothing like exploring a room finding objects and racking your brain to solve the puzzle; ZTD was no different in that regard. What I hated the most in VLR was navigating the rooms with the mouse, sometimes when I clicked on the wall or a massive object the characters would begin explaining it when I merely wanted to change the camera. I had absolutely no issue navigating in ZTD. However one thing that I loved about VLR was the gold files you could collect. Every puzzle had two solutions at the end which made clearing them just fun, it made me think in ways I hadn't before. This is replaced with a decision game.

Decision Games are the new gimmick. At various points during the story the characters are forced between two options, clicking one determines which route the story follows similar to the AB games in VLR. But I felt as though there were too many of these games even worse they never felt fun. these "games" always seem to end in character deaths or simply end the current section; to which I would simply restart the decision just to see the bad end.

There are numerous bad ends in this game, too much. It made it impossible to stay attached to the characters. It got to the point where I just stopped caring about them all together. Worst yet, I just ended up laughing at the death scenes just because of how ridiculous they were. In every other game, death meant something it comes out of nowhere emotionally impacting the player, not in this game. Characters die over and over, after every decision game there was a death, heck just to see the entire game you had to make sure to kill off the cast at least once during the second decision (this really frustrated me, as I was literally stuck with nowhere to progress because I didn't think to execute every team, the game never tells you this heck I got every scene meaning I picked both options and still got stuck.)

A big gripe that I had was that the characters just never seemed interesting. Everyone was just bland or annoying. Even the returning characters just felt off. Junpei for example is not the same character from 999. He just feels downgraded to a cynical sometimes meanspirited individual nothing like the character from the first game. Even Akane annoyed the heck out of me with some of her actions just feeling completly out of character.

I honestly wished the game was more linear. You are just presented with different sections and are required to choose one. The biggest problems with this is that I would run into a section that completely spoiled another ruining a potential twist.
Another gripe I had with the story is how confusing it all was. The long winded conversations about science and paradoxes didn't help one bit either.

All in all, I really wanted to like this. I really enjoyed the previous games. just not this one. If you want to play, best to wait for a sale.

75605289.review:
God, what a horrible, absolutely atrocious game. There's literally nothing good about it and I say it as a fan of the first two - this one is just a disappointment and a waste of your money.
- The graphics are TERRIBLE. The 3d models are seriously only good for one thing and it's to laugh at them and their convulsions as they try to convey deep emotions and suffering but only make you suffer instead.
- The characters are incredibly effing boring, especially the new ones. There's nothing deep or interesting about them that would make you care about their fates, the fact that they die over and over again doesn't help. You just get used to everyone dying all the time so you couldn't care less when they die again - not a good thing for a game. The old characters are just shadows of their former selfs, they're so much worse; Akane is even more infuriating (I didn't know it was even possible), Junpei has lost all of his brain cells and character consistency and Sigma is neither the hilarious himbo that I've come to love nor the serious work-obsessed scientist that Kyle described in VLR. Phi is tolerable, I guess, but she's dead for the most parts of the game somehow. I don't remember much of her.
- The story is literally nonexistent. This random cutscenes system messes with the story continuity a lot, and I mean A LOT. There's no plot to the game until you get to the endings and you spoil yourself stuff all the time by playing scenes out of order. Not fun.
- The puzzles are so dumb sometimes. The fuck kinda question in a video game requires you to answer 'I don't know'?????????????? pleaseeeeeee end my sufferingggg
- All the stuff that was promised by Uchikoshi in interviews - info on Light and Aoi's fates, Kyle and more that he said would be in this game? Not present. Don't even bother looking. Which is such a huge shame because this game could've explored them deeper (esp Kyle) but instead chose to create new characters with no personality whatsoever.
- Whew boy, don't even get me STARTED on those plot twists. I felt genuinely offended by how stupid the writers thought I was. These twists are partly disturbing and partly idiotic, they wouldn't work in any logical universe. The plot holes are so enormous that you can see the writers laughing at you through them. 
Truly, it's fascinating how this game manages to be an actual abomination in every single way possible. I'm honestly SO angry at it, because I paid money for it and I really wanted it to be as good as the first two. And it had SO much potential. It easily could have been incredible - make it a visual novel with traditional 2D art, get rid of the random cutscene system, change Sigma and Junpei's characters to be more consistent with previous games, throw the fucking [spoiler]twins plot twist and Delta reveal[/spoiler] in the trash, bring back Kyle, Aoi and Light to develop their characters and BOOM you got yourself another banger. Sadly, this game preferred to focus on being horrible. Really, it belongs in the garbage. Please do yourself a favour and don't buy ZTD. Even if you're rich and just want to laugh at it, please don't. It's not even funny in its terribleness. Seriously. Don't. It's just. BAD.

74963119.review:
Like the other two titles in the series, this entire game is a thought experiment predicated on a designer who's kind of an idiot misunderstanding a scientific fact and then having characters argue about the existential meaning of that misunderstanding. 

To be clear, I don't mind if games are based on fanciful ideas or alternate universes where basic principles of reality are different from those in the real world. The issue is that Kotaro Uchikoshi seems to believe each of his mistaken theories are real philosophical conundrums, and then devises a game around literal HOURS of characters debating and discussing the false principle as if it were true; devoting heartfelt, soul-searching questioning of the universe to it. These arguments are not something the player has control over, you basically have to listen to Uchikoshi argue with himself and then you get to solve a puzzle in between chapters.

It's boring and frankly embarrassing, like watching two stoners argue about whether they both see the same thing when they look at  the color blue, dude?! Or listening to two nerds argue about how fast the Millennium Falcon can go. Imagine a videogame story devoted not to Batman fighting Superman, but to some characters DEBATING WHETHER BATMAN OR SUPERMAN IS STRONGER for the entire 12 hour playtime.

This game's discussions of theory are based on a misunderstanding of simple probability, which is embarrassing, and also relies on misrepresentation of multiple mental illnesses that are either incredibly uneducated, or incredibly offensive.

If dense pseudoscientific dialogue translated from another language is your jam, then this game is for you. You will get HOURS UPON HOURS of a Japanese high-school-philosopher's thoughts about the universe in this trilogy. If not, these games will be torture. Nonsense can be the basis of a fun game. Reading a designer's monologue about nonsense is not.

It's a terrible shame because the puzzle parts are actually better in this installment than in either of the previous two. But they're only about 25% of your play time, and the rest is an infuriating, irritating, idiotic slog to wade through. Can't recommend.

73624510.review:
Zero Time Dilemma (ZTD) es el juego final de la trilogía de Zero Escape, que incluye 9 Hours, 9 Persons, 9 Doors (999) y Virtue Last Reward (VLR) . Por lo que es altamente recomendable jugar los juegos anteriores en el orden correcto (999>VLR>ZTD). Esta trilogía de juegos consiste en que 9 jugadores, por diversos motivos, quedan atrapados en un lugar y deben resolver acertijos y evitar morir en el intento. 

Gráficos: A diferencia de los dos juegos anteriores, no es una novela visual, sino que los creadores optaron por animar las escenas, con resultados mixtos. Los modelos en sí no están mal pero la animación es un tanto deficiente, el movimiento de labios no está tan bien sincronizado (más notorio en el doblaje al inglés, recomiendo por ello jugar con idioma japonés) y la animación es un tanto tosca. Los fondos en cambio son bastante detallados. 

Sonido: El OST es básicamente remixes de juegos anteriores y las voces (al menos del doblaje japonés, que es el que jugué) son bastante buenas. No hay mucho que decir acá.

Gameplay: A diferencia de 999, que se basaba en la raiz digital (suma de dígitos de un número) y VLR, que se basaba en el "Dilema del Prisionero", ZTD se basa en "Decisiones" y como éstas te afectan no sólo a tí sino a los otros equipos. Los puzzles tienen una dificultad intermedia, sin ser tan obvios como en 999 ni tan difíciles como en VLR y eran bastante ingeniosos en algunas ocasiones (hay uno en donde tienes que rotar las paredes de un cuarto, fue bastante innovador). De ahí si es un poco tedioso el hecho de tener que soplarte la escena animada (teniendo en cuenta la calidad de las animaciones) antes de progresar en la historia. 

Personajes: Un punto un poco flaco son los personajes nuevos. De todos ellos, la única que tuvo un poco más de desarrollo fue Diana y a pesar de sus defectos, sentías que era una persona real, no un personaje en dos dimensiones. Eric es bastante odioso, Carlos es algo plano y Mira, si bien tenía un concepto interesante, no se le desarrolla mucho. El niño es también bastante olvidable. Regresan personajes de juegos anteriores como Sigma, Phi, Akane y Junpei. Los dos primeros, bastante parecidos a como salían en VLR (sobre todo Phi) pero es notorio el cambio en Akane y Junpei, así que si los amaste en 999, puede que los odies aquí. A mi personalmente me encantó Junpei, pero muchos fans se quejaron sobre ellos dos. "Zero" me parece un buen antagonista, pero siento que le faltó más profundidad y tenían para explotar más su historia.

Historia: busca parchar los huecos entre 999 y VLR pero en algunas ocasiones sientes que más te confunde que otra cosa. A ratos, parece que la única ruta bien desarrollada es la de Diana y las demás están de relleno. Leí que el director sólo estuvo involucrado en esta ruta, lo que puede explicar ello. El hecho de saltar entre diferentes puntos de vista también puede ser algo confuso, sobre todo si tienes flashbacks de eventos que no deberías conocer. Es recomendable NO averiguar las contraseñas si no te las dicen explícitamente en el juego sino te puedes terminar spoileando. 

A pesar de ello, si te gustó 999 y/o VLR, es una buena opción. Hay que tener en cuenta también que este juego casi no sale por motivos de presupuesto y bajas ventas, por lo que hay que tener en cuenta esto a la hora de hacer un review. Personalmente le doy un 7/10, no está mal para pasar el rato y tiene algunos momentos buenos, pero pudo haber estado mejor.

73594217.review:
Zero Time Dilemma is an extremely boring and aggravating series finale to an otherwise pretty solid trilogy of puzzle games. Filled with annoying new characters with terrible twists, it's best to just look up a plot summary if you like Zero Escape this much. 

Abandoning the first person perspective for a more abstract story involving 3 parties, ZTD somehow manages to fail at the fundamental level to remain interesting after the exciting climax to Virtue's Last Reward. Constantly switching perspectives after literal "fragments," You wake with your team to the typical locked room puzzle with a new mechanic- "decision time," a frantic scenario in which a the protagonist must choose to act in a certain way in the fragments conclusion. If you picked right, you find yourself losing consciousness with your squad as you fall to the ground, and await your next challenge. You might be able to guess how the characters get around this loss in memory...  Due to a lack of nuance in buildup to these portions of the game, the first half or so becomes quite redundant as you pick choice after choice, sitting through awfully shock-value consequences that prove to be mind-numbing after the first batch of fragments. The new cast of characters come off (and stay as mostly) as super bland- even the returning cast comes off as super uncharismatic. Many character arcs are rushed or, in the case of one, arguably completely unfinished, and developments in the story read as pure fanfiction honestly, I cannot believe some of these choices made it past the drawing board. It's absolutely, unequivocally, the worst story in the trilogy- probably the worst narrative out of the whole Spike Chunsoft catalogue (that i've played).

Virtue's Last Reward, the adventure preceeding this one, is quite solid narratively, but is known for its... less than stellar presentation. Part of it is fault to the hardware of the 3DS, but it is generally somewhat unattractive to the eye. Surprised as I was, this game's presentation may be even uglier? The character models look fine, but the actual animations themselves are ridiculously whiplash, actively ruining the potential sincerity any point in the game could have. It's a little funny at first- seeing the strange hand gestures Q makes or the or the awkward mechanical prowl of Gab, but it gets pretty unfunny around midgame. It's almost like watching an old random Garry's Mod movie on YouTube without any of the familiar frenzied energy- or any punchline really. At least like, 95% of the shots in this game feature this slowwww crawlllll across someones profile while they explain some mathematics/psychology/philosphy concept, with little charm any sort of execution. A surprising blow to this game's atmosphere was the very subpar voice acting this time around. 999 and VLR both had relatively strong dubs, but ZTD once again showcases its mediocrity with pretty poor performances all around. Carlos and Mira sound particularly dead, but I was super surprised to hear Phi sound really phoned in, especially after VLR. The music is pretty uninteresting too. mostly consisting of some tracks from older games with added drums. 

The gameplay is the only part of ZTD that doesn't completely blow. Puzzles aren't difficult, but are somewhat stimulating depending on the room. My favorite is definitely the "hammer" room (I think you'll know when you get to it). While not annoying, "Decision Time" could have been expanded upon. A good chunk of the time it's glorified "enter password" or "which option will not kill you". Without elaborating, it's VERY SUSPECT in some portions of the game you do not decide on anything. 

Passable gameplay does not save ZTD from a rushed storyline with unsuccessful immersion and terrible plotpoints. Sadly, ZTD was made on a bit of a budget- with proper funding, this likely would have been a fine entry to the series, but its soaked in issues from every corner. Significant overhaul of many ideas/characters should have been accomplished for this game to soar. You are better off with the first two.

3/10

73544835.review:
I loved this game. To be frank, I played the two prequels a week after so the story was cohesive and smooth as I played, but having some characters from past games and some new ones, tied with old and new elements of both the puzzles and stories, makes for one hell of a game.

I was lost at the beginning, as this game runs differently. Instead of a straight story path, you play sections of the game. You do not know where you are in the story, nor do you really understand what is happening. About 10 hours in however, I realized the true purpose of the game and it all made sense. If you knew what was happening, the twists later in the game would be dull, boring, nothing to write home about.

This game closes the trilogy with very few open ends, and I highly recommend this game and the two prequels to anyone who is interested in story based puzzle games. All of the games were worth every cent and second.

A série como um todo deve ser jogada por qualquer pessoa que possua curiosidade, já que a forma que a história é contada te mantém entretido durante todo o tempo, mas jamais comece por aqui.

What you have here, is a very well built, very complex in nature scenario, that definetely deserves an appreciation. Even though, the way they hid the information and are slowly trying to uncover it for us is sometimes frustrating, it's well worth the time you put in this game. ZTD might be a mixed bag, but it wanted to cover every plot hole there is in the whole franchise (which is overall 60-70 hours to complete), [spoiler] even if it would be aliens. [/spoiler] 

Usually, you get treated with new things from the story and you're happy about it, but at some point it just becomes dull. That's what happened with many who left this game a negative or a mixed review. And I can't blame them, since it was the same for me. You would think that the game just can keep on building up the interest to it but that's not the case. You will become overfed with new bits of info to a point, when you just start to ignore them. That's where you should probably stop, relax, rethink the current state of the story up to this point and then continue on playing.

If you wanted to start your way into "Visual novels" section, Spike Chunsoft games, and especially, "Zero Escape" might be a great way to do so. I'm pretty sure, that stories in these games can be interesting to most people of Steam community. You should definetely try it, if you never did before. It's a ride.

Was the story confusing? Hell yeah. Keep forgetting which scene belongs to which route. Hmm, I hate being forced to decide between recommend or not, but hey, it's in theme...
So I came in blind, after loving 999 and wading through VLR, and you can imagine the hype! The conclusion of the story, all is revealed, etc.
Except it's really not.
I guess it was to be expected: with the story Uchikoshi set until then, nothing short of magic should have been brought up to somehow "conclude". 
I'm not gonna lie, a couple of times he got me good with those plot twists (classic "no way, what??" stuff), but I'd describe the story overall as a castle of cards: good to look at, but very, VERY fragile. 
Plot points are weak, reasoning is weak, some things are obviously super forced to coincide with previous games, and the "anyway, you ever heard of [RANDOM THOUGHT EXPERIMENT]?" moments are back full swing; magic (for lack of spoilery words) objects appear with no context (probably sequelhook), and so on.
What I absolutely abhor is the art style of the game: they altered so much from the original characters, they not even look the same (the game had to tell me who's who) and from start to finish the cell-shaded manually animated thing made me either puke or bust in laughter at the uncomfortably janky long close-ups and dutch-angles.
Really disgusting, at least in VLR they had the portability excuse; if they didn't had money for mocap then just stick with 2D, like 999 (whatever).
Summing up: passable game sections, solid frame, but very botched execution. Still, if you've come this far with the story, you may as well pick it up for the couple of good moments inside.

69800037.review:
[I]Zero Escape: Zero Time Dilemma[/I] is the final part of the [I]Zero Escape[/I] trilogy. The first two parts, [I]Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors[/I] and [I]Virtue’s Last Reward[/I], were re-released as [I]Zero Escape: The Nonary Games[/I], [URL=https://steamcommunity.com/id/CharlieLima79/recommended/477740/]which I reviewed recently[/URL]. [I]ZTD[/I] was designed so that players without any experience with [I]999[/I] and [I]VLR[/I] can still enjoy it. However, I highly recommend you to play [I]The Nonary Games[/I] first so that you can understand the narrative of [I]ZTD[/I] better, and to appreciate the game’s nuances and references.

Main characters from [I]The Nonary Games[/I] -- Junpei, Akane, Sigma and Phi -- return in [I]ZTD[/I], only this time they are supporting cast to three new protagonists, Carlos, Diana and a mysterious boy. Despite that, Junpei, Akane, Sigma and Phi remain to be important characters, as their pasts and futures play a huge part in the engaging, convoluted story. Thankfully then, [I]ZTD[/I] features fully-voiced cinematics instead of visual novel reading, allowing creator Kotaro Uchikoshi to show, rather than tell us (verbosely), what’s happening.

Don’t get me wrong, I appreciate the visual novel roots of [I]The Nonary Games[/I]; yet, the transition to cinematics truly works in [I]ZTD[/I]’s favour. In [I]The Nonary Games[/I], there was so much reading of repeated text and scenes that it bogged the games down at times. The use of cutscenes, combined with some editing, and slight variations in cinematography and photography, allow [I]ZTD[/I] to move along at a better pace. The cinematography and photography also help evoke suspense, shock and terror.

In [I]ZTD[/I], our protagonists find themselves trapped in a mysterious facility filled with escape room puzzles. This part of the game isn’t much different from [I]The Nonary Games[/I], and many of the 13 featured puzzles are fun. My favourites are the ones in the Pod Room and the Healing Room, because they make use of the game’s new graphics technology. They also stand out amongst others because you to do more than just “find/pick this up and use it on that” in those puzzles.

To differentiate itself from its predecessors, [I]ZTD[/I] also includes Decision Games, in which you have to make one of two or few possible, often difficult, choices. Your decision will have an impact on how the narrative unfolds, inviting you to try out different responses. As a result, the story in [I]ZTD[/I] is presented in an expectedly non-linear and intentionally fragmented manner. While this may seem like a flaw on the surface, I can assure you that this style of storytelling is integral to the story, and adds to the suspense and mystique.

To reference a key element of the game, the “snail” that derails [I]ZTD[/I] from achieving perfection, however excellent it is, is the character animation. It’s disappointing to see the game falling short in this area, given its full transition from visual novel to graphic adventure genre. First, there’re slight inconsistencies in character designs. The styles in which Junpei, Akane, Sigma, Phi, Carlos and Diana are drawn do not seem complement each other completely. When you put all these characters next to the antagonist, you’d notice the differences even more.

Then there’re Mira and Eric, two new characters to the [I]Zero Escape[/I] trilogy. Of all the characters, they look most out of place with their dead eyed appearances. (Perhaps this was intentionally done from a narrative perspective.) Combined with all characters’ inadequate facial animations for emoting (including limited, if not absence of, eyebrow movements), their general wooden expressions, the very poor lip-syncing to English voiceovers, and the small number of character stances and movements, I felt like I was watching marionettes acting out scenes at times. If only the developers had more time and money to fine-tune the animations...“Life is truly unfair, don’t you think?”

The fact that the poor character animation didn’t deter my enjoyment of [I]ZTD[/I] goes to show the game’s strengths in escape puzzle/Decision Game presentations, as well as in storytelling. Sure, story of [I]ZTD[/I] is even more outrageous and convoluted than that of [I]VLR[/I], but it’s very entertaining overall. Honestly, after all the science fiction wackiness in [I]VLR[/I], I’d have been surprised if [I]ZTD[/I] is more grounded and restrained.

I’d be lying if I said I know just how wacky the story of the [I]Zero Escape[/I] trilogy would become right after playing [I]999[/I]. No, the [I]Zero Escape[/I] trilogy takes you to places you’d not imagine, especially given its humble visual novel roots. [I]ZTD[/I] is a good conclusion to the [I]Zero Escape[/I] trilogy, and I highly recommend it. As I stated in my introduction, I do feel that this game is best enjoyed if you have played [I]999[/I] and [I]VLR[/I]. If possible, play all these three games back to back as I did so you can get a complete, uninterrupted narrative experience.

69793822.review:
Zero Time Dilemma is a very polarizing entry in the Zero Escape series. Some think it ruined the story and the characters with a drop in writing, and others think it's still amazing as Zero Escape usually is. 

I too thought it was somewhat weak on my first playthrough, the non-chronological order of fragments that can be played in any order doesn't do the game a lot of favours. On a second playthrough, I followed a guide so that I could play the fragments in the order that they happen, and this has given me a lot more appreciation for the game. Even if the game is intended to be played non-chronologically, I think everything works better if it's played in the order events happen. I wouldn't recommend that someone on their first playthrough follow a guide, it's important to get the intended experience first, but after a few months I'd recommend to everybody that they do a chronological playthrough of the game. 

The writing is still great, on par with 999 and Virtue's Last Reward in my opinion, and the puzzles are still designed incredibly well. The story has some strange asspulls, but they're not so major as to ruin the experience. If you played 999 and Virtue's Last Reward, you must play Zero Time Dilemma to tie up the story and see if you think it's another masterpiece, or something not quite on-par.

In this one, for whatever reason, the game gave me the impression that I should try all permutations of a fragment of the story before trying to go down one particular path. In this way, I ended up with an overwhelming amount of story fragments after the first big decision in the game. It all ended up coming together and making sense in the end anyway, but it was problematic at times (There were times where I had to revisit chapters I had already completed to advance the story just to "shake something loose). Again, I'm not really sure why I chose to play it this way when it wasn't the way I played the first two. It could have been sheer stupidity on my part or the way the game was designed, I'm not sure.

Overall, I didn't enjoy it as much as I did Virtue's Last Reward, but it was still a strong entry in the series.

The art style has been changed (yet again...) to cell-shaded anime-inspired 3D models, and it doesn't really fit the game at all in my opinion. It completely goes against the 2 previous games (which already had different art styles). The animation is terrible, it makes the cutscenes look really awkward and the characters look like puppeted mannequins.

These do NOT feel like the characters you know. 3 out of the 5 new characters are very badly written, and feel like they have no real reason to be in the story. 2 of them are so completely unlikable AND useless that they make 1/3 of the game almost unbearable for me to get through. 69521220.review:
[h1]An Interestingly Bizarre and Fun, Yet Flawed Final Entry in the Series[/h1]

999 was a fantastic game, and one of the best visual novels I've played for its unique atmosphere, memorable characters and twisted story, and fun puzzles. It's an experience that's almost flawless, with the exception of hit and miss voice acting and a few questions not being answered. VLR on the other hand, I didn't enjoy as much. The graphics were just ugly, the characters weren't as memorable (except Phi. She's my favorite character in the whole series), and it just drags on for far too long (I put over 40 hours into it, and I was just done with it when I finished) thanks to repetition, having so many endings, and those map traversal moments. While I still think the story's great and the puzzle rooms are pretty fun, it's my least favorite in the series.

Yes, I think ZTD is a better experience than VLR. While I do think it's the weakest in terms of story and such, I had more fun.

Zero Time Dilemma is the most interesting in terms of what it wants to do. There are nine people (3 in each team in different wards. C-Team, Q-Team, and D-Team) put into a bomb shelter by the villain known as "Zero II." He wants everybody to play a game, that game is to kill if they want to escape. Kill six people, at the very least. You'll be switching between the three teams and making the choices of the leader of said team in order to find out what's going on, and who this Zero is, how to get out safely, along with other mysteries.

While I do think the story is fine, it's not great. Every now and then, plot points can be downright stupid or nonsensical, a twist that comes out of left field and might not be explained. Along with the animation (which I will get to) and Saw-like violence (seriously, they really upped the violence in this game), you just can't help but not take it seriously and laugh. There still is some great dialogue, emotional moments, interesting mysteries, and plot points and clever references to 999 and VLR that will click. The pacing is also *much* better than in VLR. The ending, without spoilers, was weak however. It gives off the feeling that they ran out of budget and didn't know how to wrap thing up, which is a bummer.

The cast is the weakest in the series, although not bad. We have Jumpei and Akane from 999, and Sigma and Phi from VLR; the rest are new. Carlos being the best new character, Phi being just as enjoyable as ever, Q and Diana being great additions, the rest don't leave that much of an impression on me. Eric is the most unlikable character in the whole series, Mira is uninteresting, while Jumpei and Akane not being as likable as in 999. Sigma's character just feels off. 

The team's stories are told through cutscenes, and it's very different than last two games. To put it in a simple way, imagine having the text set to "auto" in the visual novel sections while it's fully animated. In my opinion, it's an interesting direction to take, but it comes with one of the biggest problems the game has: the presentation and animation. While I do think the models look much better than in VLR (although Akane and Junpei look too different), the environments weren't given the same treatment. The game looks fine overall, and effects do look solid, but the animations are just flat out awful. They're janky, stiff, feels like they're trying to cut as many corners as possible (shaking the camera while zoomed onto a character's face, cutaways if somebody falls over or gets attacked). There were a few times I saw errors, like a character teleporting when the screen fades. The movement of the characters' hair freaks out at times, the lip-sync is awful. Despite all of this however, there is some odd charm to it, and it makes dumb moments even more hilarious at times. They don't get in the way once you get use to them.

The voice acting in this game is great! The animation does hurt some performances, but overall, I have nothing to complain about. The soundtrack is pretty enjoyable and fits scenes pretty well, although I wish they didn't reuse many songs from 999 and VLR. The new songs are still good though! The sound mixing on the other hand is rough, and I highly recommend turning down the music and upping the voice acting by a couple of dots.

The gameplay... I don't have much to say. You still have the escape rooms and moments of choosing the path you want to go. The rest, you're watching cutscenes while trying to piece the story together. I'd say the escape rooms are pretty fun in this, even if some puzzles are reused a few times. The movement while looking around in the room is a big step up from VLR, and it's the same as the first two games: you're in a room, find a way out. 

The biggest change in gameplay is that instead of a flowchart where you go from the start of the path to an ending, you now have "fragments." Each team have multiple fragments you can choose from, and they resemble a small part of that team's story. They aren't in order, so if you find one interesting and it's unlocked, you can do it. If you finish that fragment, it's added onto the main flowchart to show which time it took place. It works very well in my opinion, and having it nonlinear like this is refreshing. I do have a gripe that [spoiler]you have get all teams executed in the voting segment if you want to finish the game,[/spoiler] but overall, I like it.

In conclusion, I'd say this is a good game. The puzzle rooms are pretty enjoyable, the plot is interesting and has good pacing, the flow chart is refreshing, and many of the characters are good. But this is a flawed game, and you're not going to get the quality of storytelling 999 and VLR had. Personally, I think this experience is much better than VLR since like I said: the pacing is much better and repetition occurs much less. 

This could've been better, but for what it is, I think it's worth your time. It's an enjoyable game.

[b]SCORE: 7/10[/b]

69459081.review:
This was one of the more interesting games which I have played in a long time. The bulk of the gameplay is escape room style where you solve puzzles to complete the objective of the moment. However, the interesting part of the game are the "decisions" you make when those are concluded, often involving tough moral choices. It also has a unique element of how the game is divided into fragments which you can go back and do them again with different effects. The voice acting is done very well and the pacing and style of the story is compelling. I highly recommend this game if you like to  enjoy the story more than gameplay.

Graphics: **** (The graphics are designed for this type of gameplay, but they're not "beautifully" rendered like Skyrim or something)
Story: ***** (fantastic story that is very interesting to see unfurl)
Gameplay: *** (the escape room element is integrated into the story, and does pretty well staying fresh the whole time)
Sound: *** (voice acting is very good and works well. You'll need to turn the SFX and score down significantly because it defaults to being overpowering).
Overal: **** Would very much recommend if you like story and that is the most important element. 

Playtime for me: 22 hours
Value at $20: *** (I'd like to see it at $10, or even $15, but it's still a decent value at $20).

69097944.review:
I bought this game with very little knowledge about it. I believe I thought it to be the original game of a DS game I had never played, and it reminded me of Dangaronpa with the sudden introduction of characters I had never seen, some of which I couldn't tell apart on my first play. It was all very confusing to me, the bizarre cutscenes, minimally expressive character models and animation, the English voicing sounded so strange to me I found it more enjoyable to just listen to the Japanese and read subtitles, I even WON the game with the first decision I could make (about 20 min in, I think, I'll talk about this later). But because I made that (seemingly correct) choice, I was shoved into the menu UI without any explanation. This plague doctor creep flipped a coin, I apparently escaped this game, without ever hearing what it entailed, and now I HAD to go back and make the wrong choice so that I could properly play the game. For some reason that rubbed me the wrong way when I first played this, that and the really repetitive scenes- the characters constantly forget their experiences so they don't know what they have revealed before- which grew quickly tiring, because I was not aware this game was more a long movie with a few puzzles and Big Decisions to make.

I left and came back a long time later, I quickly learned what I had written above but this time I rolled with it. And even so, going from ~2 hours playtime, to then 8 hours, 15 the next day, now 25 hours in the span of less than a week, this game is a LOT of talking. I'd say its 80% talking, 15% escape room puzzles, but even the puzzles have the character's witty commentary- to a point where they reveal info about the puzzles through 'hints' that range from things you already know to [i]the literal answer.[/i]

The first half of the game, like the first 12 hours I swear, is the same information repeated over and over and over again, sometimes in different rooms, with different people, you learn things but these things are then repeated, and repeated, until you want to just call it quits. I don't think everyone will feel this way, but if it wasn't for quarantine there's no way I could have put the hours in this game that it drains from you. 

I was really tired for a lot of this first part, not because the series of events weren't interesting, they just took so long to listen to, and when I figured anything out for myself one of the characters says it a minute later, except it's still not information that helps. I had to really get myself to care somewhat about these people who complain a lot and make stupid allegations all the time, who would constantly whine about each other or their past or dead parents. But finally, finally I got to a point where I was given the one piece of information that seemed to spark the second half, basically none of the people were there by coincidence, and they know a lot more than they've been telling you or each other.

It was everything I wanted, the narrative switched from character details to profound discussion about the bounds of time and space, multiple universes, the reveal of apparent common knowledge that was kept from you. It gets weird. It gets confusing again but in a world-breaking way, you finally see how big this puzzle actually is, and you want to know everything, you want the good ending. You strive for the good, for the complete. Every ending, every bad ending, because there's purpose now, because you're getting answers, you're revealing new things because of what you know, what you've deduced.

I can't say the ending is savory, it would have been better as an ending to a movie, but not a video game. Because choice is so important, that's told to you constantly, then you believe your choice is nonexistent, then you have choice again, but then it's revealed the choice was never actually yours, but still offers you  illusions of choice everywhere. I only recommend this game because I can see and experience the love and effort that went into this experience, I loved the complexity of everything, and because this game will make you feel all sorts of things. But those emotions include boredom, sometimes impatience. My computer fell asleep multiple times during some cutscenes. Take that as you will.

I would play a sequel.

68934208.review:
As a huge fan of the other two Zero Escape games, this one is a huge disappointment. It's writing and characters are awfule compared to the other two and just awful in general. It also leaves a lot to be desired coming from VLR, as it completely neglects a lot of details and threads that were set up previously, as well as retcons things, and completely changes world-building and characterization. These aren't the characters you know and love anymore. The new characters are all completely horrible as well. Eric and Q are incredibly annoying with Eric especially having the most awfully stupid character motivations. Mira is also a bland and incredibly flat character, despite what her in game model looks like.

There is one thing I did like though. I really did like the decision mechanic, and how there weren't just two binary options for each choice and that some had three or even four outcomes, and how they were all different. The problem is that nothing interesting was done with this mechanic. All of the different outcomes are just as bad as the others, even if the way the game splits the paths off of each other was unique.

I also didn't like the change to a more movie like format instead of the more traditional visual novel format. This is just a personal preference, though. I don't think the graphics looked good enough for the movie style. It also takes away control from the player in being able to skip voiced lines, even though that's not my personal preference. It also makes skipping using the fast forward button a lot slower, and more imprecise, than it was in previous games. There's also the rather funny little slip up of them including the skip button UI element in some characters' memories. 

The escape rooms aren't bad. They're actually pretty good by themselves. Some of them are just very generic compared to VLR. Not an inherently bad thing, but can make them less enjoyable if you have played VLR recently. Multiple times while playing through this I thought, "haven't I done this already?" only to realize that it was actually a very similar room from VLR that I was remembering.

Overall, this isn't a good game. There are many elements to it that hit personal boxes that really irritate me specifically, but might not bother you. If you want a fun escape room game with a passable story, get this while it's on sale. If you're a huge Zero Escape fan, this game might hurt. It's kind of necessary to play to finish the story from VLR, but you're probably better off creating your own head canon and forgetting this game ever existed. That and playing AI: The Somnium Files. That one is good.

I enjoyed my time with the game, but IF YOU HAVEN'T PLAYED THE LAST 2 GAMES AND AREN'T INVESTED IN THE SERIES, YOU PROBABLY WON'T ENJOY IT. There are better visual novels out there.

The jump to 3D models and voice acting is janky as hell. The models have limited animations, don't really emote, and often don't sync lip flaps with voice lines (I set the audio to 'dub' so maybe the japanese is better). 

The series has always had a bit of a problem with spelling every concept out 3 or 4 times, which works fine when you're reading at your own pace, but feels really slow and ungainly when you have to wait for the VA.

67313772.review:
Historia plana con personajes mal llevados y un fan service que más que ayudar empeora la experiencia. 
Digamos que todo lo que sus entregas anteriores: Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors y Virtue's Last Reward hacen, este se lo carga completamente (argumento y personajes), hasta el punto de que un personaje destacable y querido lo destrozan completamente. 

Sin más no lo recomiendo, ni aún costando menos de 17€. Solamente se salva su banda sonora y que en parte es reciclada de las dos entregas anteriores y aún así ni eso.
Y aunque se juegue mejor que los anteriores (tema de acertijos), estos son poco originales.

Digamos que la receta ya estaba agotada, y por lo tanto debería haber terminado en la segunda entrega.
Mencionar que quitar el toque de VN para que fueran cinemáticas, es una de las peores decisiones que he visto en un videojuego. Con modelos simples si nada de carisma y terriblemente ejecutados (recalcar que son modelos cell-shading), y que en momentos en los que intentan ser tensos, resultan más graciosos de lo que pretenden. Por no decir que es excesivamente gore por que sí. No había ninguna necesidad de hacerlo de esa forma (mira las dos entregas anteriores).

En fin, solo recomendaría su compra en caso de querer saber como termina la trilogía, y ver ese final tan esperado que además es sin más.
Un desastre que no se como pudieron llegar a pensar que triunfaría y que no está para nada a la altura de la saga.

En esta página he escrito una review más a fondo: https://opicionyanalisisvisual.photo.blog/2020/04/15/zero-escape-la-trilogia-casi-perfecta/

Zero Time Dilemma เป็นภาคที่ 3 ในซีรีย์ zero escape หากใครอยากจะเล่นควรจะเล่นภาค 999 -> Virtue's Last Reward แล้วถึงจะเล่นภาคนี้ ในภาคนี้จะสานต่อเนื้อเรื่องจากภาคที่ 2 มาโดยตรงเพื่อสานต่อเนื้อเรื่องให้ใกล้เคียงความสมบูรณ์ของไตรภาคมากที่สุด
     ข้อดี
1. ภาคนี้จะมี cut scene เป็นฉากให้เราได้ดูอย่างต่อเนื่องไม่ใช่การกดอ่านเรื่อยๆ แบบในภาคที่แล้ว
2. เนื้อเรื่องยังคงความเข้มข้นไว้ได้ถึงจะไม่เทียบเท่า 2 ภาคที่ผ่านมาแต่ยังอยู่ในระดับดี ตัวละครอาจจะมีแปลกๆ ไปบ้างแต่ก็ยังพอมีมิติ(คือถ้าเขาอยากให้เราเกลียดตัวไหน เขายังบิ้วเราได้อยู่)
3. การ control ทำได้ดีกว่าภาค 2 (มั้ง)
     ข้อเสีย
1. cut scene ทำออกมาได้แย่ ยังดีที่นักพากษ์ยังแบกตัวละครและตัวเกมส์เอาไว้ได้ (แต่เชื่อเถอะเล่นไปซักพักก็จะชิน เหมือนตอนที่เล่นภาค แรกจบ แล้วมาเล่นภาค 2 ใหม่ๆ)

3. ภาคนี้อาจจะมึนๆ กับการเรียง time line ในภาคแต่สามารถทำความเข้าใจจาก global flowchart ได้
4. ภาคนี้ cut scene ไหลยาวทำให้คนไม่เก่งภาษาอาจจะสตันแล้วไม่อยากเล่น สามารถแก้ได้โดย[u]กดปุ่ม S [/u]ระหว่างฉากเพื่ออ่านข้อความได้
5. เบื้องลึกตัวละครบางตัวเล่าออกมาได้ไม่ดีหมดจดเท่าภาค 2

65740306.review:
This game...is phenomenal. Absolutely Fantastic.
I know it says that I've only played 3 hours but that's only because I ended up watching the entire game in movie format first.

Why? Well. That's the game's only flaw.

Zero Time Dilemma, or [ZTD] for short, Is the third and final entry to The Zero Escape: The Nonary Games Series. It follows 999: Nine Hours, Nine People, Nine Doors and The Nonary Games: Virtue's Last Reward; Both of which have a flowchart style story.

What this means is that in the first two games, You start off at Point A. You're lead down to Point B where a choice you make will determine whether you move on to point C or point D. The story line possibilities continue to divide until each path reaches it's finale. You're also able to jump back to certain points to change your mind and follow different paths. It's important to do so because some crucial answers needed in say Point E can only be obtained in Point J in order to progress to a better ending.

This is a formula that is maintained throughout both [999] and [VLR]. However in [ZTD], this flow chart system is abandoned in favour for a new...uh...I don't even know what to call it. It's not even a web. It's very confusing to behold at first. You're so used to the flow chart that none of this makes any sense. 

So the begining is simple enough. but random points pop up soon after. sometimes one new path shows up, some times 2 or 3. Before long you have so many options you don't know what order to take. 

Worst off, you pick a path, and it feels wrong. Disjointed.

But here's the problem. The game doesn't tell you to just do whatever and that no matter what, everything would make sense and work out in the end. So Because i didn't want to 'Get the order wrong' I watched a movie guide version of it where someone who played the game, edited it and arranged it in the most progressively pleasing manner possible. But it was so damned good i couldn't stop watching.

So just play it~ play it and complete everything! This one is easily the best of all three of them (Assuming you've completed 999 and VLR) 

The story is totally fantastic! The voice acting is incredible! The characters are all perfect! The game is perfect! The OST is a perfect mix of old and new! That one little flaw gives it a 9.5/10. But honestly it's fantastic! I don't care what anyone says. This game is worth every penny!

65576273.review:
This is the game that closes all the mysteries that remained from the previous game, Virtue's Last Reward.
It is a polemic game due to its execution and the way it closed some of the questions. 
I must say I enjoyed its story. I also liked the idea of bringing it in a cinematic way, although the characters expressions and movements were quite weird, which made it more difficult to take seriously. On the other hand, thank god it was like that because this game was the most brutal and gory with lot of difficult choices to make, in which someone always ended up dying. And despite the fact that the visuals were weird, knowing the characters, being attached to them, made it sometimes difficul to continue, so props to Uchikoshi for that.

The premise is similar to the other games: nine people locked in a building, but now they are separated in 3 teams and you play with the leader of each team. They have to play the decision game, which implies killing elements from the other team, deciding who survives or believe in luck.

I liked the fact that the game would build up by playing fragments of story. I liked it because you would gather information from each fragment, and although you would lose youself in time, at the same time as you were locked inside a building, it looked like it didn't matter what time it was. Even the fact that they were sedated and their memories erased at the end of each fragment, made it look like any fragment could fit along or that you could map the correct fragments for each timeline giving the constraints from each one of them. There is also a flowchart so you could always guide yourself from there.

About the flowchart, there was only one thing I couldn't understand at first. One of the first fragments is to vote on a team to kill. The team with more votes would die. One of the requirements to finish the game is to kill every team (each in a different timeline). From the flowchart I didn't understand that and it blocked me for a while but despite that, the rest was kind of easy to figure out by playing different fragments.

The credits song for each ending is superb. It is melodic and it affects you, like what happened was a result of your choices and you have to live with that. Some songs from the ost are songs from the previous games (and it's interesting because you find some similarities between some rooms too), but there are also new ones, especially for Q team.

The beginning of the game, in my opinion is genious and you really have to try it because I kept thinking about it until the end.

The "true" ending (it is difficult for me to define it as a sole true ending because every ending in Zero Escape is essential for the final one) is a bit rushed and leaves a lot of questions to answer. I kind of liked the "each player makes it own decision about the ending", but there was material for another one (although it would the the 4th and 4 is an unlucky number in Japan).
But despite that controversial ending I liked how some of my suspicions were confirmed and how some events were explained.

I also liked the characters. Some were already known from the previous games. There were actions that didn't make very sense to me, regarding waht I already knew from them, but giving the fact that they were playing a deadly game, I kind of accepted it.
The new characters were very interesting in terms of traits. In a first glance, you may not like them, but please give them a chance and try to understand them in terms of personality, traumas, experience, and you will see how good they also were to the story.

So, overall, the game doesn't close all gaps, some are explained in a rushed way, and perhaps the game should have had more budget in order to create a more solid story. It should be longer too, giving the fact it was the final game.
Despite the shortcomings, I think it is a good game to play, it has wonderfull characters and, even if not perfect, it closes the story.
Please, give Zero Escape a try!

64962238.review:
This game should've never existed. The first two game were pretty good. This? Where should I even begin.

First the obvious: The presentation sucks. I don't need to talk much about this. 

Second: The entire story is awful. They had the great idea to use fragments for storytelling, so there's pretty much no narrative order at all. Stories without any kind of order however make everything feel quickly pointless. Whatever happens in a fragment? Who cares, it's not mattering in the next one. Someone dies? Who cares. Even if the next fragment plays afterwards, who actually died isn't set in stone.
The game was praised by some for giving you a huge amount of choice. It's not a choice if you have to exhaust all "choices" anyway though. The entire drama also becomes frustrating. Press the button or not? WHO CARES?!? We do both anyway. I don't need a full damn minute of "exciting countdowns" where people argue about pressing the button. Both. Happens. Anyway.
There's also way too much random killing going on. The writer was insanely lazy with the endings and just decided that characters simply start killing others without much of a reason.
Speaking of characters, the returners are a shadow of their former selves. 

Third: The gameplay. Puzzle rooms are at their worst designs as well. It feels like nobody ever bothered thinking things through. Many hints can be understood in multiple ways leading to trial and error. Other hints are completely pointless. Random triggers you have to find that are complete and utter nonsense. Like having to click twice on something before you can do what you need to do. Or when you have to find special spots so you can insert 8 keys, having to actually only find 6 and insert them to progress, because the last two are locked away. Frustrating. Pointlessly frustrating. The latter could be easily fixed by making the trigger FINDING and not INSERTING. Everything could be easily fixed. But alas.


I've never see a worse final entry in a series, let alone to a series that was so promising. In all of the time I've played this game, there was nothing relevant about the story either. Everything felt pointless. How can you even care about the characters when every damn 5 minutes they snap and kill random people, themselves or whatever, and then are back in the next fragment where that didn't matter? I can't. That's for sure.

64177742.review:
ZTD is a masterpiece that will turn your mind inside out.
Though there are some flaws and it feels like they ran out of money at the end "My motives are complex!..." and Chunsoft just said "Ship it".(Very obviously they were working on a tight budget due to the series lack of success in Japan. And they did very well with what they had)
I wish the ending had been better with an animated Epilogue and answering the rest of the plot threads left untouched. (There's nothing that tells you there are "Epilogue Files". And why do only 6 of the characters get epilogues? I won't spoil who but there is a group of 3 that gets absolutely nothing.)  Unwoven.  An otherwise small blemish an amazing game and series.  It really feels like there should be an anime film sequel that finishes the whole thing. (As the whole escape room plot thread has run it's course. But there's still things left unsaid)

If you want to just play 1 game in the Zero Escape series. Play 999. That game works on it's own by itself. But also as part of the other two that cannot function as a whole without 999. I never played VLR when it first came out and if I had, man I don't know how I would've handled the thought of there never being a third game. Because that ends on a utterly depressing clifhanger, and on it's own it feels wholy incomplete.  ZTD ties up a lot from VLR and is really VLR part 2. But still leaves some pretty WTF feelings on how to interpret it all. Really, thinking about it one way is so sad that it makes me feel anxious. Another way it's bittersweet but necessary that eventually leads to success. However it doesn't change what happened, from still happening. 

Also it cannot be understated, that if you don't play this series and cry (or want to cry) at least a dozen times or so. You are not human.

Shinji Hosoe's music is incredible. The way he reuses themes and reworks them in each entry is just enhances the continuity of the series as a whole. There is never a bad song. It's never repetitive. He finds great ways to rework tracks and re-arrange them to make it different enough to make you say "wow". The emotional themes will get you to cry all over again. It's a shame that it isn't easier to legally get a hold of the soundtracks to this series. It's a grave injustice to how good this legendary composer's music is.

The shift in character designs is jarring at first but they grow on you quick as Rui Tomono's art is amazing. Equally as jaw dropping as Kinu Nishimura. 

The puzzles are less difficult than VLR and more in line with 999 as well. Though still thought provoking. Between VLR and ZTD I think I had about 25 pages in a small notebook filled with notes. I LOVED that the puzzles (and other bits of key info) were engaging enough to need to write down to figure out or remember. 


The PC version lacks some of the visual changes in the PS4 version, like SSAO, greater self shadowing, and some bloom. But I feel the game actually looks better without them. Mostly the SSAO, as it looks extremely overpowering on PS4 and doesn't blend well with the character models. (There will be random shades of gray on places that there shouldn't be that look egregious. Such as on specular highlights in the cel shading.)  The option would've been nice I guess. But really you aren't missing much. 
The things you are missing that definitely look much better are UI assets like the fonts for subtitles. They are very low res on PC but much improved on PS4. As are icons for items.
But overall the PC version looks very good. You can turn off effects you want (Like the motion blur that really doesn't belong in a game without much fast motion), and inject others with reshade if you want them enough.

Lengthwise i've seen some criticism against ZTD for having 3 less puzzle rooms (not a big deal) or being shorter than the other games. This isn't really true though. Because ZTD is actually about the same length as 999 if you do everything in both. In fact, longer because you can only reach the true end of ZTD by doing everything. Where as in 999 you can learn absolutely everything and attain the true ending by only taking 2 paths. Leaving the other 7 paths unnecessary but still entertaining. (Minus Lotus).
Virtue's Last Reward is really the outlier, it's a 60 hour game to get the true path and there is a lot more repetition of similar dialogue playing out and it's all necessary. In my mind VLR is just about 10-20 hours too bloated in contrast to ZTD and 999.
I will say though that the length of the VN segments in ZTD often feel too short. Moving to animated cutscenes instead that are much more difficult to create lead to the balance sometimes feeling off kilter and not leaving enough time for character development. (And some characters not quite getting enough screen time. Like Phi and Q Team).

Another thing that felt kind of off as well was the beginning of the game. You are just kind of thrown into the mix without much context. Where as there exists a sort of proper beginning slash prologue for the story. But relegated to a digital pre-order bonus in the west. And part of a pre order booklet in Japan. That should've been animated and expanded on to become the beginning of the game to really set things up more.

ZTD isn't perfect. But it's still masterful.

63886902.review:
A good ending to a great trilogy. If that tells you enough, you won't need to read the rest.

Zero Time Dilemma picks up where the story of Virtue's Last Reward left off, with some old faces coming along for the new ride. Don't expect familiarity, though. With one notable exception, every returning character acts notably different from how they used to. Most of that is explained, but it can be off-putting.

Once again, puzzle design has been improved from the previous entry in the series. Puzzles and story also intertwine more than in the last two games.

So far, so fantastic, right? Well, not everything is sunshine and rainbows, I'm afraid. For starters, this game is technically very unstable. If you're experiencing crashes in Windows, I recommend setting the executable to run in administrator mode and/or compatibility mode.

[spoiler]So, remember the cliffhanger at the end of Virtue's Last Reward, with the mystery character hopping into Kyle's body? The character Phi explained would be vital to stopping the pandemic? Because the writers don't. No payoff to that is explicitly given in this game. And Brother? It's revealed who he is, but nothing comes of it and the goals of Free the Soul are largely left to the imagination.

This game wraps up the plot thread of the Mars mission simulation just fine, but in doing so it forgets to give closure to more or less anything else. Even in the final, true ending to the series the game manages to leave several major plot point unresolved, most of which are introduced earlier in this game. It seems to beg for a fourth entry, but leaves almost no room for a new nonary/ambidex/decision game to frame such a sequel around.[/spoiler]

I'd still recommend this game if you want some more Zero Escape, for it is a Zero Escape game through and through. Unfortunately, that includes the series' faults, magnified to an even greater degree than they were in VLR.

62865003.review:
I have to say, while I love the series and I wouldn't stop anyone that loves the first two from playing this game, it's really hard for me to give it a flat out recommendation. There are quite a few issues with the story logic, story structure/game play loop, and basic things like people just staring when talking and mouths moving when silent. It does have an interesting concept iterating on the story mechanic of the last two games. Instead pure linear branches, the story is sectioned off due to the character being knocked out and given amnesia drugs. But while it looks good on paper, in practice it hampered the momentum of story progression. I had to restart it half way and use the Chronological Fragment Guide because it was not clear in game the places I had to try new choices or endings. Even more so when game over endings would still have nodes after it. 

The puzzles, for the most part, were good and interesting. Many felt more interactive rather than minigames, but I think they were some the easier puzzles in there series. Or it could be having played all three, I had the Zero Escape mindset that made them seem easy. Some of them had a few logic inconsistencies, like the transporter room when finding the last part to finish the room. The answer goes against the logic you were told and operating on up until that point. If anything, I felt like there weren't enough, that it was almost too story heavy, or that the easy of the puzzles or how quick they could be solved was out of balance with all the story you watch.

The story itself...well, there is a twist about 2/3rds through that really made the whole thing seem very doubtful. Up until then, I kinda figured out many of the storylines of the characters and why they were there, but towards the end, with that twist, it felt very illogical and random. It made "sense" as the story finished, but there were a lot better ways to do what they did and get to the same place. 

So, if you feel you need to play to get the whole story, I won't stop you since I did playthrough it myself. But of all three games in the series, this is the only one I wouldn't replay later on

62821489.review:
unpei[h1]Diary: Zero Escape: Zero Time Dilemma - 100% Complete[/h1]

[table]
[tr][td][h2]Day 1 - 2/1/2020[/h2][/td][/tr]
[tr][td]A game where choices matter? With like 5 billion endings, and tons of wifus? Ya, I bought this game for silly reasons, and I'll stick up for them forever. Now it's time to rant on my day one playthrough of this game even though I only spent like 5 minutes doing the coin flip part of the game, which is the very start. READY SET GO!

Cough, so these people are derp already, accusing the other kid in the same jail as them for putting them all in there. With no evidence, for no reason, they are just jerks what the heck, man. I like how everyone also is so quick to pretend they know the exact color the coin flipped to, like guys. If you are wrong, you realize we are all doomed, right? 

So, of course, I did the most logical thing. I looked up the matrix red pill vs. blue pill. You may think, huh, that's insane. What in the world does the Matrix have to do with this? But when you realize, the truth it's spooky.

The red pill reveals the truth that you are actually in the Matrix.
The blue pill of the coin toss is supposed to represent ignorance. 

In this game, you win by choosing the blue one, and you lose by selecting the red. Guess what one gives you knowledge? That's right, the red one, and the blue one gives you ignorance because you didn't learn anything from winning right away.

But that's just a diary theory~ 
[/td][/tr]
[/table]

[table]
[tr][td][h2]Day 2 - 2/3/2020[/h2][/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Man, I made quite of progress today. I finally beat the voting choices portions and unlocked the rest of the "undiscovered" map, which shows me I still have tons of content to get through before the game is over. 

I was streaming the game to my friend, and we were solving problems together. He's more math-oriented than me, so some puzzles were easy for him to answer. I'm more object-oriented, so environmental puzzles were something I was quicker at. We made a great team when it came down to it. It was a fantastic time.

I did a lot of the Q team story, and let me tell you, man, doing these separate timelines gives you so many perspectives on the characters and development for them because you are seeing them unfold when the circumstances are different, it's just so interesting. I'm excited to see where this game goes from here.
[/td][/tr]
[/table]

[table]
[tr][td][h2]Day 3 - 2/21/2020[/h2][/td][/tr]
[tr][td]So, my opinion of this game hasn't changed much, still has a lot of nice puzzles and a good balance of story too. I'm very grateful for the forward button when you are repeating scenes to go for different results. Otherwise, it would be an impossibly long game. 

I have been focusing mostly on C team missions today and trying to unlock as much as possible. I swear the way the drama is played out in these scenarios almost feels alien in comparison to the Q team because right from the start, we pretty much understand that all three are friendly people and wouldn't seem to hurt a fly, except Junpei I guess. 

Though man, most of the stuff I did was all luck based material when it comes to choices. I was doing dice rolls, antidote gambling, and also tackling the Monthy Hall problem. Mind you, it took several times to get the desired outcomes I wanted, but this game plays a lot of trickery when it comes to choice. It's downright awesome how much this game messes with you.

They go into more detail about player choice and how it affects the world the further you get into the game. It's interest and a nice take on things. This game likes to remember every choice you made. 
 [/td][/tr]
[/table]

[table]
[tr][td][h2]Day 4 - 2/22/2020[/h2][/td][/tr]
[tr][td]I've mostly focused on D team today, and they are probably my least favorite out of the group. They aren't so bad persa, but I just didn't care as much as I did with the others. I finally unlocked a unique ending once I beat their missions, though, so that was nice. It was about time I got another unique ending.[/td][/tr]
[/table]


[table]
[tr][td][h2]Day 5 - 3/23/2020[/h2][/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Wow, I finally beat all the puzzle rooms, and was able to just go through cinematic after cinematic. Felt like the game changed from a puzzle, visual novel hybrid to strictly a visual novel one. Though there were a lot more "meta" questions, I had to figure out the answer to. 

The twists and turns at the end is quite a lot, and all the mechanics they flesh out throughout the game come together. It makes sense once I took some time to think about it. I'm glad I kept getting all these neat, unique endings also. They were fresh and gave me a lot of information about the other characters. The individual conclusions are simply another way to obtain critical information.

I can highly recommend this game if you like to experiment a lot with actions, and gather information from multiple timelines.  
[/td][/tr]
[/table]
