61763022.review: Of the three games in the zero escape trilogy, this is the one that I find it difficult to recommend. If you enjoy the series for the puzzles, then this game won't be a problem for you. If however, you mostly played for the story and the characters of the previous games, then you may want to skip this one. This game has different timelines like the other games, however, they forget everything that happened in between scenes. This not only makes it difficult to tell just what decision made which outcome, but it also means that you never see any kind of character growth. It also doesn't help that the themes that the previous games had about minds being connected is a much heavier stretch, at least to how its connected to the real world. By the time I had reached the halfway point of this game I was sleeping my way to the end, tempted to just skip through all the cutscenes and simply play through the puzzles.

61685167.review:
I would give this neutral rating if I could. I enjoyed the overall story after it all clicks but feel this game isn't really needed.

There are a few dumb design decisions this time.

1. Most important the story doesn't follow set routes this time. The characters lose their memories after each event and so YOU also don't know the correct order. This leads to dumb situations where you will experience all the routes at once without knowing what is really going on. Your choices don't really matter since you won't go further in that specific story next more then likely. In the end it all makes sense but I hated this from start to finish.

2. The characters are split up into three groups of three and only interact with each other for 95% of the game. No going through routes with different characters on different doors here. I suppose since most aren't new characters it doesn't matter but I like the interactions.

3. You might get stuck in the story. Some events do not have predetermined outcomes. Something different can happen if you do it enough. You can't advance the story unless you see all of these events. By that point you will have a bunch of story locks on your flowchart so it can get confusing. One of them I had to do 5 times and finally looked at a guide to see what I was doing wrong.

4. Skipping text is annoying. The dialog is in cutscenes this time not static images. If you skip dialog you are likely to skip more then just that line. I don't need to hear every word so I skip a lot of text. You will have to check the backlog a lot if you do this.

5. Animations. Yes they are ugly but they aren't that bad. I like the new artstyle but 999 still looks the best. 2D>3D.

6. Not many escape rooms this time and the majority of them are pretty easy.

7. Could ruin 999 and/or VLR for you.

8. The ending is abrupt and that's it. Nothing else after it.

61651316.review: Mostly likeable characters with some awesome twists and challenging-but-fair escape room puzzles. A must-buy for any Danganronpa / Zero Escape fan.

61324477.review:
I got this as a gift and I want my money back.

I'll admit, I haven't even seen everything the game has to offer, I've only seen a few hours of content.  However, I can still say with full certainty that I have seen enough to warrant never recommending it to anyone, especially fans of the series.

The game just looks awful, honestly even worse than VLR.  Animations are either nonexistent or goofy as all hell, so any time the game wants you to take it seriously, I can't help but laugh.  I could forgive this if the writing was good like the other games in the series, but it just isn't.  The entirety of Q team are all new characters, and they are just awful people with no redeeming qualities.  The other teams are mostly just returning characters, but are just far less interesting than they were in other games.  Junpei, the protagonist from the first game, went from being someone who got sick just seeing a dead body to being perfectly fine with killing off just about anyone that isn't Akane over the course of a single year.  He also hates Zero for killing people, despite the fact that he has no issues with sending entire teams to their deaths. 

The overall story itself is a joke as well.  It is so poorly managed that you just have no idea what comes next.  You can, and probably will play everything out of order.  Because of this, your choices straight up do not matter.  Like I mentioned before, you can choose to kill off an entire team, which I did.  Immediately after, I had 4 new scenarios on the team I just murdered.  It just isn't coherent at all, and to really make it easier to understand, the most you get from a scenario before playing through it is a single frame that doesn't convey anything at all unless you've already played it.  From everything I've seen, the writing is awful and from a few spoilers I've seen, it only gets worse.  Just know that Zero's motives are complex.

Remember how the puzzles, especially in VLR, were really cool?  Yeah, they aren't anymore.  They are some of the easiest I've ever seen in a game and the only time you'll get stuck is if you forgot to check on something or if you aren't very good at math.  

Overall, just stick with the first two games and don't spend any money on this one.  It's not worth your time.

61143680.review:
Let me start off by saying that I really love the Zero Escape Series and all other similiar hybrid VN Games that this series is compared to, but thats exactly the reason I don't recommend it.
So where do I start? They moved away from a sprite based VN with dialogue boxes to one with models and voice acting. This sounds dumb but I prefer the older way, because in later parts of this game it felt like I was watching a movie instead of actually playing a game. It doesn't help that the animations are....not good. Some scenes that were meant to be serious just end up being funny jokes because of the animation.
Lets talk gameplay. This game has less escape rooms than the 2 previous Zero Escape games and it also lacks one final escape room in the true ending path like Room Q from VLR. Also some of the rooms are just plain bad. The Pod Room literally consists of the same puzzle like 8 times and thats it. Puzzles get reused a lot during this game and I found that most escape rooms were just not enjoyable to me.
Now lets get to the story and how it presents itself. Instead of following a flowchart with forks in the road, you have the option of going anywhere. You just select a fragment and have no idea where you are in the story and on which fork. I know this was done because the characters lose their memories each time but I feel like this hurts the presentation of the story more than it favors it. Some of the endings were really lackluster and not unique enough. C End was literally just an extended version of D End 1. The true ending itself was good, i give it that, but getting there feels like such a slog because you probably finished all the escape rooms 5-6 hours before getting there, so you just sit there for 5 hours watching cutscenes that try to be serious but end up stupid instead.
Lastly I want to talk about the characters and the teams that the game sorts them in. If you play this game, there is a high chance youve played 999 and VLR before. Then why does C Team have 2 999 Characters and D Team 2 VLR characters and Q Team no old characters. This makes Q Team by default the most uninteresting team of them, because of course you want to know what happens with Tenmyouji or Sigma, thats just natural. It doesn't help that most of the new characters are just so damn uninteresting that even if they didn't exist, it wouldn't change much in the story. (looking at you eric)

Overall, not as good as 999 or VLR, but still VERY much worth playing!! Slow to start, as are the previous two games, but you will come to a point where 5 hours in one sitting feels like nothing. 60682617.review:
I'm a big fan of the two previous titles in this series and was hoping Zero Time Dilemma would provide a fitting end to the trilogy. Unfortunately, I was left with utter disappointment.

Character development is a joke compared to 999 and Virtue's Last Reward, and all the jumping back and forth between different characters and events, combined with the vast amount of death scenes in different timelines, make it really hard to care about what happens to any of them.

There's also the issue of several of the loose ends not being addressed in any way whatsoever. An example:
[spoiler]What happened to Aoi from the first game? He escaped with Akane during the cliffhanger ending, but while she's part of the story in both sequels, it's not mentioned once what happened to him.
I had been thinking since Virtue's Last Reward that maybe he was actually Brother and that that title was a reference to him being Akane's brother, but no, he's just randomly erased from existence. Am I supposed to assume he died from the Radical-6 outbreak or something like that? Killing off major characters off-screen without any explanation isn't exactly good writing in my book.[/spoiler]

Furthermore, the game actively omits visual information and logical dialogue between characters for the sake of using certain elements as plot devices in later parts of the game.

In addition to everything mentioned above, the ending is one of the most unsatisfying ones I've ever experienced.
Basically, the main issue at the core of the game is never resolved, and we're just left to imagine the rest for ourselves. It effectively ruins a lot of what 999 and Virtue's Last Reward worked so hard to build up. If you enjoyed those games, I suggest you pass on this one.

60614313.review: If you're a fan of puzzle games and convoluted story lines (or escape rooms) then this is the game for you. I highly recommend playing the Nonary Game series as it's a prequel. The puzzles range in difficulty, so some will be straight forward while others will require more brain power.

60414043.review:
Zero Escape: Zero Time Dilemma (ZTD) is final game in Zero Escape trilogy, was made for 3DS, Windows and PS4. Being in the same trilogy as The Nonary Games 999 and VLR standards and expectations for ZTD were really high.

If you haven't finished both 9 Hours 9 Persons 9 Doors and Virtue's Last Reward don't bother playing ZTD since it is a culmination of those two and heavily spoils their plots. Since you've finished 999 and VLR and are still debating whether to buy ZTD or not let me give some of my insights. 

ZTD was made to be multi-platform game and has PS4 and PC next to 3DS in it's targeted systems you can already expect it to be a bit disappointing. It aims to be fully 3D game with cutscenes (lots of cutscenes) and fancy looks yet it is obviously downgraded, has stiff animations, weird camera angles, low amount of movement and all that just to cover how lacklustre it is. On top of that, characters' design of some of the reappearing cast have changed drastically for the worse. Puzzles on the other hand look fine and work similar to VLR. Some game design decisions are done on purpose so I don't think ZTD would work much better as a pure Visual Novel.

Puzzle design was hit or miss. ZTD gives same feeling as VLR did since puzzle sections work almost exactly the same. Most of the puzzles aren't hard. In my opinion toughness of the puzzles was overall between 999 and VLR. Some of the functionality is lost from VLR. Menus are confusing and sometimes terrible.

Now onto the most important part. Story. Just like 999 and VLR, ZTD too has main twist lurking in shadows right in front of your nose while carefully crafting the amazing reveal. The problem this time is that as the culmination and conclusion, ZTD doesn't work. There were amazing moments and incredible reveals but the story suffers from overpowered plot-devices and complexity of some of the characters' motives. Reappearing characters are way different (in negative context) than what they used to be for bizarre reasons. The story gets itself into easily noticeable paradoxes that start appearing when you start thinking about the issues. On the other side, drama and horror of the game work really well in building up the tension. You can expect some good emotional payoffs.

Weighing pros and cons can give different results for everyone. Personally, if you're like me and you too overthink, overanalyze and have really high expectations out of things, then I don't recommend ZTD. If you are able to lower the expectations and suspend your disbelief without too much looking into things you will probably have a nice time.

60161482.review:
☆[i] A single, solitary snail took the lives of six people. No, not just six... but six billion. Six  million people will lose their lives as a result of that lone snail. Life is simply unfair, don't you think?[/i] ☆

I finished this game back in spring but never wrote a review for it, even though I wanted. In a very short summary, this game is iconic. I rarely find games that have that much influence on me, but this game is the one. 

It came out as a third game in franchise with a different gameplay and visual style which made many people who played first two games dislike it. I kinda disagree with them and think that this game is best in series. If first two games were all about finding the way out and beat the escape game by completing boring routines, this is one is showing how much the 'butterfly effect' can change the human history, not just the history of players. It also has a good example of a 'time loop' causing Zero to exist (it is somehow a huge spoiler, so I won't tell more) and is more about philosophy than entertainment. Throught the whole playtime, the player has to make a choice, and each of his choice has a great plot twist. You can beat the game in a very beginning, but you may also cause a huge catastrophe. All you need to know in this case that you can and you can't determine your future at the same time.

The events of ZTD take place between the events of 999 and VLR. It shows what made the events of ZTD even happen and how easily it could be avoided. This explains why this part has characters both from 999 and VLR. It also had some new characters. Each character plays his own role in this game. If you played VLR, you know what happened in the future in their timeline. If you didn't, I recommend you to do it first, cause the 3rd game is a huge spoiler to both Nonary Games.

The gameplay is different from NG. You don't have to play this game from the beginning to the end which I love - it has many video and escape game fragments, and you can watch/play them in the order you like in most times. To continue some routs, though, you need to finish some fragments first. Some fragments can be opened by doing certain actions, f.e. killing someone. Yes, that's another difference from previous two games - only three people may escape the game zone. The individuals who can make it to escape change the history - the game is playing with timelines again, just like in VLR. There many endings, too, and all of them are equal, unlike in previous games where there's only one 'true' ending. However, there's only one ending that actually leads to the VLR main timeline. Despite all that, there actually IS a way to make all people escape but it wouldn't be that easy.

As for characters, there are ten of them, - nine players and Zero, the mastermind. Some of them are familiar to those who played Nonary Games as they already participated in them (not in chronically order but in previous games). Three of them are new and belong only to certain timelines. What they have in common is that they all woke up in a place looking like a base for preparing to go to outer space. None of them have any memories.

In this game, you'll have to play as one of teams. You can start with the team you like the most but you'll need to play all of them in order to find a way to keep everyone safe. Each team has a leader and includes three players. Two of them are connected but leader is someone new to them. You'll learn the story of each team by playing their routes. 

Team C is represented by Akane, Junpei and Carlos. While first two people are very familiar, Carlos is a new player who plays for the first time. He is a fireman who came to the 'base' for his very own reasons. He has no idea who his teammates are but he had to lead his team anyway. Unlike them, he's not from Japan. This thing makes  a player understand that the 'team' is international and they were preparing for a really serious thing. He appears to be 'gifted' in a special way, like everyone in his team. His abilities save the day in some timelines. He's also the one who starts the escape game in the very beginning. 

Team Q is represented by Mira, her boyfriend Eric and Q, a little boy wearing a helmet. While Eric has no influence on the game, the other two do have one. Mira is a sexappeal girl with a big secret which you may learn by completing the story. She's also a reason why VLR timeline even happened and a reason for the some events Zero is referring to. Eric is a simple ice cream seller who's in love with her. Q is the most mysterious person among nine players. He has his own ending, unlike everyone else in this game, and represents a part of Zero's past.

Team D is represented by Sigma, Phi and Diana. The first two will take part in the next escape game while Diana seems to be the one who doesn't matter at all. The truth is that Diana, a red-haired young woman with a bird necklace, is probably the most important person among them all. The story of these three is the most interesting but not that unexpected for those who learn from noticing little details.

Finally, Zero II. This Zero is my favourite because he's not trying to achieve his own goals as much as he's putting a true challenge for nine players by making them learn more about the responsibility for choices they make and effects they cause on the human history. Literally, he puts them all in his little game to turn them into figures on his chess desk called 'the fate of the world'. Even the passwords the players need to receive to escape are connected to them - and to him a little, too. He has the ability of mind-hacking while most of players have the ability to travel between timelines. He's not an actual evil genius but some kind of God who rule the game and the world, and also some kind of philosopher.

The identity of Zero II is truly amazing. By revealing it, he makes some players learn the truth they never thought really existed. He also makes them understand that time is much more mysterious thing than they could have ever imagined. The biggest mystery behind it is that actions that make this game exist were taken in the this very game but in a different timeline, making the greatest time loop you have ever seen. All the timelines are connected to each other a lot, and all players' actions summarize and turn into the future of the humankind. That's the dilemma that he leaves to three teams - choosing the human history's future knowing how much he can affect it and deciding whether to make him pay for his sins or not.

This game is a true masterpiece. 
You won't get bored by all the dilemmas you'll have to solve.

60159159.review: Recommended but only if you've played 999 & VLR, on it's own it's even more confusing than it is with context

60140518.review:
I recommend this game, but let me say it is definitely below the first two games.

First off, the graphics and sound are fantastic in the game. Nice texture work, the characters looks great, soundtrack is beautiful, love all of it.

The plot, I have mixed feelings on it. Sometimes you'll get stuck and not know what to do next (puzzle wise and flowchart wise), and there are a few plot twists that leave you incredibly confused. The ending is somewhat abrupt and you'll sit there thinking, "..Really? It ends there?". It does expand on 999 and VLR, which is to be expected, but bear in mind this will even change how you see THOSE games. Overall, I do like the game and its plot, but something just feels like it's missing. I've heard this game was rushed and honestly it shows. I wish this game had a bit more love put into it.

Now, the few things I hate about this game.

The animations:
The models are beautiful in this game, but the animations are so god awful that I wish they stuck to 999's 2D sprites for the characters. Those sprites were animated so well and they actually felt alive. In this, the animations are so stiff and robotic that a lot of times that's all you can notice. The lip-syncing is also terrible, but I'm guessing the two go hand in hand.

Eric. Fuck Eric. He basically never redeems himself and you'll hate him the entire time.

Also, a returning character had a personality shift, and acts like a scumbag now. You'll know who I'm talking about, even 2 minutes into the game.

Overall, the game is good, but there are so many things it could do better. It's definitely not the ending I was looking for, but I'll still take it.

60052683.review:
A satisfying conclusion to the Zero Escape Trilogy. I would highly recommend using a guide to follow a reasonable order for the "fragments."

[b]Pros:[/b][list]
[*]Compelling story that answers most if not all the questions that arise
[*]Characters are interesting but new ones could be fleshed out more
[*]Challenging escape room segments
[*]Wraps up the Zero Escape saga with several large twists and revelations
[*][b]No Dio[/b]
[*]Gab
[/list]
//Could have been more information about the characters post-game lives (D Team specifically)

59865749.review:
[NO SPOILERS IN THE FOLLOWING REVIEW]

Zero Time Dilemma (ZTD) is great! I entered it with slightly dashed hopes, as I got the impression from some in the fan base that this game is a step down from the first two in the Zero Escape series ('999' and 'Virtue's Last Reward'), and whilst I do understand the complaints, ZTD is a brilliant game and a step up from the other games in some ways too.

The pacing is improved tremendously from the first two games. The player doesn't have to sit through so much unnecessary dialogue and repeated situations, the player doesn't have to mash a button to skip the text boxes anymore either. This made the experience so much more enjoyable for me. The added animations and cinematography is well-appreciated too. 

Another pacing-thing that was improved was the characters explaining things, in the previous games many concepts and stories about characters were explained well, but sometimes it went on a bit, such as the infamous 'Explaining Ice-9 while freezing to death' situation. In ZTD, the explanations were done well and took as long as they needed to. Unlike in the first two games, I never felt impatient playing this.

The story is as genius as ever, and I think it serves excellently as the finale to the Zero Escape Series. I don't think I'm qualified to explain why I think this, and going over the story would go into spoilers, but I really liked it. Even if I'm not sure I understood it.

Speaking of spoilers, try and avoid using a walkthrough. Basically any and all ZTD content online is full of people who love to try and spoil the story, but by the time you're reading this review you probably already know not to do that, realistically, by the time you're reading this you've already beaten the game and are wondering what everybody else thought of it.

Don't get me wrong, ZTD did make some missteps, but they aren't significant enough to warrant not playing it. If you enjoyed 999 and Virtue's Last Reward, play Zero Time Dilemma as well. Also, play 999 and VLR first. If I had to sell the game to you in one sentence it would be: 'Isn't it obvious?'

59344991.review:
For this game to make any sense whatsoever (the little it does) it is vital to have played both prequels. (The Nonary Games + Virtues Last Reward)

While the first two games already set up a grand stage for the most paradoxical twists anyone has ever thought into existence while being completely on acid, Zero Time Dilemma takes it all home.

The story is the strongest point of the entire series and the fact that the developers and writers already outdid themselves during the first two games leads to some really weird story twists in the last game.

These are all highly enjoyable, you'll just have to go with the game logic flow though without questioning certain aspects too hard to be able to get the best possible experience.

If I could just forget the entire series I would, mainly to experience it from scratch once again.

Mechanically speaking this series consists of very lengthy Visual Novels with escape room logic puzzle elements and massively branching story paths. Contrary to most other games with a similar premise, ALL story paths are relevant. Not wanting to spoil anything, I cannot go further into why that is the case.

Playing all three games, which basically are one major story-continuum takes about 70 hours total. Shorter if you skip the majority of the puzzles with the help of one of many walkthroughs available.

All things considered I liked the very first game best though. The third entry, while essential for the overarching story, is probably a somewhat weak finish. I still consider it a great experience though.

If you have no interest in the previous two games you should entirely skip around this. The entire story makes zero sense otherwise.

59323652.review:
Game: 9/10 (see con's as to why this isn't a 10/10 to me of course)

Pro's
This game has a pretty crazy story line if you actually pay attention to it.
- Unique twist on 3 different teams
- Actual REAL life theories and Clinical studies which makes this game much more immersive
- Pretty neat graphics
- Blondie with the emerald green eyes :D <3
- Interesting characters all with different personalities and backgrounds to learn about
- Voice acting is really good as well not cheaply made by any means.
- Puzzles are on average about a 6/10 in toughness with some leaving you stumped, but don't overthink the situation and you'll come to complete them
- The timeline and being able to choose where you want to go and what you want to do next has no penalty on the choices because no matter the choice you make they always have set outcomes, you'll be able to select a different point in the timeline to see a different outcome and eventually see them all.
- This game actually makes you retain and remember information so make sure to have a pen and paper handy to write things down for the puzzles so you can remember, there is an in game journal but a lot of the puzzles have things not in the journal so you'll have to stop the puzzle and go over to the other side of the room just so you can see some symbols or numbers again. so write them down and you'll never go wrong.

Con's

- The time line can be a bit cumbersome off the start, you feel as if you don't know what to do next but there really isn't any need to panic just play them all and listen to the story.
- There is a lack of gore that would have really put this game above and beyond, There are times in the murder / death scenes where you cant see how the character is dying or being beheaded or shot, whatever else and that to me is a pretty big deal. I want to play a game where you can save / kill members and I want to actually see it happen. If this was in there the game would be a solid 10/10
- Some sections of the game can be really slow and tedious especially some of the puzzles, You might get stuck on what seems to be easy stuff when in reality it's a little more tougher then you thought.

Conclusion: Excellent game with a rich story, interesting characters and a fun play style, gets your brain working to deduce puzzles and figure out pathing to story lines. 

Bought this game and Zero Time Dilemma: Nonary Games when they were on sale in a bundle for 5$ got lucky and definitely well worth the price, its worth it at full price, you get hours of game play and it's all enjoyable!

55646517.review:
Having bought all 3 of the Zero Escape games and binge-played them, I would say a few things about the franchise in general that certainly apply to ZTD:

* Each game left me a bit cold for about the first half of my playtime - I initially felt that each title seemed a bit tedious and quite silly.  Eventually, each one revealed their best sides and my opinion swung around.  I didn't learn - after coming around to really appreciating 999, I internally grumbled about the set up of VLR.  And then having ultimately liked VLR, I thought ZTD was a big step down, until I ... got it.  If they release a 4th title I'll play it because they've earned my respect and willingness to stick with their story telling - I will probably think they've dropped the ball for quite a while, though, but I'll trust them enough to keep going.

* I'd definitely start at the beginning if you're coming to this franchise fresh - I think a lot of the character interactions and story explanations will seem both incomprehensible and dopey without having fully experienced their backstory.

* It's another game series where spoilers should be avoided as much as possible.  That's particularly hard for this franchise because each of the games had a small number of points where I ended up road-blocked by either a small missed detail in a puzzle, or the timeline display (or both) and looking up how to progress is, of course, fraught with spoilers.  Zero Time Dilemma is perhaps more of a problem here because the timeline/fragments system is really opaque in some crucial details and they have made the actual story structure significantly more complex.  All I can say, without spoiling anything, is be watchful for any parts of the "flow" that are not complete/activated, and that there are some unexplained aspects of the decision making system that can result in non-obvious road-blocks where you think you have done everything you need to, but the order matters (when it really shouldn't).

So, yeah, I recommend playing the whole series in order, and while each of those titles has flaws I think they each provided enough story-telling reward to shine - in the end - even if that's not apparent early on in gameplay.

55470045.review:
I jus-ugh. To put it shortly, I don't think Zero Escape: Zero Time Dilemma doesn't do a very good job of continuing, much less concluding the Zero Escape series. It's worth playing if you want to end the series, or if you got it for about $3.69 Canadian Fun Bucks like I did.

ZTD is in many regards less technically sound than VLR, and sometimes, 999. ZTD takes a lot of the issues I had with VLR, and actually ends up compounding on them for bigger issues. Convoluted menus turned into an incomprehensible mess. Files turned from inconvenient reading to frustrating because of the inability to write memos in them. Janky animation turned into laughably weightless, Telltale level animation. Even the new 3D models go from tolerable to a bizarre sidegrade with high-poly counts but compressed textures. Zero Escape's style, polish and presentation keeps getting cleaner and sleeker as it goes on, but the overall usability and enjoyability still peaked at 999.

But, the story. Man oh man, the story. It retreads too much while simultaneously adding too much. The returning cast return in name only, with personalities at such a distance from their old ones that they're practically a new character entirely. [also the new characters suck oh my god i fucking hate you eric] The plot hits all the same story beats that 999 & VLR did while telling it in a nonlinear fashion that, well it is pretty damn cool, but still leaves a lot to be desired. The story hits lots of targets that VLR and 999 set up. It also ended up missing quite a bit and accidentally shot VLR and 999. It has its moments, but there's a lot of slog to go through to get to those moments, and the payoff isn't always worth it. Even thinking about the story in relation to the other games makes my head hurt a little, much less trying to think about it on its own. 

I'm really torn on what I think about ZTD. I mean, yeah, it's [i]good.[/i] Hell, I'd even say it's worth playing to end the Zero Escape series. It's still got great puzzles, witty banter, tons of "OH SHIT" moments. Hell, even the mathematical logic themes I thought were great when put up to 999's pseudoscience & VLR's philosophy. It's just...everything feels like such a step down from VLR that ZTD ends up leading the series to a disappointing end. It doesn't end with a bang, but it doesn't end with a whimper. Not with a farewell, or without saying a word.

Zero Time Dilemma ends the Zero Escape series with a ¯\_(ツ)_/¯.

55170524.review:
The long awaited third chapter to the Zero Escape series, which for a long time almost didn’t exist if it wasn’t for the continuous support of a devoted and invested fanbase. Zero Time Dilemma is many things: it’s the overarching conclusion to a cult sci-fi thriller series, it’s an attempt to square every thread left unwind during the previous games, it is an experiment of how far will people passively accept faux-science in lieu of common sense; it’s a thriller devoid of real suspense, a conspiracy story where the conspirators never show up, a sci-fi with so much fiction and so little science, a character driven drama where the characters are almost non-existent and lack any sort of humanity and coherent development. Zero Time Dilemma is many things, hardly any of them is good, well developed or new to the general audience.

The story itself won’t require many spoilers as it is more of a giant meme than a serious narrative by this point. Uchikoshi Koutarou came back and decided to strip everything that made previous game enjoyable and memorable – the style, the characters, the mystery, the sci-fi implications – and instead decided to bring everything the players had previously know from the series to a climax consisting solely of SNAILS, of ANCIENT ALIENS and COMPLEX MOTIVES. 

Characters still are probably the worst offenders of this game, even more so than the dumbed down puzzles and idiotic narrative: new characters are either disconnected completely from the plot or have one very specific role that is either fix the holes in the narrative or being a hole in the narrative; old characters are unrecognizable from their former selves and probably fit into the story even worse than their new counterparts. You would’ve loved to see some of your favourite come back with their wits and humour to spice things up and get their deserved good ending? Too bad, instead everyone is now a massive unlikeable c-nt and they will gladly leave the centre stage to some lame bugger, like the kid with Yoko Taro’s mask or Carlos.

The graphics are also at their lowest ever. The rigid models in Virtue’s Last Reward were an offense to the eye but at least they stayed put and pretended to be sprites, now instead someone woke up and decided to try a full-fledged cinematographic approach by adding camera movements and panning over the models, probably just to show off their immense ugliness. The facial expressions are more comically rigid than ever, movements just robotically stiff and there is an impossible amount of time lost between unskippable idle animations during replays.

More often than not the game actively punishes you for thinking ahead about the possible solutions, as the most predictable and inconsequential answers will almost always be the correct ones, leaving one without the feeling of reward for actively solving the mystery but more like an accomplice to the huge joke that is the storytelling in this game.

Do you feel the unsurmountable urge to complete each and everything you ever begin, have a fetish for train wrecks and C O M P L E X M O T I V E S, or generally like to enjoy your own anger? By all mean, this game was made with you in mind as the target audience.

55066530.review:
MINOR SPOILERS FOR GAMEPLAY

I definitely recommend playing the earlier Zero Escape games first (999 and Virtue's Last Reward) before this if you want to get the most out of the story! Most of the characters are known to us from previous games.

You play with three teams that consist of three persons. You play by choosing a fragment you want to investigate. You don't necessary know where that fragment belongs in a timeline until you have played it through and can see the flowchart. Be sure to play through every option: otherwise you might get stuck. Also, playing through earlier scenes where you haven't reached the end yet might help to unlock new possibilities.

The game itself seems more sadistic than the previous ones. At points you get to choose to kill off other characters to ensure you and your team survives. Most of the death scenes are brutal. I myself am not squicked out easily but this game managed to do it.

The puzzles themselves are not as hard as in Virtue's Last Reward (no easy or hard modes in this), but still very challenging. Some decisions you make seem arbitrary but can have a huge impact on what happens next. 

This third Zero Escape game solves some mysteries but not all. It also leaved me asking more questions after it. I have to say I was not satisfied with how the game treated some of the characters, but overall the experience was positive and emotional.

54875709.review:
Don't read this review if you haven't player 999 or Virtues Last Reward. 

This game is hot garbage. This is coming from a non weeb, who thought 999 was just okay and VLR was good. The puzzles are fine as per usual, and I didn't mind the graphics, but the story is trash.

The pacing is awful, mainly because of the "fragment" system that the game uses to tell its story. The premise of the game is that each segment is 90 minutes long (not real time 90 minutes, but in universe time 90 minutes) and that once those 90 minutes are up, the characters get knocked out and lose their memory. These 90 minute segments make up the "fragments" that you can select from. They are given in a non linear order, with you having to piece together what comes before or after in these scenes. This seems like an interesting idea on paper, but it ruins the flow of the story. Scenes just start and stop abruptly and there often isn't a pay off to anything that you just did in these segments. Things don't really lead to one thing or another until you understand the full context of the story, and often times are meaningless in the grand scheme of things.

Another thing that bothered me was the premise of the game itself. To "win" the game zero sets up, 6 of the 9 people in the game have to die. This obviously leads to a lot of moments where the characters die, but because of how often the characters die, there's really no emotional impact when someone dies.  Death becomes so meaningless that it's impossible to care when characters die, because you constantly see these characters die in each of the "fragments" that you play.

 The story can get promising at points, but completely falls apart at the end. The twists that the game tries to throw at you are laughably stupid. 
[spoiler] They introduce alien technology that can create copies of yourself and send these copies back in time. There is no mention of any aliens through out the whole series until this point, so this plot device comes out of fucking no where, and it's origins are never brought up or questioned. [/spoiler] 
Also the reveal that  [spoiler] Zero is a tenth participant in the game, that is kept offscreen and hidden from the player, even though the other characters seem to have always known about him, but just decide to never ever bring him up at all (besides 1 time where it's implied that the characters are talking to a dog, and not the tenth player), or ever verbally question why their group has 4 people in it instead of 3. It's obvious that the only reason they kept this character hidden from the player is because the player would immediately suspect that he's zero, so they had to show the story in a "dishonest" way in order to BLOW YOUR MIND LMAO.  [/spoiler]

The characters are pretty hit or miss. I enjoyed Carlos and Sphere kid, but Mira and Eric seemed like they were just there to [spoiler] sperg out and dispense game overs. It's also sucks that they retcon the ending of VLR because K (who was supposedly going to play a big role in stopping radical 6), Clover and Alice are not in this game at all. [/spoiler]. The characters from the previous games come across as incredibly incompetent or often time just acted like completely new characters. The decision to make Junpei a drunken beat cop while his character design makes him look like an angsty fuck boy lead to some pretty funny moments

Overall, the game is pretty disappointing. If you're played the previous 2 games and enjoyed them, then you're going to play this one regardless. Just don't get your hopes up, because this is clearly the worst game in the series. I guess you could say life is simply unfair...

I give this game a final score of 1 snail out of 6 billion.

54792622.review:
Zero Time Dilemma is the 3rd game in the Zero Escape Trilogy.  I strongly recommend playing the two games within the "Zero Escape: The Nonary Games" package (999 & Virtue's Last Reward) before playing ZTD.  There are recurring characters between the games, and the plot of VLR leads heavily into ZTD.

I was initially hesitant to pick up these games since I generally steer clear of anime.  However, even though all 3 games are all puzzle oriented visual novels from Japan, I wouldn't really classify these games as anime.  The English voice actors are all pretty solid, though I find Clover a bit annoying.  This series really got me hooked because of its strong science-fiction elements.  

To avoid spoilers, I won't go into too much detail about all the sci-fi topics covered in Zero Escape.  A lot of sci-fi stories take a concept and make a permutation in a way that may or may not coincide with reality as we know it.  

The Zero Escape Games examine the consequences that would occur if elements of human consciousness could be transmitted wirelessly, or stored in a cloud in a limited sense.   And these games really run with that initial idea.  Zero Escape regularly invokes concepts from quantum mechanics, philosophy, and even fictional research results to validate the pseudo-science presented.  

This series is a crazy ride across branching timelines with numerous fatally bad endings.  The first two games are more mystery than psychological horror, with tension and conflict generated through several prisoner dilemma type decisions.  ZTD does however ramp up the gory consequences of your choices significantly.  As you learn more tidbits of information from all your ending failures, you'll start to learn more about your companions and their complexities for better or worse.  You'll really bond with some of them, and be shocked and disgusted by others.

Fortunately, the flowchart system provides a convenient way to swap between story branches that have already been completed, so you don't have to repeat content over and over to reach the multiple endings.  It is also possible to skip and fast forward through previously seen dialogue sections.

The only game I've played that is remotely similar to Zero Escape is the first Life Is Strange, but that game lasts for only 12-15 hours.  Each game in the Zero Escape Trilogy will probably run 15-20+ hours, unless you're really fast with the puzzles.

ZTD provides a mostly satisfying conclusion to the trilogy.  The art and presentation is significantly improved with the third installment, even if the animations can seem a bit robotic. Just be aware that some of the branching plot threads weave and intertwine in impossible ways, so expect to suspend disbelief a bit (e.g. Phi's brooch) and just enjoy the wild ride.

54754550.review:
So after 25 hours of playing this game, I finished it. I have to admit that it was a really random move to buy this game. The images I saw reminded me of the movie Saw and made me get the game during sale. Honestly i could've never expected the game to be this challenging/difficult/deep as it is/was.

I wasn't familiar with the zero escape series so the beginning of the game was a bit random and strange for me since the characters were mentioning previous events, but a lot of it was explained to me later in the game. Also the way the game works is a bit strange; you'll shift between different segments/fragments and doing specific actions in a specific fragment unlocks another one - etc. etc. The thing is that all these segments and fragments are non-chronological so the game asks a lot of attention and investment from you (but believe me, it's worth it in the end).

The game exists out of a lot of cinematic clips, making choices and finding your way out of rooms by completing puzzles. The last one was what made the game interesting for me. The puzzle rooms are really fun to complete even though some are really hard and completing them without pen and paper or calculator is almost impossible. Also the choices you have to make at the end of each room and their results kept me at the edge of my seat.

The storyline is really deep and sometimes confusing but if you invest some time and perhaps write some crucial things down, then you''ll get the hang of it. 

I never expected this game to be as much fun as i had with it. I strongly recommend anyone who likes a good story driven game with puzzles and a decent amount of gore to buy this game. You won't regret it!

54750514.review: Continuing from the cliffhanger ending of Virtue's Last Reward, this game was supposed to answer the mysteries that game set up. Long story short, this game does not do that. Nothing of any real importance happens by the end; the vast, vast majority of the playtime is spent watching pointless, gruesome deaths that are undercut by the limited animation. The Fragment system, which allows players to see most of the story in any order they choose, destroys the pacing of the story because the tension is constantly being built up, then reset once it becomes time to move to a different fragment. By the time the mercy of god lets you reach the end, you still don't even get a proper conclusion to VLR's setup; ZTD instead sets up an even bigger threat for a 4th game. My theory is that the team ended the story this way because the budget didn't allow them to end it the way they planned, but that doesn't stop the game from feeling like filler. The game isn't unplayably bad, its just mostly a waste of time.

54314251.review:
[i]Zero Time Dilemma[/i] is obviously the weakest game in the Zero Escape trilogy. Still, for people who played both Nonary Games, it probably merits a play.

More than 999 and VLR, ZTD focuses on moral choices and their consequences, with a darker presentation. For me, this was the game's strongest aspect—crises manufactured to force the player to make the hard choices themselves. (Of course, player choice is a theme in Zero Escape, but ZTD steps it [b]way[/b] up.) At one point (in the "Fire" fragment, for those who are curious), my decision made me hold my hand up to my open mouth and stare for a while. In place of mechanisms like digital roots or color combinations, player decisions (and by extension, timeline divergences) revolve around these choices. Characters remain in separate groups of 3, but the player plays as all three group leaders throughout the story.

But for this one strength of [i]Zero Time Dilemma[/i], there are a plethora of weaknesses. Unfortunately, the game's structure and plot are disappointing. Basically, you're unaware of the structure of the narrative at the beginning, and have to fill it in yourself in fragments. You don't know where a fragment fits into the flowchart until you've completed it. This is an interesting idea, but it obviously takes a lot of precision to implement well, especially when the narrative heavily includes branching plotlines. There were too many points where I was at a loss for what to do to open up more of the flowchart. Then, beyond just the structure of the narrative, its actual contents really don't have a saving grace. It was messy, it was confusing, and it was even a bit frustrating. 999 is a great game with a self-contained plot. While VLR is clearly a different game than 999 with a higher-stakes plot, it at least made sense. Frankly, ZTD hardly feels like a member of the Zero Escape series to me.

The story in this game, in a big transition from other games, is presented in 3D-animated voice-acted cutscenes. This could be a plus or a minus for you, depending on preference. Fast readers won't always want to wait for the VA, not to mention that it isn't great in the first place. Subtitle readers will also have to deal with the occasional typo and misread line. However, the added depth of animation partially makes up for it, even if it is stilted at times. As for the puzzle rooms, they were good fun, but I still contend that 999 is the best in that regard. And, in my opinion, the soundtrack is good. Somehow they made "Clarification" an even better track than in VLR.

In short, the game is only worth playing if you're eager to understand how the loose ends from VLR tie up. If that's your aim, though, you'd do just as well to read a synopsis and save yourself 30 hours of mediocre gaming. So if you buy, just don't expect a masterpiece. And if you're new to the series—play 999 for sure, and play VLR if you want, but don't play ZTD.

54044558.review:
I can't recommend this game generally but anybody who's played the previous two should suffer through, if only to experience the nadir of interactive storytelling. I won't spoil the big plot twist in this game, but it is by a large margin the most stupid thing that I have seen in a videogame. It is not just sub-David Cage tier, but several strata beneath that. 

The escape rooms were bad. They've always been bad, and to be honest this series has desperately been in need of an option to skip them entirely from the start. Outside of a few puzzles they all amount to busywork, solving very basic problems in a roundabout kind of way, and pixel-hunting. They're frontloaded here, you can finish all but one immediately and then it's nothing but story. 

One character really sucks, but if you like ironically enjoying bad things then you might like him the most. I did. 

In the end - and again, without spoilers - there are so many questions left unanswered. Some extremely basic questions. Fundamental questions. Despite this, the game will waste a lot of your time explaining basic things to you. This is the sort of game where a character can be reminded of an anagram and say, "I remember, the anagram. An anagram is where you rearrange the letters to spell something else" and have it not be a joke. They're happy to rely on the worst kind of sci-fi gibberish to explain things at the writers' convenience, though,

I could only really recommend this series to people who will play any old anime trash. I'm one of those. I would first recommend playing something good, like Danganronpa, but if you're finished with good games then play Zero Escape.

54015800.review:
Me ha gustado, pero no lo recomendaría en general. 

Mi mayor queja es que el juego tiene escenas de diálogo mucho más largas que el tiempo de juego actual. Podría ser una película de anime, pero se trataría de una película lenta la mayor parte del tiempo.


PROS:

La interacción del juego está en dos áreas, la navegación por los fragmentos de las historias y las habitaciones de escape.

+ El juego lleva unas 4 historias paralelas (la misma historia pero con variaciones en las muertes y los sucesos), cada historia formada por una serie de fragmentos que se juegan en un orden desorganizado. (Al principio parece bastante lioso y confuso, pero cuando desbloqueas varios, empiezas a ver el patrón y la coherencia de los mismos). Los fragmentos se van desbloqueando por las decisiones que se toman en ellos (puedes re-jugar las decisiones para escoger una diferente y desbloquear más fragmentos). Está muy bien, aunque algunas decisiones son complicadas porque necesitas información que consigues más adelante o en diferentes historias, (con soluciones bastante sutíles como un número largo dicho durante una escena o una palabra dicha ahí perdida durante la trama) así que se quedan bloqueos algo difíciles.

+ Las habitaciones de escape están muy bien, son habitaciones llenas de puzzles que hay que resolver, muy al estilo de las aventuras gráficas de los 90. La pena es que son pocas (¿unas 13?) y muy distanciadas entre tantas cinemáticas.

+ La historia que sigue a los 9 personajes, Está entretenida también, y los personajes también están bien. En gráficos es simplón (creo que el juego se hizo originalmente para una consola más pequeña) pero el estilo manga encaja bien y le da un aire característico.

CONTRAS:

x La jugabilidad está limitada. (Más tiempo viendo escenas que jugando).

x Sin rejugabilidad. Una vez se han desbloqueado todos los fragmentos, es el final del juego y el 100% de los logros.

53996031.review:
Set between the first two games, the story is intreiguing and immersive as always, though the Flow layout is different. You have 3 player characters now instead of one and switch between the three to play the Decision Game. Each time you go to make a decision, one of your team advocates one option, while your final team-mate pushes for the other. Sometimes to the detriment of lives. Escape room puzzles are sometimes difficult, but for the most part I didn't need too many hints.

The new characters are interesting and returning ones have more information about them revealed, though I really can't bring myself to like Eric on any level. I do like Carlos though. Simple motivation, obvious Red Ranger type.

My main criticisms are that the 3D models don't lip sync very well in the English language version, as well as have their textures clip. Often girl's hair is partially inside their back, which is a little saddening when this is mostly seen during cut scenes. The English Voice Acting also has it's ups and downs. Much of the text is read well, however I come across moments where two characters are in heated discussion and one VA obviously hasn't had that memo, or doesn't have a Voice Director on hand because the lines they offer are flat, or expressing a different emotion than should be expected.

All in all, it's a good game, but I'd recommend buying it on sale.

Zero Time Dilemma (ZTD) is the finale of the Zero Escape trilogy, started by the great 999 and followed up by the - IMHO even better  - Virtue's Last Reward.
Games I would give 8/10 and 9/10 respectively, with ingenious writing, great puzzles and natural feeling controls.

ZTE is at no point on the level of its predecessors, the puzzles are still enjoyable and far from bad, but the story and the great plot twists the series so far was known far is nowhere to be seen.
On top of all that I cannot overstate how [b]f*cking[/b] atrocious the quality of the port is.
If you have a Playstation Vita or a 3DS (more likely I assume) buy it there. It doesn't really matter you pay more there.
This port is horseshit.

The game itself I could give a 6/10, but due to the port being buggy, having horrible controls and showing controller inputs WHILE NOT EVEN SUPPORTING A CONTROLLER APPARENTLY (tested with Nintendo Switch Pro Controller)...

The big plot twists - something both 999 and VLR managed to do such a good job with - were hit and miss, one was well orchestrated - even if not on the level of the twists from 999 and VLR - but the other big one about the identity of Zero II was just... bad. I want to say so many words on HOW bad, but I don't think I could do it justice, that's how bad it was. Worst plottwist I've ever witnessed.

While it seems like the story is going to be as good as the previous games, it turns out to be one of the weakest in the trilogy. The ending seemed rushed to find a conclusion and offered minimal closure for just a handful of characters from the series. There are also quite a few story paths that feel meaningless and don't add to the overall story or development of the characters. I actually don't mind the twists about the main villain that seemed to come out of nowhere. There are actually quite a few hints, they are just a bit too well hidden. Speaking of the main villain, quite a few of his English lines have very hammy deliveries. There are quite a few other weak/weird lines in the English dub as well.
On the technical side the animations are all very stiff and limited. For some reason I could only access the menu with the memo and save buttons by tabing out and tabing back in and clicking on them for some reason while playing in windowed mode.
Overall, while not the worst way to end a cult-classic series, it could have been a lot better. I'm just glad this game came out at all and we have some sort of conclusion to the cliff-hanger ending of the second game.

51055787.review:
I bought this game in a bundle with the first two Zero Escape entries, assuming that if I liked The Nonary Games, I would also like this. I was turned off of playing this after a mere few minutes, so keep in mind that I have made no substantial progress in the game and can only rag on the presentation. The visual novel aspects of the first games has been replaced with something more like an interactive movie, where you have to wait for each character to fully say their lines and automatically progress, which is fine if you want a movie but I personally can't stand being forced to wait. I want to read at my own pace even if it means cutting off dialogue mid-sentence because I've already read it. If you play visual novels the same way I do, you can't do it for this game, and if you enable the option to skip text, it skips multiple lines at a time, and the only way to read them is to go back in the log, at which point you're better off looking up a transcript of the game online. My last complaint is the character models. As other people have stated they are poorly animated and I personally find them unbearably slow. The mouth movements are not the least bit synced with the dialogue, and the textures are so low-res that I'd prefer the look of VLR.
But if you reaaaaally want to know what happens after the first two games then that may outweigh your complaints, but it didn't outweigh mine.

51042178.review:
[h1] Pros: [/h1]

+ The conclusion to the Zero Escape saga...? It clears the major plot points set from the first two games, although some questions still very much remain at the conclusion.

+ The visual style of 0E: ZTD is a huge improvement over the last game, trading the DeviantArt inspired models for a much more satisfying outlined, Catherine-esque style. Most characters look much more improved in this style.

+ Some of the puzzles are at their most difficult in this sequel, with one room in particular being a considerable challenge.

+ The most brutal entry in the series, one that doesn't shy away from actually showing you the violence (although it does have moments where it pans away from scenes as they happen for animation reasons).

+ Voice acting is, imo, at its best in this finale to the series. Some of the voice deliveries are very well done for the scenes.

[h1] Cons: [/h1]

- While I feel satisfied with the actual ending of the series, I feel a lot of irritation at how they explained away several glaring issues with the series. The final reveal of who Zero is is very weak and pulled out of thin air, but with the air of a "GOtchya!". Several issues with the story aren't explained adequately, the time travel gets extremely convoluted, and the spiritual direction the game takes is irritating when compared to the grounded story of the first game.

- The game has a confusing and convoluted progression system that ruins pacing. Fragmented story was, honestly, not a great idea. It fits into the story thematically and they give a very good explanation for it, but overall the structure of how you experience the story destroys a lot of the pacing. For instance, one of the things you MUST do to unlock all the relevant endings is to experience all the outcomes of a vote. BUT, it's not immediately clear that you need to do so, and it is not immediately clear how you go about restarting the vote. You need to do the vote and then immediately swap to another perspective before you pass out. It's asinine. It also took a lot of the impact out of choices. 

- Despite a higher visual quality, ZTD has absolutely, positively, unquestionably the worst fucking animation I've ever seen in a videogame. Somehow it managed to beat VLR in terms of having the most lazy animation possible. Every scene is acted out as if it's the person's first time animating in 3D Space, with movements looking stiff and cycled. The camera does its best to hide this by panning away, but it fails to really hide how bad it is. What's more, truly emotional scenes happen and are brilliantly acted out by the Voice Actors, yet all of the emotion is sucked out of it simply due to how badly the scenes are animated.

- Many of the player models (Zero especially) have a really low texture quality. 

- Music feels much more... weak, in this entry. In particular the one that plays for C Team, mostly when Junpei talks about how hard his life has been. It all feels incredibly cheesy and annoying.

- Some characters are written very oddly, in particular Junpei.

[h1] Overall: [/h1]

I only recommend this game under the following:

1. You played 1 & 2 and desperately need to know what happens next.
2. This game is on sale.

The animation quality is enough to make me hate how this game was handled. There is a lot of potential in the 0E series that is woefully wasted here. Somehow, I feel as though it is the worst in the series, with the first game (The Nonary Game) being the best. So, f you are invested in 1&2's story, you HAVE to play 3 to see where the crazy train was going. But otherwise, I do not recommend it, especially not at full price.

50980778.review:
Zero Time Dilemma is a fantastic conclusion to the Zero Escape trilogy. 

Much like VLR there is little horror [i]per se[/i] here, and a huge, sprawling story to explore and enjoy. Whilst overall the main endings aren’t all as satisfying as they were in VLR or 999, there is notably more of them, and I found that the bad endings in ZTD were actually more significant than in VLR or 999, so it balances out somewhat. 

ZTD also avoids the slight issue VLR had with repetition, although at the cost of its interface being a little confusing at first thought. It is easier to be lost in ZTD than either of the previous two games, and it’s flowchart, although initially appearing similar to VLR, is considerably more complicated. There are alternate methods of viewing the timeline in ZTD which assist with understanding the timeline.

I can’t stress enough just how fantastic the story is, bringing just as many surprises as VLR.  It also ties together the trilogy, in particular answering unanswered questions from VLR. The final ending in ZTD could be seen by some to be a little underwhelming – personally I didn’t think that but I know others did so I thought it worth mentioning. There are after game files that offset that, if you have that reaction.

If you enjoyed 999 and VLR, you should definitely play ZTD. It was an amazing end to the Zero Escape Trilogy. Feels like I’ve come to the end of a journey that I never wanted to end.

Deciding whether to recommend [b]Zero Escape: Zero Time Dilemma[/b] or not seems harder than any of the choices I had to make in the actual game. Although it is a [b]gratifying end to the trilogy[/b] and it [b]connects seamlessly to its predecessors[/b], the [b]game itself has little value[/b] beyond the player's desire for finding out if our well-known heroes have suceeded in their mission. Due to a [b]severe downgrade of the flowchart interface[/b], [b][i]Zero Time Dilemma[/i][/b] does not feel organic nor coherent, even if said remodelation had an intended narrative value. As such, [b]dramatic moments are undermined by choppy cutscenes[/b], leaving you temporarily unfulfilled until you meet all the requirements to further the story. Not only that: the [b]escape rooms also take a [i]considerable[/i] blow[/b], with [b]puzzles[/b] that are [b]annoyingly easy[/b] and pose no challenge whatsoever - a [i]massive[/i] letdown considering this was one of the main attractions past installments relied heavily on. As for character design, it is fair to say they did [b]polish their 3d models[/b]. However, [b]animated scenes[/b] are [b]extremely clunky, [i]almost[/i] robot-like[/b] - and often become [b]unnecessary gorefests[/b] - so the overall pay-off for this art style improvement is questionable. Oh, and forget about playing with your [b]controller[/b]: it is likely it [b][i]may[/i] not be compatible[/b]! 
For the longest time, I wondered why [b]Zero Escape: Zero Time Dilemma[/b] was not part of a [b][i]Zero Escape[/i][/b] trilogy pack despite being about the same price as its prequels bunched together. Now it seems clear [b]it preys on an itch for closure[/b] rather than offering the player a new, refined experience. Is that itch unbearable? Wait for it to go on sale for [i]at least[/i] half price, and bear in mind, [b]that scratch is all you are getting[/b].

49921313.review:
Perhaps too concerned with meeting the expectations of the series' enthusiastic, niche fanbase, [i]Zero Time Dilemma[/i] made a lot of bold, bad decisions, not only diverging from the time-tested qualities of its predecessors, but also running them over with a lawn-mower.

Most of the plot can be described as "fumbling [i]in media res[/i]." Rather than a navigating a branching yet still chronological storyline, the player jumps between discrete, out-of-context scenes and puzzle rooms called Fragments. The characters wear bracelets which knock them out and erase their memory at 90-minute intervals, so every scene starts with them waking up in a new place with knowledge of the game in general, but no memory of the previous scenes.

The Fragment system is definitely the game's Achilles' heel. While it may seem at first like a highly personalized way of delivering a story — every player will experience it in a different order! — the developers probably realized that, in a game that relies so much on plot twists for emotional impact, it'd probably be a bad idea to let some players accidentally bump into a plot-crucial revelation, without any context, right at the beginning. (They did not follow this realization to its logical conclusion, that the entire Fragment system is lousy, but I digress.)

Their solution was to arbitrarily limit the scenes you can access by delivering them in sets. You have to explore every option in a single set (including every gameover) before unlocking the next one. The result is, ironically, a system that seems even [i]less[/i] personal than simple chronological decision-making, and more like crossing items off a shopping list. It doesn't matter which Fragments you pick when; you do all of them because you have to. And if that's the case, what is even the point?

The Fragment system ultimately ends up undoing a lot of the series' characteristic strengths which [i]Zero Time Dilemma[/i] might otherwise have been able to rely on. For one thing, cutting the puzzles off from the rest of the story really emphasizes the disconnect between gruesome horror and off-beat humor (usually reserved for puzzle flavor text), making the latter seem out of place.

There's no longer a single point-of-view character. Furthermore, the character teams for puzzle rooms are also always the same, meaning that not only are you likely to be stuck with someone you dislike in every puzzle, but the group dynamics are almost identical, which becomes increasingly obvious whenever you're forced to repeat the same Fragment with all three teams. Each has a leader, a chaotic neutral guy, and a girl who will have an extensive reaction to any moral choice you make. In the case of Akane and Phi, this is to explain that you're a horrible person every time you press the kill-your-friends button, which is not great when you're required to press the kill-your-friends button to get the next set of Fragments.

Rather than starting with a puzzle, the opening is about 20 minutes of repetitive Fragment cutscenes. None of the branch endings are very climactic, since you're stuck ping-ponging through out-of-context scenes in order to reach them.

And of course, a lack of context between scenes makes bad, over-the-top twists even harder to swallow.

[i]Virtue's Last Reward[/i] introduced a lot of revelations that greatly exceeded in magnitude those of the first game. [i]Zero Time Dilemma[/i], attempting the same on an exponential scale, was left to scrape the absolute bottom of the barrel for interesting plot twists. As a result, [i]Zero Time Dilemma[/i] a lot like [i]Professor Layton and the Azran Legacy[/i], in that it's not only bad, it's so series-crunchingly bad that it also actively sabotages your love of the games that were actually good.

There are many ways ZTD does this, including such bleach-your-brain twists as [spoiler]Phi being Sigma's daughter, the entirety of of VLR being a bad end of one ZTD timeline, and a bad memory-wipe retcon for Tenmyouji's character arc[/spoiler], but the biggest offender is its handling of Akane and Junpei, who, now sporting purple hairdos, only vaguely resemble their former selves.

Apparently, during the time Junpei spent with Seven searching for Akane in the criminal underground(???), he witnessed such Traumatic Events™ that he claims to have lost faith in humanity and is now an alcoholic. He's "done playing the action hero." Needless to say, [url=https://i.kym-cdn.com/photos/images/original/001/143/657/d0b.jpg]this image of him as Junpei the Epser[/url] is no exaggeration.

Meanwhile, Akane has been vacuum-pressed into a generic anime heroine who is at times grossly cutesy, overly maudlin, self-righteous, and yes, even yandere.

Glancing at the early concept art and profiles included in the DLC artbook, I can kind of see what they were going for (I might have called Junpei's original outfit "lovably dumb"; the developers opted for "childish"), but the result is two mass-marketed, unlikable iterations of erstwhile charming and morally complex characters. They are so unrecognizable that the opening cutscene spends an awkward beat just revealing their identities.

I can imagine this game might be enjoyable if it wasn't also a disappointment. The promotional art and [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WzNS8Ah139Y]the music[/url] is good. It might be a worthwhile purchase for people who have never played Zero Escape and have really low expectations.

For series veterans, don't bother for any reason. Any questions you have regarding Kyle, Dio, Snake, or Santa will not get answered. In fact, your time is probably better spent looking at [url=https://www.shutterstock.com/image-illustration/3d-render-beefburger-wheels-197855378]this picture of a hamburger[/url]. Enjoy!

49287044.review:
I liked VLR so much, I bought Zero Time Dilemma without even waiting for a sale. Life is unfair, isn't it?

The story: is abysmal.
There are 30 minutes to an hour of puzzles, then 19 hours of nothing and it ends. Well okay, Team D's story was good, and I liked that a certain character from VLR phi-nally got a backstory, but that's like a quarter of the game. The rest is basically a rehash of the previous games, but way slower and wordier. Yep. This game is more wordy than 999. They introduced so many interesting ideas and then did absolutely nothing with them. You may have also heard about the game having an awful ending. That's only half correct. It's awful, but there isn't an ending. And I don't mean "Ooo, I wonder what happened. I hope there's a sequel that explains what character xyz did." I mean like "Well this ties up zero of the plot threads and answers zero of the questions. Is that where Zero got his name?" And this is coming from someone who liked VLR's ending. And the plot holes. Oh laaaawd the plot holes! I can't go into any more detail without getting spoilery, so let's move on to...

The characters: are utterly unlikable.
4 old faces join 5 new playable characters. I dislike the new Junpei (why did they make him so wanksty?) and ACTIVELY HATE every single character from Team Q. Zero II being whinier than Tidus didn't help matters, either.

The gameplay: is bad.
I liked 3 of the puzzle chambers, of which there are only 13. And then there's Biolab. When was the last time YOU played a point-and-click adventure that was nigh-uncontrollable? You only need to be able to do two things: point and click.

The presentation: is horrific.
What is wrong with their faces? It's like they attempted cel-shading but missed by a country mile. And the characters expressions are all so...wrong. Is this what low-functioning spectrumfolk see when they try to interpret emotions?

TL;DR: look up something along the lines of "Zero Escape wiki Phi" online, repeat for Diana, watch the 10 hour version of nyan cat twice, then donate 40 USD to a charity (I recommend Doctors Without Borders). You'll get basically the same result, but you'll also give money to people who actually deserve it.

48534627.review:
Where do I even start with this game? Truly, when I review a game, I can usually say what is so good or so bad about it, but not with this game. This game messed with my head too much for me to say what's so great about it, but hell if I won't try.
The time travel elements within this series floors me every time; this game is no different. It seemed a little bit overwhelming at first with so many timeline fragments opening at once, but it's more straightforward than it seemed. The idea of involving how the player will retain information from different timelines in a way where the characters are aware that they know things they shouldn't is utterly fascinating, and something I've loved throughout the series.
This game builds upon the previous two, ramping up the mind-heckery and the existential dread. With the new premise being that *6 of the 9 trapped people* have to die for the others to escape, it kinda makes the player think "How the hell do I get all of them out alive then?" What I love about this game, and the predecessors, is how it makes you go through *failure after failure* before reaching that point of an epiphany.
Gameplay-wise, the puzzles are really fun and engaging, as well as difficult! You shouldn't have too much trouble as long as you're *observant*. I missed a bottle of water and that left me searching around the room for an extra 10 minutes just to find it. A lot of the time, the puzzles gave off the same epiphany like satisfaction that I mentioned before.
As for cons, I can't name off too many. I had trouble running the game after my first time running it, but was able to play after disabling anti-aliasing (MSAA). Otherwise with the core game, I can say there were some mouth synchronization issues, as well as kinda weak animation at certain points.
TL;DR This game is a fantastic time travel, mind-hecking, psychological horror with great puzzles, and a conclusion to the series that I enjoyed.

48525981.review:
Zero Time Dilemma, the third game in the Zero Escape series, is very similar to its predecessors. They are each suspenseful visual novels about a group of people trapped in a bunker and forced to play mind games to the death. The Zero Escape series are among the best visual novels because they:
- have branching storylines which have vitually no shared content between them.
- have multiple endings which each give you a different point of view or insight on the main plot.
- each include of a flowchat which allows you to easily skip back to any decision so you can explore other paths.
- have escape room like segments which force you to think and add a bit of interactivity.
- each have a mysterious Zero antagonist whose secret identity keeps you guessing until the very end.

That being said, I feel that Zero Time Dilemma is the worst game of the series because:
- I felt that the "decision game", the main mind game featured in Zero Time Dilemma, is not as interesting intellectually as the main mind games in the previous installments for the series (the Nonary Game and the Ambidex Game).
- The identity of Zero II, this entry's main antagonist, was not as interesting or exciting as the identity of the main antagonist for previous installments. The flip side of this, however, is that his identity was at least original (was not a reused, rehashed idea from a previous Zero Escape game).
- The plot started up too quickly (there was less confusion among the characters and lead up to the situation than I expected and was in previous installments), which might overwhelm players who have not played the first two Zero Escape games.
- The plot was even more complex than previous entries due to the heavy use of science fiction elements.
- The characters sometimes looked stiff and unrealistic when moving and their mouth movements did not always match up with what they were saying.

Despite these downsides, it did have some advantages over the other games in the series:
- The cutscenes were all done using 3D models, which was both a technological step-up and an interesting art departure from the previous installments.
- For some decisions, you are given a box to put a character's name into. This allows for many different and creative answers, many more than could be done realistically with multiple choice.
- It wrapped up most of the plot holes between the first and second games in the series.

Though I liked the previous games in the series better, I enjoyed Zero Time Dilemma overall and would recommended it to friends, especially those which have played the first two installments in the Zero Escape series.
