46685741.review:
[Spoilers ]

I've spent the better part of a month replaying the trilogy and I'm still in awe, even after all these years. Truly the best sci-fi / plot twist based games ever, and ZTD was more than satisfactory, despite leaving things a little unanswered.

This is less a review and more of a reply to not only the naysayers, but myself from 2 years ago.

I still liked the game during its release, and wasn't as frustrated as the vocal minority back then that still spew their hatred on reddit and tumblr. However, outside of gameplay and artistic elements, there were story points that really didn't sit well with me, namely:

[spoiler] Eric and Mira were terrible
The big reveal of Delta was cheap and not that great of a plot twist 
Junpei and Akane's actions seemed really off.
The romance between Junpei and Akane seemed unsatisfying
Delta being the true mastermind of the series kinda hurt, after the game seemed to set Akane up as the mastermind.
The introduction of alien technology and Delta's mindhacking seemed a little deus ex machina and ill explained
The ending could've been more conclusive[/spoiler]

After playing through for a second time, I believe I only still have a problem with the first two

[spoiler] Eric is still the worst character in the entire series. Completely void of any character and inspires zero empathy. Mira is interesting in only what her actions provide, but she's still bad. In fact, they were essentially just the fodder required to make up the 9 players.

In retrospect, the reveal wasn't cheap, and was kinda well foreshadowed. It just wasn't that good. And honestly felt really try hard for a plot twist. We already had the hidden "Zero" amongst the cast with K and his suit in VLR, and Sigma being Zero.

As for the rest, I'm now satisfied. Playing through 999 and VLR gave enough context to make me realize Junpei was always kind of a jerk when his back was against the wall. And Akane was always the manipulative type to achieve her goals. And there was enough to assume both of them felt the same way toward each other

After a second playthrough, I'm more warm to Delta as the big bad/good. Akane ruled with her own brilliance in "that" timeline, and her actions were necessary. But the history and conundrum Delta was presented with is equally as interesting, and his implementation, eben if left with holes, is somewhat hard to deny.

I still believe the transporter pod was conceived specifically for making the series work, and is therefore a little desu ex machina. But it still makes complete sense, and in a universe where morphegenetic fields and "unlimited universes and possibilities" exist, it seems daft to deny somehwere, there was such an item.

The ending could have been better, and I think closure should have been brought further to the fore. But I also liked leaving it open ended. After all, the entire point of the series to this point is, there are unlimited possibilities. This gives the player a chance to come up with their own ending with the characters they love.

[/spoiler]

Gameplay wise... this is probably weaker than VLR. The flowchart and AB game narrative device from VLR was vastly superior. The puzzle rooms were also stronger in VLR. SOme of the rooms in ZTD were fun, but some were also obnoxious and full of vague half hints. And let's not deny... the animation here is absolutely godawful. Thank god the voice acting was pretty good.

So, yeah, such a great game. I no longer have any time for people that feel other wise. It seems like they had a version in their head long before ZTD was released and couldn't accept it. Maybe they should SHIFT to another timeline where Uchikoshi wrote a different Zero Time Dilemma.

This is going to be a short review. Many others say here that Zero Time Dilemma is the weakest episode of the Zero Escape trilogy.  I think they are very wrong.  It is by far the best among three excellent games.

So if you can scrape together about 70 free hours and are willing to follow a complex story with some deep concepts, told in a very unusual way, you should not miss the Zero Escape trilogy.

44605630.review:
This... is really just a good game in terms of story, as a follow-up to the previous two games in [i]Zero Escape: the Nonary Games[/i]. Though the ending leaves mixed feelings, there is a lot more clarity off of the second game in regards to what has happened, what will happen, what we need to try to do. Like the other games, it was good at providing interest in the characters as well, though they certainly didn't shy away from the time travel elements yet again, more present than ever.

In that way I need to recommend it, but there are some major aspects holding it back. Some people say that the Zero Escape series should never have moved on from 2D storytelling. With this game I can most definitely see that complaint. While the 3D art in [i]Virtue's Last Reward[/i] was passable, at least apart from some cutscenes, the 3D work here was much more noticably lacking by way of syncing dialogue with lip flaps, the 3D models clipping over bits of themselves, and overall just being more lacking by way of facial expressions. There are a couple truly psychotic characters though, so I'd be lying if I didn't say it worked in their favor sometimes.

I also greatly dislike the "fragments" gameplay mechanic, in which the player doesn't know in when or within which timeline they have chosen to play through, until the story fragment has reached one conclusion or another. In fact, I was once stuck for more fragments to unlock because I didn't realize that one branch's ending had multiple results of one decision that was left up to chance. 

This is a lot more confusing and creates less coherant of a story than the previous games, which allow you to follow a timeline beginning to end with the decisions you make, later providing you the option to simply go back and change your decisions to reach a different conclusion. This decision could be used to create some mysetery in that you aren't following a single protagonist anymore but switch your perspective between the different groups, so information is withheld this way. Needless to say, for the game to simply follow one character would have been much simpler for the player to have blinders on and not be as informed on what happened around them. It was a fair method to exercise, but came at the cost of the experience of the player in my opinion.

But, if you made it this far in the series? You want to know the conclusion to Zero Escape. What happened those years ago with the spread of Radical-6? In one form or another, you finally get to see.

[b][u]NOTE: I would highly recommend playing the previous entries to the Zero Escape Series (999 and Virtue's Last Reward OR Zero Escape: The Nonary Games [which has both]) In release order, to get the best experience out of Zero Time Dllemma.[/u][/b]
TL:DR: Might not look or be as well rounded as the other two games in the series but still a good series finale.

Full opinion: While I still liked Zero Time Dilemma, it felt less put together than the other two, and two major reasons for that are that the game jumps from the Visual Novel format of the previous two games to cutscenes and cinematics, and that many of the major plot twists, though not the biggest ones, were hinted at too much, lessening their impact when they were supposed to hit. As for the cinematics, you'd think it'd be a step up from the traditional portrait-text-occasional-CG affair, and while it is used rather interestingly in the game, the animations [which are stiff, unnatural and very limited (You never see characters start/stop running, interacting with the environment without a cutaway, get killed off on-screen, etc.)] and the visual presentation of the game brings it down significantly. If it wasn't trying to compensate for the Nintendo 3DS, which was what this game was also released onto [As well as the PSVita and the PS4], it probably would've hit a lot harder with the attempt of a more realistic presentation.

That being said, it is still very much Zero Escape, with all the puzzles, plot twists and everything being (mostly) consistent with the other games. The story itself is enjoyable for the most part, even though there are a few points that I feel could use a bit of polish. The rooms' puzzles are more difficult at points than previous installments, however, to the point where I have a notebook filled with tiny pages of notes for rooms and the info certain scenes contained. When it comes to game-critical password entry screens, info can be hidden almost anywhere. By the time you get to the near-end of the game with only a few endings left to go, you'll still be asking too many more questions than is necessary [in my opinion at least]. The gameplay itself is solid though, and the story managed to surprise me several times. It might not be the best way for a series to end, but it's still a good send-off in my opinion.

43751411.review:
If you're not familiar with the Zero Escape series, Zero Time Dilemma is the 3rd installment of it and you should NOT play this before you play the first two. They are on Steam, Zero Escape: The Nonary Games, and they are fucking amazing.

Now onto this game and how it concludes this trilogy.

While serviceable, ZTD never quites reach the quality of the 2 previous games. What bothered me the most was the animation and 3D models. The first game had the characters drawn in a nice anime style with pre-rendered backgrounds. This worked the best in my opinion and the game looked great. In the 2nd game, they moved to 3D model of the characters, and, maybe it was because I played that in the small screen of a 3DS, it looked fine.

But, playing ZTR in a 24 inch full HD screen, it just looks BAD. Even more disappointingly when you see the amazing art Rui Tomono had for the characters. The animations are stiff and the characters non-emotive. There's one scene where I had no idea if Diana was afraid or giggling, that's how bad it is. 

So, the game functions similar to the 2nd game, Virtue's Last Reward, where you live, you die, you live again, this time in a different timeline where you made different choices. Using the knowledge of all different timelines you can reach the game's true ending. But honestly, it's not as good as the 2nd game mostly because it get's stale. In the 2nd game that was the whole gimmick, and you, the player, shifted together with Sigma, the protagonist. You really felt in the character's shoes, trying to fix the horrible situation they were in by trial-and-error in different timelines. 

Now, basically everyone can shift, and it just feels like you're playing a videogame and checking out wherever this path leads you before you try again with a different choice. "But you're playing a videogame!", yeah, but isn't great when you immerse yourself into a game so much, you forget you're playing one? That's what the second game does and the third game fails. 

Moving on, and before I talk about the plot, if you have played the The Nonary Games and is wondering if you should play this one the answer is YES. It should be obvious since my review is a thumbs-up, but I understand some people might be confused after I did nothing but trash the game up to this point. So let's talk about the plot and this means, spoilers!

The story is good as an ending to the Zero Escape Trilogy, but as a standalone, it's by far the weakest of the three. It get's much better during the 2nd half, after you finish all the puzzle rooms, but the beginning is such a chore. Since you can't blow your load and reveal all the mysteries, they spend some time developing the characters for mixed results. Eric is, by far, the worst character in the entire trilogy, Junpei is going through an weird phase, much more cynical than his previous appearances, and... yeah, I guess everyone else is fine. The biggest problem is caused by the separation of the cast. Unlike previous games, you only have 3 people interacting with each other for most of the game and again, it gets stale. Oh, here comes another scene of Akane trying to understand why Junpei is such an asshole now. Oh, now Eric is bullying Q again, etc, etc. That's why it gets much better in the second half when the groups start to meet each other.

The mysteries and revelations are good, but never quite pack the emotional punch of 999s twist or the mind bending of VLR. Still, it's good, it's just not as good. Which I guess isn't really something to be shameful of, you can't expect that level of quality being reached in every game. Even Phoenix Wright had it's low points.

43719582.review:
I am not a newcomer to this series, and I loved 999 and Zero Escape. Finishing ZTD was a nice send-off to the series and I recommend it to anyone who enjoys puzzles, especially with logic and advanced problem solving-- as well as visual novels. Personally, I suggest playing all of the games in order. I loved seeing old characters return and I feel that someone playing this game without having went through the first two would be a bit lost as to some of the symbolism and long-term meaning of relationships. I love the characters and the building of story and time, so this matters a lot to me, but it may not matter to some people who are just going in to solve the puzzles or try something different. The plot can be a bit overwhelming and kind of a convoluted mess, but that's why I love it.

I do have a few nit-picks about the game-- my primary gripe is with the new fragment/flow system. I don't like how there isn't as much of an organized order to the way that you play, not because I feel like that's vital to the story, but because at some stages in the process I had trouble getting some fragments to unlock unless I played through a cinematic more than once. I feel like this really hindered me getting the purest experience I could of had-- seeing as I had already played through the cinematic once, not sure if it is a bug or just a glitch on my end. It was easily resolved and I was able to finish the game. The only other thing I can complain about is that the teams had different numbers of puzzles to solve, I don't feel like I actually spent a lot of time with Q-Team as compared to the others, but I know that was kind of on purpose. The graphics are not the best, does not sync up with the vocal performance, but all in all this is a charming, puzzling, and lovely game for a conclusion to a series I'm very happy I saw through to the end.

43541226.review:
Zero Escape : Zero Time Dilemma is the conclusion to the Zero Escape trilogy.
Set in the near future, 9 players are forced to play a game , The Decision Game in which the fate of mankind and themselves depend on their actions.

TL;DR This game is still a pretty decent visual novel/adventure game, but relies heavily on the two previous games for plot and pales in comparison as a whole. Its definently worth it for ZE fans who enjoy the franchise and still does a lot of things right.Regardless, playing the previous two games first is a must for those who have not experienced the Zero Escape series besides the fact that the first two can be purchased as a bundle and with a cheaper price tag while being undoubtedly some of the best storytelling experiences in the genre.

Let me just start this review off by saying i am a big fan of the Zero Escape series. The first 2 games of the trilogy are some of the best in the visual novel genre and are probably some of the best written stories in video game history.
That being said , this third game was close to not being a reality due to poor sales and only managed to be made due to demand by loyal fans albeit with a limited budget. I am aware that many fans were thoroughly dissapointed with this installment and to be honest, it was kind of a letdown for me too. Character developtment and writing was a lot more inconsistent and rough but still within acceptable standards. Some of the puzzle elements were just plain unnecessary and frustrating but this applies for all of the Zero Escape games. 
Nevertheless, this game imho is still pretty decent, however compared to the previous two this game probably pales in comparison. Without spoiling too much, most of the characters (especially the returning ones) are pretty enjoyable once you get enough of their backstory and the twists are as mind blowingly absurd as they are in the other games. The unexpected but much darker setting of this game compared to the previous ones was also fitting for the game. It was a hard decision for me at first wheter to recommend this game or not, but i decided that it had done enough things right that the majority of it was a enjoyable and satisfying experience for me and ended up being a fitting conclusion to ZE franchise.
So for those still having doubts about getting this game, dont be disuaded by the negative reviews until youve truly experienced it yourself. 

FINAL VERDICT
(3.5/5)
Sadly it seems like this installment of the series garnered the most public exposure but ended up being pretty mediocre compared to the previous games and undoubtedly caused some to lose interest.
Regardless, this game is a must get for ZE fans but newer players should play the previous two first.

43463280.review:
[h1]No spoilers review[/h1]

If you enjoy visual novels and time traveling stories I highly suggest you to check out Zero Escape series! Make sure to play in the right order, starting from 999 and VLR before playing this one (ZTD).

The animation in ZTD is a bit clunky, but considering the amount of animated scenes (I'd say roughly 20+ hours of animation) in the game it's no wonder and honestly, you do get used to it pretty soon. There was a minor problem with character mouths not always moving when they were speaking (Maybe they all are ventriloquists? Just kidding!)  The gore scenes were, as with the previous games, not very realistic and rather awkward but if you let yourself become immersed with the story they still get to you pretty bad.

I didn't really like the Floating Fragment system and would have preferred to use only the Global Flowchart, yet the game makes it obligatory to use FF in some cases. I got so familiar with the flowchart in VLR that I wanted to continue using it in this one, and the floating fragments had me tearing my hair off in one part of the game when I couldn't figure out why a part of the timeline hadn't opened even though I had done everything required.

The puzzles were nice and sometimes pretty hard as you had to think outside of the box in some of them (which isn't a strength of mine). Make sure to either use the memo feature in the game or take some pen and paper for some serious brainstorming and for writing down clues to progress the game! 

For the people who are looking for a game with lots of gameplay and puzzle solving, this might not be for you. ZTD is mainly a visual novel so if you don't enjoy watching the story for 90% of the time I suggest you skip this series entirely. But for those of you who like a good story, you'll fall head over heels for Zero Escape, 999% guaranteed!

43257571.review:
Score: 7/10
Time to 100%: 20 hours
Similar games: [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/413410/Danganronpa_Trigger_Happy_Havoc/]Danganronpa[/url], [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/288160/The_Room/]The Room[/url]

Do [b]NOT[/b] play this game unless you have played the previous two games; both 999 and Virtue's Last Reward, which can be found in [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/477740/Zero_Escape_The_Nonary_Games/]The Nonary Games[/url] for three main reasons. First, the game doesn't have the same impact, since you won't have a connection to the characters in the same way that you would if you have played pervious games in the series, as about half of the cast are reoccuring. Secondly, the game wouldn't make much sence in certain parts of the story, what the heck do you mean an old mans' brain in a young mans' body from the future?!?! And third, it is the weakest in the series - with the first game being the best. 

Pros:

[b]A Real Mindboggler[/b] - The biggest and most significant aspect of the entire series - the story. It's always been amazing in a weird wonderful way and Zero Time Dilemma is no exception. In true Zero Escape fashion the story only gets weirder, crazier, FASCINATING and harder and harder to explain to another human being the further you progress into it. In Zero Escape style one playthrough isn't enough either, it requires a multiple 100% playthrough in order to fully understand each characters' perspective and the overarching plotline and while this is the third installment of the series, time-wise it's actually the second. Those who finished VLR may already understand why. 

[b]Interesting Characters[/b] - For the most part these characters are interesting. Some are an enigma to be unravelled. Some have their dark issues yet to be revealed. Some are likeable favourites from previous games and some have complete character overhauls. Zero Time Escape have always had intriguing characters throughout the franchise and this is no exception.

[b]Are Puzzles Harder?[/b] - Compared to VLR I actually think the puzzles are a little bit easier, which I found to be okay. I didn't really have any issues with any of the rooms except for maybe one or two - looking at you, weird card puzzle thing - but otherwise I could complete them without having to look up answers or having to go through too much mental gymnastics. Didn't feel like they were too easy either, being spoonfed answers. I will say however that the puzzles do not feel as inventive as they did in the previous games. 

Cons:

[b]Graphics[/b] - Again with these weird old Playstation 2-looking graphics. Didn't work for VLR, doesn't work now. They should have kept the cool looking 2D art style from the first game, personally. 

[b]Pacing[/b] - They talk reaaaaaaaaaaally slowly. Kind of takes some getting used to. Wish they would speed up the tempo, or atleast let me skip ahead.

[b]Unskippable Cutscenes[/b] - There are several cutscenes throughout the game which are shared with multiple characters perspectives. The cutscenes themselves have about 90% similarity through each of them and you have to watch the same thing said from Zero over and over and over again.

[b]Convoluted Timelines[/b] - In the past games, you pick a timeline and you see how it plays out before you go down another. Not in this one. In this one you jump from different universes and at different times. It's very easy to get lost and forget what is happening in a current timeline, it gets a little bit crazy.

Ultimately I definately recommend this for fans of the previous two games as it keeps its CRAZY storylines, characters and wraps up this wild ride known as Zero Escape.

43233556.review:
I have 43 joyful hours invested in the original Nonary Game bundle (999, VLR). I wrote a review for that bundle explaining the brilliance of the storytelling and how engaging and engrossing each game was. I played literally every ending in VLR and then replayed the ones I loved.

This is why it breaks my heart to say that ZTD just does not work. I'm now 6 hours in, and the game rings hollow. From sub-par technical specs to poor writing/script/characterization and disjointed gameplay pacing, this game does not work. The character animation is stiff and the lips do not sync to the dialog resulting in PS2 levels of animatronic stiffness. The voice acting is cringe-inducingly bad for at least 3 of the 9 cast members (including some very important main characters).  The actual written dialogue comes off like a script rather than a conversation between characters. And while I adored the multiple endings of the previous games, the way in which gameplay is fractured into 1000 tiny pieces in ZTD just leaves me feeling like none of it really connects. 

I'm going to force myself to finish this experience out of loyalty to the superb story VLR set up, but I can't really say I've enjoyed myself at all thus far in ZTD. If you aren't a dedicated fan looking to conclude the story set up in the original two Nonary Games, please invest your time and money somewhere else.

42754882.review:
I wish I could recommend this game, I really do, but it just doesn't work for me. When comparing it to the other Zero Escape games, it just doesn't stand up. The first red flag showed up as soon as the game started. It tries to shake up the classic visual novel style by making everything fully modeled and animated, which just did not work. At serious moments, the low quality of the animation and basically nonexistent lip-syncing destroys any tension. They lack if the player acting from the perspective of a single character ruins the sense of immersion that interactive stories should give. And the worst bit, for me at least, is that you can't move to the next line once you finish reading. The pace is slowed to a snail's pace, and I found myself just twiddling my thumbs waiting for the next line. This utterly fails as a VN.
And as for being a Zero Escape game, the character's feel completely messed up. It can be somewhat understandable for some characters, but is just a mockery of others. Heck, they turned Junpie into the polar opposite of his personality in 999. While having a heel is needed, having a good amount of characters who solely exist to piss you off is a horrible decision. Admittedly, I've yet to force myself through the game, so I may not have reached a point where they redeem themselves. But that's the point. I feel like I have to trudge through the game hating the characters at worst, or having little interest in them at best. The only reason I'm compelled to play through is that I'm a big fan of the series and want to see the conclusion of the story.

If you aren't a fan of the series, don't get this game. You won't have a clue what's going on. I would wholeheartedly recommend getting Nonary Games (the bundle of the first two games in the series), with a hesitance of getting this after completing the others. I'm still going to push myself through this, but I can't recommend it to others.

42449530.review:
I don't usually write reviews, but I feel like this needs to be said about the game...

To be honest if this was a game on its own and not a part of the Zero Escape trilogy I probably would have recommended it. It has good music, it's entertaining enough and the non-linear storytelling not only makes sense, but I personally enjoyed it; however, since you obviously have to play the other games to play this one there are some issues that I just can't forgive:

1. The puzzles: the puzzles are fine, maybe easier than the other games but the main issue is how quick the game gives you tips about how to solve them, essentially spoiling the answer.

2. "The Decision Game": it's a boring system compared to 999 and VLR, a lot of the "decisions" aren't even decisions but input a password and most of the time the right and wrong decisions are painfully obvious.

3. The death centered/gory scenes: I don't mind gore in general but this game makes you go through so many surreal and easily avoidable death scenes that it makes you not really care about people dying, whereas the previous game's deaths were shocking, unexpected and meaningful.

3. The characters: without spoiling anything get ready to see certain characters from the other games  be completely different than they were, without any kind of character developement.

4. The story is overall weaker with plot twists already used in the other games, fair amount of plot holes and an ending that could lead to another game even though this is supposed to bring closure to the trilogy.

5. The graphics: I personally don't care about the graphics, this isn't the kind of game i expect mind blowing graphics from, but it is true that I found myself laughing at dramatic or tension-filled moments just because of how bad these were.

I was disappointed by this game, especially with how many positive reviews it has, so maybe the key to liking this game enough to recommend it is not expecting much from it ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

41800660.review:
Much like the two previous games in the series, Zero Time Dilemma offers a simple ontological mystery premise: you are abruptly kidnapped, and wake up in a closed space with a bunch of strangers. A voice informs you that you will be forced to play a life-or-death game consisting of a series of puzzle rooms if you ever want to see daylight again.

As the final chapter in the trilogy, ZTD offers no cushion for new players -- flat-out, do not even attempt to play this game before completing the previous two. Within the first 15 minutes you'll be fatally spoiled for both games, and most of the rest will be a mishmash of nonsense without knowing the rest of the story.

Zero II, the mastermind this time around, is unlike both of the previous Zeros -- he is an absolute monster, and the game is set up to be full of sadistic choices, murder opportunities, and wanton cruelty. ZTD itself is more violent, more bloody, and more cringe-inducing than both of its predecessors combined.

On the plus side, the general quality of the puzzles has improved, and the usual mind@#$@ of these games is taken to whole new levels. Everything mostly hangs together, and even if Zero II doesn't have the depth of character or interest factor of his predecessors, his plotting is just as airtight.

On the minus side, the decision was made to get away from the "visual novel" style and show cutscenes in the form of non-interactive movies. The character graphics are awful, rooted firmly in the Uncanny Valley, and conversations seem briefer in general, lacking the wonderful long tangents into physics and the supernatural of the previous two games. The graphics ruin a couple of scenes that should have been really emotional.

Overall, it ain't as pretty as the earlier games, but if you've already played them and want to find out how this story ends, can you really resist the temptation?

41148857.review:
[h1]Pros:[/h1]
+ Ending to the Zero Escape story.
+ Music
+ Story presentation
+ A bit more gory.

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
- Story itself
- Graphics and UI
- Logic, plot holes and convenient twists (but then again, it's Zero Escape, what did you expect?)

[h1]In-depth:[/h1]
Two things that are important to know before reading this review:
First, I think it goes without saying, but since it's the third game in the series, it's impossible to talk about it without comparing to the others.
Second, this is a review from the perspective of a person, who loves Japanese games and visual novels and can tolerate a lot of their... specifics.

With that said, let's talk about things this game does right.

Music. Obviously. It's pretty much the same, so it is good, as always. Not much more to add here. If you loved it in previous games, you'll love it here.

Story presentation. Without spoiling anything, in previous games you had to finish some routes to progress through others. Here it's a little bit different. You don't follow the routes linearly, nor do you follow only one character. Instead, there are three separate teams and their routes are fragmented, chaotic, and you jump through events along those routes without knowing what is going on or why. At first it may be a bit disorientating, but you know what, it makes sense. It's great, because it fits the theme of the game and the plot. But it's also great because it's incredibly satisfying to piece the story together. I think I enjoyed this way of presentation even more than the way it was done in the other two games.
However it comes with a slight minus. Since you are in direct control of all three teams, you basically always know what they did in certain situation. Which can decrease tension in certain moments, when characters are afraid of decisions the other team makes, while you know exactly what these decisions are.

Now, to the things that aren't so good.

First of all, graphics. It is straight up the ugliest game in the series.
The first one had fantastic animated sprites. The second went semi-3D. Which means while the models were 3D, they were still mostly used in the visual novel style, so no walking around, not many animations overall and thus not many chances to fuck these animations up. And while I personally didn't like the overall style of some characters (#NotMyClover), the models themselves weren't that bad.
This game, however, decided to ditch the visual novel bits and replaced it with fully animated cutscenes. And they are atrocious. The animations were done by an amateur. Lip-sync is virtually non-existent with characters often speaking with their mouths closed. Facial animations are laughable and ruin tension at times with how silly they are. Then there's hair and various objects that clip through characters' bodies. And of course, the textures are as bad as before.
And it's not like you can just ignore this. Because everything that's not a puzzle is these cutscenes now. Awful.

On a plus side, with the game having these cutscenes in fully 3D environments, there is now room for more visual gore. Mind you, the game is still very much censored, there isn't THAT much graphic violence. But there are a few chunks of meat, pools of blood and some other delicious gory stuff that I won't spoil for you. It's nice.

What isn't nice though is the new UI and control scheme.
I played these games back to back. Switching from 1 to 2 was really easy, they barely changed the UI there. But 2 to 3 was kind of a frustrating experience. You can't just right-click to exit menus now, you have to click the "back" button. Annoying, but meh, not a big deal. What's worse though is that you can't reliably skip the dialogue lines. I'm a fast reader, despite English not being my first language. I read A LOT faster than the characters speak their lines. So in visual novels it's always nice to set the speed text to instant and then click through it at your own pace, without waiting for the character to finish talking. Here, however, like I said, the visual novels are replaced with cutscenes. Mind you, you can still skip the lines, but sometimes it skips the whole sections (that are probably tied to animations), which means you have to go back to log and re-read these. This is REALLY frustrating. Not being able to play a visual novel at my own pace is the last thing that I want.

Finally, the story. Again, no spoilers here. But honestly, past the presentation part, I thought it was rather weak. A few reasons for this.
The plot "twists". Some were really obvious, some a bit less so and some were not foreshadowed at all. Like, absolutely 0 indication or clue that this or that would happen. And it's absolutely unacceptable for a mystery novel (or game).
The second game had that little "Easter egg" document in it with quotes from a detective writer about how a good detective story should look like and what it should avoid. Going though this game I was thinking: "How the hell did you manage to add that little bit into your game without reading it yourselves?". It takes practically everything that that author says not to do and does it. Worst of all is - overcomplicating their "scientific" explanations. Sure, Zero Escape series were always full of unnecessary expositions, with first one actually being the worst culprit, but here they are just so dull and unnecessarily overcomplicated (despite being simple in concept), that I was simply sitting there thinking "please, just move on, I can't take it anymore...".
And that's why the remark in the beginning of the review about me loving Japanese games is important. I can deal with a lot of stuff. I don't have issues with, say, for example, 4-hour long intros in Persona series. But Zero Escape (the whole series, not just this game) really tested my patience with these exposition bits.

The culmination was meh. If you've played the previous games you know how they solve all their problems. Spoilers, [spoiler]time travel[/spoiler]. I can't say it's satisfying. In many ways it cheapens the experience and is anticlimactic. Not to mention it was done pretty poorly in some aspects of this story, with characters struggling with moral choice one second and completely ignoring them the other, whenever it's convenient for the plot.

The characters themselves were fine. I mean, it's hard to be worse than in 2nd game.
Junpei's development makes sense. Akane is as frustrating as ever. Sigma is slightly less stupid now that you can't hear his thoughts. Phi is... still Phi. The newcomers are probably the worst (with the exception of Diana, who is amazing). I can't talk much about them without spoiling the game, so I won't. But let's just say that overall development of Q team was a cause of many facepalms during this playthrough.



In conclusion, this is, in my opinion, the worst Zero Escape game. But I still enjoyed it in the end. This game is like that weird relative of yours. Odd, clumsy, a little stupid, but you still love him.

Obviously, I don't recommend this game to anyone who did not play other Zero Escape games. It will make no sense, just don't bother. But if you've played the other two and want just a little extra... well, at this point - why not? You're invested anyway.
If anything, it's worth it just to see Junpei's development. In my opinion, he is one of the more interesting VN protagonists ever.

41054237.review:
Zero Time Dilemma is a fairly controversial game among Zero Escape fans, and for good reason. At its strongest, it's in my opinion the best game in the series - but at its weakest, it's pretty freaking bad and definitely hard to play through. For me, the good parts (especially D-team) were absolutely worth the weaker parts, and it's probably in my top 10 games, despite how much I disliked certain parts of it. 

It's definitely not playable without the previous games, and if you liked 999 better and thought VLR was too over-the-top and fantastic, you will not enjoy Zero Time Dilemma (it's a very over the top game, and also really butchers Junpei and Akane's characters). If you liked VLR more than 999, you'll probably enjoy ZTD - it does a great job with Sigma and Phi, and continues to play up and mess with the more fantastic concepts of VLR. 

Also, don't buy this game if you don't like wildly inaccurate takes on modern science (not that you should've made it through VLR anyways), and definitely don't buy it if you can't stand bad animation. The voice acting is fairly good and for me redeemed the somewhat hamfisted, awkward animation, but not everyone would agree. All that said, I loved this game - and if you want to enjoy an incredibly over-the-top, mind-twisty, sometimes touching and sometimes groan-inducing end to a fantastic if sometimes flawed series, this is the game for you.

When all are faced with the choice of the coin toss, I got it right on the first shot and saw the game credits roll.  I had no clue what the heck just happened.  For a good portion of the first half of the game, that pretty much summed everything up.  I had absolutely no clue what the hell was going on.  I was either killing people or not killing people and there did not seem to be much by way of connection to anything.  It wasn't until much later in the game where everything started coming together and started making some kind of sense.  That is my complaint about this installment of the Zero Escape Series.  It was good, but I spent so long with a big question mark over my head, that I almost put it up and was going to resign myself to not knowing what, if anything happened.  This fragmented form of story telling in my opinion made it the weakest of the three.  
Now.. here is my dilemma.  This game left a lot of unanswered questions.  I don't know whether there was more plans to release a spin off, or another Zero Escape installment.  I chalk it up to leaving these "questions" in here so that way you can formulate your own theories about a few things.  Whatever the reasoning, they did manage to clear up the majority of the loose ends and tie things together quite well.  Do you really get the answers that you wanted when you saw the end to VLR?  I know I didn't.  In fact, when I watched the true ending, I was questioning why in the hell did they bother with a true ending that really did not end? So why still recommend this game? 39816036.review:
Original 999 (Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors) was released back in 2009 on Nintendo DS to very positive reviews on how it tackled the mix of virtual novel and "escape the room" puzzles, while also using it's branching narrative, common for visual novels, as a plot point for many worlds interpretation influenced plot. It was also one of the first attempts, to my knowledge, to bring the Cube (the movie) ideas to video game format, mixing horror, thriller and mystery novel and becoming somewhat of the "What if Cube, Saw and Agatha Christie's "And Then There Were None" were anime". Virtue's Last Reward followed 3 years later on PS Vita and 3DS, and then in 2016 Zero Time Dilemma was released as a final chapter of the plot on the same systems, but also on PC.

As mentioned, all games are made with the same basic structure: most of the story is told via visual novel segments, which tend to have no puzzles or choices (though that gradually changes with every next game), while at times game switches to the escape the room puzzles, which require you to solve puzzles, find items and do the usual puzzle game stuff to get to the next visual novel bit. Another common concept is the idea of branching timelines and multiple endings. First game had very few of them and, as such, in the original version didn't have a Flow Chart for "jumping" between the timelines, but starting with the second game the timelines and jumps between them become much more complex. Being influenced by Cube and Saw, games also tend to deal with pretty dark themes and while it varies from game to game, it is common to expect lots of characters dying in horrible ways in different timelines with the main goal, usually, being finding the best possible solution where no one should die. Finally, I should really mention that the entire trilogy has absolutely amazing soundtrack by Shinji Hosoe and while very few tracks seem to be exclusive to a particular game and most themes repeat from game to game, the themes themselves are really good and it is a real shame that the soundtracks are not sold alongside the games.

Zero Time Dilemma in particular, though, is a mess. Most of it feels as if "David Cage really liked Saw and was Japanese", since instead of following on the cohesive storylines like in previous games, you're usually just presented with a scene, barely connected to other scenes (a common issue of Quantic Dream games). And then the scene develops, usually involving the escape the room segment, and then it ends with either everyone or some people dying in absolutely horrible shock value torture porn pointlessly brutal ways, or ending with less gore but then dropping the scene and asking you to go to another mostly disconnected one. There is a story reason for this structure and the 3 main characters instead of one approach does bring in curious possibilities for the story, but it's so dumb most of the time and very much not worth it. You will be watching people dying horribly and then going "Oh, this reminds me of this famous philosophic dilemma!" and proceeding to talk about it for several minutes (while still dying or in immediate danger of horrible death). And when everything has been explained, you'll see that barely anything has been resolved, and what was, was done in such an unnecessarily convoluted way that the whole experience feel like it wasn't worth it. And it really isn't worth it. There are rare smart moments, there are rare great puzzles. But unlike The Nonary Games, ZTD is not something I can recommend to anyone but the absolute die-hard-est fans of the series.

39012514.review:
I hardly ever write reviews, but I felt that it was necessary to do so for this game.

[h1]Story[/h1]
The story was excellent and it was a good way to finish up the series. It didn't come out as well as either of the previous games' stories, in my opinion, but it got the job done and left me somewhat satisfied.

[h1]Visuals[/h1]
The visuals were pretty enough although I hated the janky animations. The fact that mouths sometimes just didn't move at all when a character was talking, or that hair just ripped through bodies made it an annoying experience most of the time, but especially during intense scenes. I strongly preferred the more static visual novel style of VLR, but it didn't make ZTD unplayable by any means.

[h1]Music[/h1]
Music was good as always. Only had a few instances where I felt the score was a little too powerful for what was happening or the other way around.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Or rather lack thereof. Scenes play out without you having to click to go to the next line and the scenes have a more 'cinematic' feel to them. So you are basically not allowed to do anything by yourself, except during the puzzle rooms and the decision games. It felt more like watching a movie than playing a game. During each of the long discussion scenes I felt my attention slip more than once, while this was never the case during previous games because I was forced to read and click, so I had to be looking at the screen.
The fact that jumping between fragments and teams was available from the very start made it so that not a single choice felt even remotely pressuring aside from that one in the AB game format. There wasn't a single time where I thought "oh no, if I choose this now, they might choose this and screw me over, but what if they don't". Nor was there any time where I actually legitimately felt bad for a choice that had a bad outcome for a certain team.
Another issue I had specifically with the fact that this is a port is that the memo feature is virtually unusable because drawing with a mouse sucks. The least they could've done was allow keyboard input for typing (which would've also been cool for the password inputs etc.)

[h1]Final[/h1]
Overall I am very glad that we got this game after all the issues it went through, but I'm not happy with the design choices that were made for it. It's obvious they went for a style that was very much inspired by the West (TellTale Games), rather than sticking to the original VN style. The cinematic scenes, the (largely unnecessary) gore and fountains of blood, and the fact that some of the characters did OOC things just made me roll my eyes most of the time.
All in all I would say I recommend this game solely for the fact that it's the one that wraps up a lot of the story.

38984458.review:
La última entrega de una de mis sagas favoritas, Zero Escape.

Es una saga compleja, con muchas paradojas y vínculos que te pueden dejar un poco confuso si uno no presta mucha atención. A pesar de que es uno de sus encantos, también puede volverse su punto débil. ZTD no es un mal juego, pero dentro de la saga pierde fuerza. Es difícil hacer un buen final para una trilogía y, especialmente, cuando es tan esperado y no hay mucho presupuesto. La narrativa de ZTD a veces resulta confusa, ciertas cosas resultan forzadas (en mi opinión, especialmente el final) y, teniendo en cuenta la saga completa, bastantes cosas quedan sin responder.

En ZTD se optó por cambiar de una manera un tanto drástica el gameplay, narrativa y visualmente. Desapareció la narración literaria del protagonista y pasó a ser 100% diálogo. No está mal hecho pero quita cierto nivel de inmersión del jugador. Esto, mezclado con que visualmente pasó a ser 100% 3d y la acción/narración dependía de diálogos y acciones de los personajes, fue un punto muy negativo. Por motivos de presupuesto, los modelos en cuanto a expresiones y movimiento no eran muy allá, lo que a la hora de crear tensión, emoción o una escena dramática puede revertir el efecto y hacer que resulte ridículo. Por suerte, la banda sonora de Shinji Hosoe compensa en muchos momentos por lo buena que es. En VLR la mecánica de juego es similar, pero dada su narración la tensión sigue presente mientras que en ZTD esa atmósfera se pierde un poco. 

En resumen; ZTD es un final para la trilogía un poco regular. No es un mal juego pero tampoco es un juego muy bueno. Sin embargo, lo sigo recomendado para los fans de saga, por el cariño a la saga, porque ZTD sigue teniendo un valor nostálgico por la presencia de personajes que salen en juegos anteriores, y porque los puzzles me resultaron entretenidos.

Having played the previous two games, I was really looking forward to this. But 6 hours in I felt an overwhelming urge to play something else. That was months ago, and I just can't find the motivation to give it another chance when there are so many other time wasters out there. Unfortunately it's too late to demand my money back.

Now this is a matter of taste, but ZTD's chaotic, disjointed storytelling structure bugs the hell out of me. I loved the precedessors because making a decision, and watching the consequences unfold before your eyes was so much fun. ZTD hops from scene to scene seemingly at random and you don't get to see the consequences of your actions until MUCH later.  This caused me to stop caring and just about killed the story for me. I don't care if it all comes together and starts to make sense 15+ hours in. I want a story right away, not disjointed puzzle pieces of one.

I also didn't like how the story would 'end' repeatedly after ONE SINGLE ROOM. No, not the 'to be continued' kind of cliffhanger, but an actual ending. After. One. Room. Not just once, but every single time I did a room during those first 6 hours.

I also felt that the story sequences were much shorter than in previous installments, though that could be because the animations are awkward and many of the voice actors amateurish at best. Plus some of the characters who appeared in the previous games have undergone off screen character development that felt forced and unbelievable.

p.s. those who say that the voice actors are good don't know what good voice acting sounds like. Horizon: Zero Dawn has good voice acting. As does Dragon Age Inquisition. This does not.

38188680.review:
Me considero un jugador de juegos tipo FPS/FPS-RPG/Fighting... sin embargo, este juego (y saga) ha sido uno de los mejores que he jugado en mi vida, y quedé con un sabor "agridulce" al terminarlo ya que "no hay más juego ni historia".

Una novela visual con elementos de point and click y resolución de puzzles y acertijos, más el agregado de toma de decisiones respecto a hechos puntuales que cambia el curso de los acontecimientos según lo decidido.

La historia es increíble, con muchos "idas y vueltas", con un desarrollo de personajes en general muy cuidado y bien expuesto, lo que hace que, a poco de iniciado en la hisotira, uno siempre tenga algún tipo de sentimiento hacia ellos y que ninguno te deje indiferente. Las situaciones y revelaciones mantendrán tu interés y llevarán tu asombro y perplejidad a un nivel que muy pocos juegos pueden llegar, lo que hace que la saga sea una pieza única y jugarla sea toda una experiencia.

La música también es excelente, con piezas y melodías sublimes que acompañan perfectamente la situación. Los controles son bastante básicos y funcionan bien, aunque extraño de VLC que el click derecho del mouse realice "zoom-out".

Como puntos en contra, podemos mencionar los gráficos, que si bien son los mejores de la saga, apenas "cumplen", así como la duración (unas 25 a 30 horas), más corto que VLR. También la ausencia de traducciones (oficiales y/o de fans), ya que los únicos idiomas disponibles son el japonés y el inglés. Tampoco se puede seleccionar individualmente el idioma del audio y de los subtítulos.

Si bien se puede jugar sin haber jugado previamente a las entregas anteriores, tiene muchísimas referencias a estos, por lo que es FUERTEMENTE recomendado jugar primero al 999, luego al VLR y recién a ZTD, para que la experiencia sea única.

Tambien recomiendo NO leer las wikis hasta completar la saga, ya que en las mismas hay mucha información cruzada entre los 3 juegos y se corre el riesgo de perder el elemento sorpresa.

36869679.review:
First off, play the two Nonary games first if you want this one to make sense.

Secondly, I have nominated this game for "The game with a character I'd most like to punch in the face repeatedly" in the Steam Awards. That character is Eric, who is quite possibly the worst person I have ever encountered in 2D or 3D, and I've met some really shitty people in real life.

If you can get past the pathetic waste of (virtual) DNA that is Eric (and he's not the only unlikable character in the game), then I would recommend ZTD, although not unreservedly.

The graphics are a marked improvement over VLR - I wasn't a fan of the move away from cel-shading to 3D models, especially when their expressions didn't change (for example, Clover continuing to smile happily despite just discovering a corpse), but I'm pleased to say the 3D modelling in ZTD is of a much higher quality than VLR.

Storywise, without revealing any spoilers, I found it too fragmented and this affected the flow and pacing too much compared with the previous two games.

With regards to gameplay, I found it much heavier on the VN side with fewer escape rooms than 999 and VLR, but that could just be my perception and related to the pacing element I mentioned above.

Overall it's an adequate conclusion to the trilogy, if not an overwhelmingly satisfying one. If you enjoyed the first two games then pick this one up, otherwise don't bother.

36512414.review:
[h1]Definamos que es antes de nada:[/h1]

Tenemos que ser francos, no es un juego de acción sino más bien una novela visual llevada al 3d o una película interactiva en la cual puedes resolver tú los puzzles y tomar decisiones. Dicho esto...

Dentro de su particular campo esta es la tercera parte de una saga... la cual sitúa los acontecimientos ocurridos entre el primer y segundo juego (si... suena raro pero para entenderlo tendrás que empaparte de la historia y jugarlos ;P)

[h1]Valoración y nota:[/h1]

Es uno de esos juegos que se te puede hacer pesado al principio pero consigue engancharte... juega mucho con teorías relativas las cuales para que engañar... a todos nos han atrapado alguna vez (o me negareis que no habéis tenido inquietudes rayantes acerca del espacio/tiempo y el origen de muchas cosas... ya sabéis todo muy Zen XDD), pero al mismo tiempo tiene un entramado bastante oscuro aunque un tanto explotado, ya sabéis, mastermind detrás de todo que tiene un objetivo y tal... 


En los tiempos que corren ya esta casi todo inventado asi que me da por saco ver tanta gente quejándose de que falta originalidad... pese a todo hacia mucho que un juego no me conseguía darme tanto en el coco como en la patata (Peero habéis visto mi símil tó guapo con la comida eh eh?! vale ya me callo uwu) 

En definitiva le doy un [b]8/10[/b] a la saga en sí no solo a este juego... el por si solo se quedaria en un [b]7[/b].

La razón es que yo primero me pase este y aunque por eso diria que es mi preferido (ya sabéis los feels…) pero tengo que reconocer que flaquea ante sus predecesores en cuanto al carisma de los personajes y entramado de los retos.

Aunque es un acierto como lo han llevado porque no es fácil crear una historia tan bien hilada así como así... por eso chapó. 

[h1] Mi comentario personal acerca de esta saga[/h1]

Esto era lo que iba a poner como análisis en un principio pero mi di cuenta que ponía demasiado énfasis en mi experiencia personal y no en como debería verlo de cara a gente que no pueda entender mi planteamiento asi que... lo añado por si alguien quisiera noticear mi fangirleo >.>" 

Pueh eso... 

[spoiler]Este juego así como sus anteriores entregas son para mí una joya... no porque sea especialmente sobresaliente pero consigue dar a tu cerebro una buena colleja y recapacitar sobre cosas que por ti mismo nunca te habrías planteado...

Igual que una película en la cual al final te das cuenta que todo estaba conectado pero no supiste relacionarlo en su momento y en este caso tienes la oportunidad de ver por ti mismo todos los diversos caminos...

Pero noo solo es eso... ves como los personajes van evolucionando y dándose cuenta (o no) de las cosas... como crece la confianza o la traición, como surge el sacrificio o el egoísmo y como todo esto les pasa a los mismos individuos siendo la única diferencia la circunstancia que les ha llevado a dicha situación. 

Concuerda totalmente con mi filosofía acerca de como las personas no tienen una naturaleza establecida... uno avanza y mejora/empeora en función de a los acontecimientos y experiencias que se ha tenido que enfrentar. 

Aunque no es una excusa por la cual todo pueda justificarse.
[/spoiler]

36481910.review:
Zero Escape: Zero Time Dilemma really feels like a letdown after the Nonary Games. I'll try not to include spoilers, but it'll be kind of hard without discussing my biggest gripe with the game.

Tl;Dr - The change from first-person view to outside observer of events killed the atmosphere and suspense, the game no longer has any meaningful mystery because you're given next to no clues on who's secretly killing people and who's Zero until the game is just suddenly ready to reveal their identities, Then some other minor gripes. Ultimately, though, you should probably play if you care about the overarching plot. 

First off, Atmosphere. The Nonary Games both had only partial voice acting, and were in traditional VN first-person view. This brought two things: Immersion, and focus on the environment. Both of those things were lost in Zero Time Dilemma. Sure, the music was just as unsettling, but it was played behind fully-voiced conversations, and the player was an outside observer instead of a participant in the Jigsaw-esque "game" the characters were part of.

Second, Horror. Sure, this could be part of atmosphere, but I think it deserves it's own footnote. In the Nonary games, when a character died, it was a terrifying thing to discover because you KNOW one of the other characters killed that guy, and you could totally be next. In Zero Time Dilemma, characters dying like that just brings an end to the memory fragment. That, combined with the altered atmosphere, just makes those scenes seem tragic instead of chilling.

Third, this game lost it's "whodunnit" factor when it decided the player didn't deserve all the information to at least try to solve the mystery on their own. Who chopped up Junpei and strangled Mira in the third timeline? We never get any clues, just the answer.

Then, there's the entire existence of a character named "Q." When the game starts, you're told that "Q" is the kid wearing the helmet, but then you almost immediately learn that his name is actually Sean, but this "Q" character is still referenced, even though he is literally never shown until after you've seen the timeline where two children, "Delta" and "Phi" are born during the game's events. I continued to assume that Q and Sean were the same person until Delta revealed himself to be Q, and that happens at the same time we learn that a now-grown Delta (time travel, it's a Zero Escape game and timelines are not boundaries. There's a 22-year-old with the literal mind of a 67-year old.) has been there the whole time. We, the outside observer, are never, ever shown this character, and no, it's not because we've been secretly playing as him. We're Carlos, Sean, and Diana.

Anyway, The fact that we are given next to no information on Q's existence ruins the potential to discover the truth for yourself. Yeah, he's locked in the game with the rest of you, but he's not a player, but he somehow is central to the plot.

Fourth, things get re-explained WAY TOO OFTEN!!! It would make sense if this were one of the older games and you had to restart at the beginning because you hit a bad end, but with the fragment timeline system in ZTD, there's no need. For example, Eric explains how he met fellow player Mira 3 times.

Fifth, there was a huge step back on the central theme of the games, which has been people with the ability to pull information from past, future, and alternate realities. In Virtue's Last Reward, the theme of "noting is set in stone until it's observed" expanded upon 9 hours 9 people 9 doors's light exploration into the theoretical "Morphogenetic field," which allows you to, at the end of the game, complete a puzzle and send the information back in time to save a child's life.
Sixth, on the topic of the first game, you meet the protagonist from there again. Sure, they explain it away as part of the plot, but they turned him into an uncaring asshole.

If you played and enjoyed the Nonary Games, you need to play ZTD just in case they make a Zero Escape based on the "happy end" timeline from there. Though if they do that, I really hope it's a back-to-basics entry that plays out more like 999 or VLR than ZTD.

Don't play this game. Play Zero Escape: Virtues Last Reward instead. And then maaaaaybe if you like that so much you want more, come back and play this. Why?

This game has what ZE:VLR had, but less of it. The story is less compelling, the reveal of the major conceit of the game is poorly pulled of by comparisonf, and it feels like there are fewer puzzles. This game also really drags at the begining, and your first through jumps through the story line don't make sense - not in an "oh, maybe this is a mystery they'll solve later" kind of way, but in a very 4th-wall breaking, "I'm thinking about the design of this game instead of having fun playing it" kind of way.

This game also has some of the same problems ZE;VLR had, most notably a couple of puzzles where you'll definitely be googling the solutions and then wondering "how did you expect me to figure that out???" This goes beyond puzzles being challenging - some of the solutions just feel cheap, while others are too easy, and the game rarely manages to land in that sweet spot in the midddle that ZE:VLR hit more frequently.

The one great thing about this game is the endgame. Just like ZE:VLR the ending goes off into some absolute insanity, but of the kind that makes perfect sense with all that's been leading up to it. The plot really comes together at the end... but good luck forcing yourself to get there.

34668686.review:
First things first, Zero Time Dilemma is the third entry in the Zero Escape series, and you need to play the other 2 games in order to understand this one properly, with that said, let's continue.
Zero Time Dilemma is by far the worst of the three games, but that does not mean it's bad, it's just not as good as the others, but that's on a story point of view, personally, i prefer the storytelling mechanic on this game (movie like, something similar to a telltale game) than the storytelling mechanics on the other games (text based), i think it makes the characters look more human and makes the story less monotone. I also think most of the puzzles on this game were better than most of the puzzles on the other games (of course, there are exceptions), i think that because the puzzles on this one are more about decifrating codes and finding passwords than doing math based minigames (nothing wrong with that, i just think it got very annoying in the other games). There's also one important thing that differs this game from the others, the story is not told in a linear way, you play through fragments and later you find out what actually happened and how these fragments matched with other fragments, initially i hated this, i thought it was confusing and ruined the storytelling, but as i continued playing, i noticed it's not that bad, mainly when things start to make sense. 
So, after all, what makes this one worst than the other ones? Well, i'll start by stating that the story is overall weaker than in the other 2 games, but that isn't so much of a problem, because it's still rather interesting, what i actually disliked a lot about this game were the poorly made plot twists near the end, don't get me wrong, there are some plot twists in this game that turns the other 2 games around, but mainly the final 2 ones, involving the mastermind and his "complex motives" that are NEVER entirely explained, i won't spoil it for you, but it does ruin the experience a little bit.
Well, so in conclusion, the game is weaker than the other 2, but not bad, and if you played the other 2 and want to finish the story, you totally should play this.

34565796.review:
[h1]The Less Stated, the Better[/h1]

[b]Obviously, you've already played 999 and Virtues Last Reward.[/b]

Otherwise, I would suggest playing those before purchasing this title. Playing this game within the vacuum of itself would be mildly entertaining, but you'd miss the entire point.

[h1]This game successfully bridges the story of all past titles, while taking on the INSANELY ambitious task of explaining how human existence works: and it excells fantastically.[/h1]

If that sounds like fun to you, I strongly suggest picking up the earlier titles. All 3 are great games.

[h1]Quick Pros and Cons[/h1]

+     More blood
+     A more ambitious storyline than past titles (if you can even believe that)
+     The fully-animated cutscenes, as opposed to the dialog boxes of earlier titles, are a welcome addition (even if some lip-syncing is out of place and some of the voice acting is a little drab during violent parts)
+     The puzzles are harder


-     The puzzles are too hard (trying to decipher an abstract alphabet, [spoiler]relating its symbols to a base 10 numeric system, and then converting/downscaling answers into a base 13 numeric system[/spoiler] is a little insane. There is also one puzzle in the game which is actually unsolvable...so have fun kids)

-     I cannot propose a better solution but...[b]Pacing the game episodically SUCKS[/b]. Having to jump around from fragment to fragment really divests yourself from the characters and the immediate plot points. Very often, I'd be lost and have to back-track the timeline to figure out where the hell I was and what I was doing. However, this helps the pacing to be less repetitive than Virtues Last Reward. So a small plus there.

-     You will actually get stuck a few times during regular playthrough of the storyline. There are some mechanics at work in the menu screens/flowcharts that are witheld from your knowledge. They are also never explained. You [b]will[/b] have to replay certain scenes ad nauseum to create different outcomes. This is unique to this specific game.

But.. when you skip the phrase that is on the screen you also skip a bunch of unsaid dialogues!! So you can't skip dialogues if you want to know the full story.

Ok, the game finally starts.. the 3D is awful.. this is a 2016 PS4 game with PS1 graphics.. the characters are well drawn but the background is really bad 3D. There are a lot of objects you simply can't figure what is just by looking.

3D puzzles are bad.. I use mouse to play, so drag to rotate and click to select. Some times when I try to rotate with an object under the mouse it clicks instead.

Also I miss RIGHT MOUSE BUTTON to go back from a zoom!! I have either press escape or click "Back". On the long run this makes a huge difference.

No second chances when you miss a password (like the last games). When you miss, you're kicked out the screen and have to click again to try again.

Time flow is a mess.. I want to follow a line I chose in the beginning but I have no way to know without having to click on a picture and play it to the end.

I'm pretty sure the story is awesome but the devs removed a lot of simple helpful features from the other games.. I'll keep playing to the end because I'm a fan of the series but after two hours playing I confess that I have some regrets on buying this game.

I cannot say I would recommend this game to someone who has not played the first two as they would not have any idea what is going on or have any backstory, but it's a game that closes the Zero Escape trilogy well.

34194686.review:
Zero Time Dilemma is drastically better than its predecessors as far as presentation goes.  I would say the graphics have a comic book style feel.  I really did appreciate it, especially when compared against the other two games in the series.  I also felt the voice acting was drastically better, although I hated zero’s English voice actor so much that I played the game with the Japanese voice actors and English subs.  I also felt the puzzles were drastically better then Virtues Last Reward.  There were a few that made absolutely no sense, but for the most part I felt they were well done.

I will say that I felt the way the menus for the time flows were laid out just was terrible.  Most of the time I had no idea what I was supposed to be clicking on or where.  It’s divided into story fragments menus, global flow menus, and character flow menus.  I guess it was kind of fun to do a character menu scene and then after see where it appeared on the global flow and if that’s entirely how you picked things that would be fine, but eventually it gets to the point where you have to go into sub menus of the character flow menu to find the right path or clicking on the global flow menu and then choosing paths from there to find the character path.  It was too much.  I guess if the plan was to have the menu’s be its own puzzle then job well done…but I’m pretty sure it wasn’t, which means it was just poorly designed.

Despite that if the story was good I would recommend the game, but it’s just not.  I don’t understand why people praise the story of this series.  First, this game is a direct sequel so it’s not like you can skip the other games.  You’ll be utterly lost if you haven’t played the others.  Which is certainly fine, but the way character act and the way the story is laid out makes no sense.  You fine yourselves at a Mars simulation in the desert, maybe in Nevada.  You have all agreed to be part of this test because the organization was paying people $500k to participate (I’m not sure  who thought that was an accurate number, no one is paying people that much money for this.  Especially, a group of randos with no real skills).  You are then captured by someone calling himself Zero and forced into a death trap game in a bunker where 6/9 of you will die. So again it sets up a murder mystery…but it’s just so utterly terribly told and just a mess at every turn, explaining why would all involve spoilers though.

[spoiler] First, so long as you’ve played the other games it takes all of 2 hours to figure out every single mystery in the game except who is Zero.  It has the same problem of Virutes Last Reward, but at least thankfully this game is shorter.  So you only have to wait about 20 hours after figuring everything out for the characters to admit it.  Such as it’s painfully obvious Sigma and Diana are the parents of Phi…to the point where I’m not sure if this was supposed to be a mystery or not.  Diana and Phi constantly act like mother and daughter…so when it’s revealed at the very end they are and the characters act surprised I was just utterly baffled.  

There is also a subplot that one of the characters is a serial killer (not zero, I mean another serial killer).  I mean it’s Mira, their isn’t even a question.  She acts like a sociopath in everything she says and Sean’s hint that he knows about a serial killer so painfully points to Mira that it’s just ridiculous.  Again…since it was so obvious I’m not even sure if it was a mystery.

So really the only mystery in the game is who is zero and it’s an unsolvable mystery.  Zero is a character that you have never heard of.  See it turns out Zero is really Phi’s twin brother Delta who Sigma and Diana put in an alien teleporter that teleported him to the year 1904 where he was raised by German scientists (and I mean clearly he became a Nazi, there is no way this lunatic that performs horrendous experiments on people wasn’t one of Hitler’s top scientists).  He came up with this master plan in order to fix the paradox that if he didn’t put people in this death trap game he would never have been born, because he gets conceived in the death trap game…except it’s not a paradox, so there was no reason for him to do this.  He exists simply because the teleporter sent him to a world where he exists…there was absolutely no reason for him to recreate the circumstances where he was born.

Oh yea, I should also mention the entire game is an unreliable narrator.  It turns out Zero was part of your group of 9 the whole time and it was really a group of 10.  They just never really mention or reference him and I guess it’s supposed to be that the player is him.  It’s a cheap twist.  It takes the genius of Agatha Christie’s twist in The Murder of Roger Ackroyd and bastardizes it.  The game literally could have done that twist though and it would have been genius.  All it would have required was the game telling you that you are the character of Delta and everything is seen through your eyes and the characters could have directly been talking to you.  That’s not what happens here, no one really acknowledges Delta’s existence, he’s apparently there in every scene, but no one mentions him at all.  Clues all certainly point to him existing, but the game tries very hard to obfuscate that.  

The game wanted a grand twist at the end, but that twist also ruins the murder mystery occurring in the game.  I guess a lot of people don’t care.  They seem to think this twist is a masterstroke, but I can’t really accept it.  It’s just too many logical leaps. (1) that when characters talk about Q, they mean Delta and not the robot who the game makes you think is Q (2) That Delta is a 124 year old man who is the son of Sigma and Diana who was sent back in time in an alien teleporter (3) That Delta/Q is Zero and their motive for putting everyone together is to stop a terrorist in the future form killing 8 billion people so really he’s a good guy.  Even if you could make the logical leap that hey wait this is weird the game doesn’t seem to be talking about the robot boy when they are saying Q…their must secretly be a 10th person here which is me…and if they are doing that it must mean that Q is Zero!  I don’t see how then you can connect the motive of…he must be doing all these horrible things in order to stop terrorists from wiping out humanity.  This point is literally never even brought up until the very end of the game, so you couldn’t possibly know this was the motive.

I guess the game is a serviceable time travel scifi story.  I don’t care for it because I dislike the twist that it deals with alien teleporter technology.  Also the ending where everyone is now friends with Mira…who again is still a brutal serial killer…who they all remember specifically murdering everyone in the game as well as the dozens she killed outside the game, but apparently is now sorry so it’s alright (what serial killer has ever said, oh I’m sorry I’m going to be a nice person now). [/spoiler] 

Ugh, all I wanted was a good murder mystery.  Why is that so difficult.

Spike Chunsoft has done it once again! Zero Time Dilemma is a great sequel to 999 and VLR. It basically picks up right where VLR left off (if you follow the story close enough) and you get all the feels in the story. It has great new characters and a good building off of old characters from 999 and VLR. 

VLR has to be my favorite story-wise, but Zero Time Dilemma had me going "OH S**T NO" after completing puzzles. These were my FAVORITE puzzles. I only have one complaint--and it is merely because of personal interest--but...

*SPOILERS* *SPOILERS* *SPOILERS*

If all the SHIFTers retain their memories, why does it seem like a number of them just FORGET the crimes of one of the major characters?! It seems like a continuity gap in the story.

*END OF SPOILER*

I guess one more thing is that the graphics can be a bit weird at times. Characters mouths sometimes don't move when they talk and animations aren't very fluid. Still this is a good PC port and doesn't distract from the story. 

Regardless, I love this game and would recommend to anyone who loves visual novels, puzzles, the previous nonary game stories, and/or other Spike Chunsoft works.

33801147.review:
You're either going to love this game or hate it. Be warned that you cannot play ZTD without first completing both 999 and VLR in that order.

ZTD is a very different direction for the series. It doesn't play like a traditional VN, it's more of a Telltale style--a really low budget TT game.

I don't put that lightly. This game has horrendous models that make VLR's look good by comparison, and it also has the most stilted, stiff, and just downright terrible animation I think I have ever seen in a game this popular. It looks absolutely awful. As for the voice acting, it's hit and miss. It's servicable overall but it's not as good as VLR's. Nearly every escape puzzle is terrible in ZTD as well. There's a couple interesting ideas here and there, but the game feels a need to make every room feel like a scavenger hunt. Unlike VLR where the puzzles were consistently challenging and logical, ZTD tends to present solutions that will either warrant a reaction of "oh, come on!" or "how in the hell was I supposed to know that?!"

ZTD's puzzles are not hard. They work almost exclusively in a manner where the most challenging part is finding wherever the hell Zero decided to hide every piece you need. If a puzzle seems impossible, it's simply because it is. However, unlike in VLR where characters would tell you when you were wasting your time and didn't have enough clues, ZTD's cast is often as oblivious as you are, resulting in indefinite times of trial and error. You'll often become irritated not because you weren't smart enough to figure out a simple solution, but because that answer was hidden away in some corner you wouldn't have considered to look in. As someone who disliked most of 999's puzzles and adored VLR thoroughly, these are the worst puzzles in the entire Zero Escape series by a landslide.

So, why am I recommending this game that I'm tearing to shreds?

Because once you pass all of the lackluster escapes, preferably with a spoiler-free guide such as this one
http://www.thonky.com/zero-time-dilemma/
you are in for one hell of a story. That's all I can say without getting into spoiler details.

Overall, ZTD has a fantastic story that will surprise you several times, and it's safe to say that it will stick with you long after you've completed it. Just look past the terrible presentation and the awful puzzles.
